{"timeCrawl": "20:15:00", "uri": "711095430", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:15:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"title": "Metro Toronto", "uri": "metronews.ca", "id": "391"}, "url": "http://www.metronews.ca/news/world/2017/08/17/donald-trump-racist-mass-murder-as-an-anti-terror-tactic.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "This time, Donald Trump said the non-massacre deterred terror for \"35 years,\" adding an extra 10 years to the original lie.\n\nReturning to the anti-Muslim bigotry that was a hallmark of his campaign, U.S. President Donald Trump once again endorsed a fictional U.S. massacre of Muslim terrorists, with bullets dipped in pigs' blood, as an example of how to deter terrorism.\n\nIt would be extraordinary even if the story were true: the president of the United States advocating extrajudicial killing, involving explicit religious animus, as an anti-terror tactic.\n\nBut the story is fake. The president was asking the world to \"study\" an online hoax.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught,\" Trump wrote on Twitter on Thursday afternoon. \"There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nTrump did not elaborate, this time, on what the late U.S. general John Pershing supposedly did. But he told a detailed (and false) story about Pershing's actions at a campaign rally during the Republicans' South Carolina primary in February 2016.\n\nHe claimed then that Pershing had executed 49 Muslim prisoners during the U.S. occupation of the Philippines in the early-1900s, adding religious insult by dipping the bullets in the bloods of pigs, which Muslims are forbidden to consume.\n\n\"This was a terrible problem. They were having terrorism problems just like we do,\" Trump said then. \"And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists and he took 50 men and he took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. You heard that, right? He took 50 bullets! And he dipped them in pigs' blood.\n\n\"And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said, 'You go back to your people and you tell them what happened.' And for 25 years there wasn't a problem, OK? Twenty-five years there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nThe myth-busting website Snopes found no evidence of the story, which has circulated by email since at least 2001. Snopes found anecdotal accounts that Pershing or other military leaders had threatened to bury Muslims along with pig carcasses.\n\nThis time, Trump said the non-massacre deterred terror for \"35 years,\" adding an extra 10 years to the original lie.\n\nThe Thursday tweet came 45 minutes after he issued a conventional response to the terrorist attack in Barcelona. Trump has sometimes chafed at aides' advice to adopt a more traditionally presidential manner.\n\n\"The United States condemns the terror attack in Barcelona, Spain, and will do whatever is necessary to help. Be tough & strong, we love you!\" he wrote in the original tweet.\n\nTrump reignited talk of his anti-Muslim bigotry as he continued to stoke the controversy over his general racial attitudes that has led to his greatest crisis as president to date, with Republican legislators continuing to denounce him Thursday for blaming \"both sides\" for the violence at a white supremacist demonstration in Charlottesville, Va., on Saturday.\n\nOn Thursday morning, he issued a series of tweets in support of the preservation of Confederate monuments -- describing them not only as part of U.S. historical but a \"beautiful\" part of U.S. \"culture.\"\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments,\" he wrote. \"You can't change history, but you can learn from it. Robert E Lee, Stonewall Jackson -- who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish! Also ... the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\"\n\nTennessee Sen. Be tough & strong, we love you! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nHe then followed it up with a second tweet, praising a discredited story of a 20th-century atrocity.\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nThe tweet harked back to Mr Trump's speech on the campaign trail in February 2016. He referenced the supposed actions of General Pershing, and suggested them as a blueprint for how terrorists should be treated.\n\nThe only problem was that no historians believe the US general did what Mr Trump claimed.\n\nThe president said that, during the Moro rebellion in the Philippines between 1901 and 1913, General John Pershing executed Muslim insurgents with bullets dipped in pig's blood.\n\nCritics called it apocryphal, misleading or outright false.\n\nThe fact-checking website Snopes considered the evidence and called it a \"legend\", while Politifact rated it \"pants on fire\".\n\nWhile historians agree that there were indeed efforts to offend Muslim Filipinos, there was no evidence for the pigs' blood on bullets story.\n\nPolitifact reported: \"We decided to check with historians of the period to see what they thought of the story. We heard back from eight scholars. Most expressed skepticism that the specific story ever happened, and many added that Trump's takeaway is wrong-headed.\"\n\nThey pointed out, that, in addition to the shootings likely never having happened, Mr Trump's conclusion that it resulted in an era of peace was also misguided.\n\nHow the Barcelona terror attack unfolded 01:10", "id": "9783431", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", {"timeCrawl": "19:43:00", "uri": "711079569", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T19:43:00Z", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "source": {"title": "yahoo.com", "uri": "yahoo.com", "id": "228"}, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/trump-reacts-barcelona-terror-touting-debunked-anti-muslim-war-crime-tale-193215604.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "President Trump responded to the heartbreaking news of a terrorist attack in Spain on Thursday by peddling a debunked urban legend about a former Army general's harsh counterterrorism tactics more than a century ago.\n\nLess than an hour after condemning the attack in Barcelona, Trump encouraged his followers on Twitter to study up on United States Army Gen. John J. Pershing and what he did to Muslim terrorists when they were caught.\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\nTrump was referencing the discredited story about how Pershing executed 49 Muslims with bullets that had been dipped in pig's blood during the Philippine-American War of 1899-1902. According to legend, Pershing told the 50th Muslim to take one of those bullets back to his people as a warning of what would happen should they persist, and this supposedly led to a massive decline in radical terrorism from jihadists for the next several decades.\n\nPeople who believe in this myth say Pershing's tactic worked because under Islam, pig blood is considered unholy. During the campaign, Trump repeatedly trotted out this story.\n\nThe Washington Post reported that Trump told the story at a rally in North Charleston, S.C., in February 2016.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do. And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men, and he dipped 50 bullets in pigs' blood -- you heard that, right? He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: 'You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened.' And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. OK? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nPolitiFact, the fact-checking website, rated this statement \"pants on fire\" at the time. PolitiFact tried to verify Trump's account of Pershing's actions with eight different historians. All were skeptical that these events ever happened.\n\nLouis Jacobson, a correspondent for PolitiFact, noted that Pershing's memoir and a letter from Maj. Gen. J. Franklin Bell, the commander of the Philippines Division, to Pershing provide \"strong evidence\" that the U.S. forces did use pigs as a tactic against Muslim insurgents during that era. Nevertheless, they do not support the claims that Trump made, he said.\n\n\"There is no evidence that Pershing himself committed these acts, there is nothing said about the use of 50 bullets dipped in pig's blood, and most important, there is no evidence to support Trump's claim that this tactic was effective in stopping violence -- or that it would provide a useful policy today,\" Jacobson wrote.\n\nSnopes judged a similar story about Pershing killing Muslim terrorists and burying their bodies with pigs to be false.\n\nThe president is citing a fake story about shooting Muslims with bullets soaked in pig's blood. This is why my community lives in fear. https://t.co/R5sdnlYGty\n\n-- Rowaida Abdelaziz (@Rowaida_Abdel) August 17, 2017\n\nRead more from Yahoo News:\n\nRoy Moore, Luther Strange advance to runoff in Alabama Senate electionTrump appears to accidentally share Twitter disCharlottesville is a target for the alt-right. John Pershing executing dozens of Muslim prisoners with bullets dipped in pigs' blood, telling people to read up on the history after a terror attack in Barcelona, Spain, left more than a dozen people dead Thursday.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\" Trump tweeted after he condemned the attack and told Spain to be \"tough and strong.\"\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\nTrump first told the story about Pershing killing Muslim prisoners in the Philippines in the early 20th century while the presidential candidate was at a rally in Charleston, S.C., in February 2016.\n\n\"He took 50 bullets and he dipped them in pig's blood,\" Trump said. \"And he had his men load his rifles and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said, 'You go back to your people and you tell them what happened.' And for 25 years there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nUrban legend website Snopes.com called the story \"false\" and fact-checking website Politifact rated the tale \"pants on fire.\"\n\nHowever, there are historical accounts of U.S. soldiers burying pigs alongside dead Muslim fighters in the Philippinnes' Moro Province.\n\nThe tactic was supposedly used to scare Islamic insurgents known as \"juramentados\" into halting their attacks. To Muslims, pigs are unholy and the insurgents feared that if they died, Pershing's practice would deny them entry into heaven.\n\nThe story is highly controversial because it suggests that the government has used a deliberate form of religious discrimination as a successful anti-terror tactic. A 2009 biography of Pershing by Jim Lacey, a military analyst for the Institute for Defense Analyses, claimed to confirm that Pershing did use the tactic.\n\n\"Until now the historical verdict is that this was a vicious rumor and while it may have happened in occasion, Pershing neither knew about it nor, given his humane outlook, would have condoned such an action. That verdict is wrong as Pershing's own unpublished autobiography states,\" Lacey wrote in Pershing: A Biography, published by PalGrave MacMillan.\n\nThe book then cites an unpublished letter by Pershing, stating: \"These juramentado attacks were materially reduced in number by a practice the Army had already adopted, one that the Mohammedans held in abhorrence: The bodies were publicly buried in the same grave with a dead pig. It was not pleasant to have to take such measures but the prospect of going to hell instead of heaven sometimes deterred the would-be assassins.\"\n\nIn a 2010 interview, Lacey said he discovered {"timeCrawl": "21:46:00", "uri": "711129599", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:46:00Z", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "source": {"title": "The Inquisitr News", "uri": "inquisitr.com", "id": "2639"}, "url": "http://www.inquisitr.com/4437243/trumps-barcelona-attack-response-draws-massive-flak-for-reviving-myth-enforcing-double-standards/", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "President Donald Trump's response to Thursday's attack in Barcelona's Las Ramblas district has drawn a lot of criticism for the backstory behind the remarks, and the supposed \"double standard\" the President's words suggested.\n\nAccording to the HuffPost, Trump issued a statement via a series of Twitter posts on Thursday, a few hours after a van had plowed into a crowd at Barcelona, killing at least 13 people and injuring several others. Initially, Trump's remarks were \"measured\" and safe, as he promised to \"do whatever is necessary to help\" victims of the attack. Less than an hour later, Trump posted another tweet, alleging that \"radical Islamic terror\" was behind the incident, while referencing John \"Black Jack\" Pershing, an Army general who led the U.S. military and governed Moro province in the Philippines in the early 1900s.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nTrump's post-Barcelona attack remarks aren't unprecedented, as today wasn't the first time he referred to General John Pershing. According to Mother Jones, Trump described Pershing as a \"rough guy\" at the South Carolina Republican primaries in February 2016, telling the tale of a general who took a rather unorthodox approach to dealing with Muslim insurgents in the Philippines, in the early 1900s.\n\n\"He caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage...and he took the 50 terrorists and he took 50 men and dipped 50 bullets in pig's blood. You heard about that? He took 50 bullets and dipped them in pig's blood. And he has his men load up their rifles and he lined up the 50 people and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said, you go back to your people and you tell them what happened. And for 25 years there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nThe above quote suggests that Trump might have been 10 years off in his post-Barcelona attack tweet. But many people took issue with the tweet because the General Pershing story may have been an urban legend all along. Snopes first debunked the story more than 15 years ago, and subsequent updates to the publication's fact-checking article have also suggested that the mass execution supposedly spearheaded by Pershing is nothing but a \"rumor created on the internet,\" and that the general had actually favored peace talks with the Moros, as opposed to violent solutions.\n\nReactions to Donald Trump's Barcelona statement have mostly been negative, with several Twitter users accusing the President of enforcing double standards and citing a story that is believed to be untrue. Moreover, publications such as the Guardian pointed out how quickly Trump found a group to blame for the Barcelona incident, not long after it took him two days to blame the Charlottesville rallies on the far right, only for him to defend his original statement blaming \"both sides\" a day later.\n\n\"I wanted to make sure, unlike most politicians, that what I said was correct, not make a quick statement,\" said Trump on Tuesday, as quoted by the HuffPost.\n\n\"The statement I made on Saturday, the first statement, was a fine statement, but you don't make statements that direct unless you know the facts.\"\n\nThe HuffPost noted that Trump's quick reaction to the Barcelona attack is not the first time he has blamed \"radical Islamic terrorism\" for attacks, as he had issued similar statements, albeit without the General Pershing reference, following recent terrorist attacks in Paris, Manchester, and London.", "id": "9782595", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": {"timeCrawl": "22:19:00", "uri": "711141134", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:19:00Z", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "source": {"title": "Economic Times", "uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "id": "305"}, "url": "http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/ap-explains-why-is-trump-tweeting-about-a-wwi-general/articleshow/60111160.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "Trump tweeted on Thursday that people should \"study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nWhat is behind the tweet and the criticism? The AP explains:\n\nPERSHING AND THE PHILIPPINES\n\nGen. John \"Black Jack\" Pershing, who would rise to fame in World War I, was a U.S. Army commander and served as governor of the southern Philippines' mainly Muslim Moro province between 1909 and 1913. His tenure came as the U.S. was consolidating its control over the Philippines, which it had won as a result of the Spanish-American War. Pershing was confronted with a Moro insurgency, which he largely broke in June 1913 in a battle that killed some 500 Moro fighters.\n\nTRUMP AND TACTICS AGAINST TERRORISM\n\nIt's unclear. Trump did not cite any specific tactic employed by Pershing in his tweet on Thursday. But during the presidential campaign, he told a widely discredited story that Pershing had halted Muslim attacks in the Philippines by shooting rebels with bullets dipped in pigs' blood. Pork is taboo for Muslims, but that story has been widely debunked by historians as unsubstantiated or exaggerated. Fact-checking organizations such as Politifact rated Trump's claim as false.\n\nHowever, according to Politifact, Pershing wrote in a memoir that another U.S. commander in the Philippines had at least once \"seen to it\" that Muslim insurgents' bodies were buried in the same grave as a dead pig to serve as a warning to others. \"It was not pleasant to have to take such measures, but the prospect of going to hell instead of heaven sometimes deterred the would-be assassins,\" Pershing wrote. According to Politifact, a footnote to the 2013 edition of the memoir cited another general as telling Pershing in a letter that the practice had long been a custom \"to discourage crazy lunatics.\"\n\nTRUMP TWEETS A DEBUNKED STORY\n\nMany critical commentators believe Trump's tweet revived the specific story about Pershing and the bullets dipped in pigs' blood that he told during the campaign. But because Trump was not specific about the tactics he was referring to, it is not possible to tell with certainty. He could also have been referring to the burials cited in Pershing's memoirs. In either case, Trump's claim that Pershing's treatment of captured militants was the prime reason for the end of the insurgency is not supported by historical fact.", "id": "9786612", "details": {}, {"timeCrawl": "19:53:00", "uri": "711084729", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T19:53:00Z", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "source": {"title": "theStar.com", "uri": "thestar.com", "id": "1354"}, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2017/08/17/donald-trump-endorses-racist-mass-murder-as-an-anti-terror-tactic-citing-fake-story.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Returning to the anti-Muslim bigotry that was a hallmark of his campaign, U.S. President Donald Trump once again endorsed a fictional U.S. massacre of Muslim terrorists, with bullets dipped in pigs' blood, as an example of how to deter terrorism.\n\nIt would be extraordinary even if the story were true: the president of the United States advocating extrajudicial killing, involving explicit religious animus, as an anti-terror tactic.\n\nBut the story is fake. The president was asking the world to \"study\" an online hoax.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught,\" Trump wrote on Twitter on Thursday afternoon. \"There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nTrump did not elaborate, this time, on what the late U.S. general John Pershing supposedly did. But he told a detailed (and false) story about Pershing's actions at a campaign rally during the Republicans' South Carolina primary in February 2016.\n\nHe claimed then that Pershing had executed 49 Muslim prisoners during the U.S. occupation of the Philippines in the early-1900s, adding religious insult by dipping the bullets in the bloods of pigs, which Muslims are forbidden to consume.\n\n\"This was a terrible problem. They were having terrorism problems just like we do,\" Trump said then. \"And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists and he took 50 men and he took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. You heard that, right? He took 50 bullets! And he dipped them in pigs' blood.\n\n\"And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said, 'You go back to your people and you tell them what happened.' And for 25 years there wasn't a problem, OK? Twenty-five years there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nThe myth-busting website Snopes found no evidence to support the story, which has circulated by email since at least 2001. Snopes found anecdotal accounts that Pershing or other military leaders had threatened to bury Muslims along with pig carcasses.\n\nThis time, Trump said the non-massacre deterred terror for \"35 years,\" adding an extra 10 years to the original lie.\n\nThe Thursday tweet came 45 minutes after he issued a conventional response to the terrorist attack in Barcelona. Trump has sometimes chafed at aides' advice to adopt a more traditionally presidential manner.\n\n\"The United States condemns the terror attack in Barcelona, Spain, and will do whatever is necessary to help. Be tough & strong, we love you!\" he wrote in the original tweet.\n\nTrump reignited talk of his anti-Muslim bigotry as he continued to stoke the controversy over his general racial attitudes that has led to his greatest crisis as president to date, with Republican legislators continuing to denounce him Thursday for blaming \"both sides\" for the violence at a white supremacist demonstration in Charlottesville, Va., on Saturday.\n\nOn Thursday morning, he issued a series of tweets in support of the preservation of Confederate monuments -- describing them not only as part of U.S. historical but a \"beautiful\" part of U.S. \"culture.\"\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments,\" he wrote. \"You can't change history, but you can learn from it. Robert E Lee, Stonewall Jackson -- who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish! Also ... the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\"\n\nTennessee Sen. Bob Corker, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, ripped Trump at an event in his home state, calling for \"radical\" changes in the White House saying \"he has not demonstrated that {"timeCrawl": "23:35:00", "uri": "711165207", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:35:00Z", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "source": {"title": "KTLA", "uri": "ktla.com", "id": "2653"}, "url": "http://ktla.com/2017/08/17/trump-responds-to-barcelona-attack-by-tweeting-out-debunked-anecdote-on-treatment-of-muslim-pows/", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "President Donald Trump said on Tuesday that before he makes a statement on an important matter he likes to \"know the facts\" and \"be correct.\" On Thursday, he responded to the Barcelona terror attack by spreading a debunked rumor.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught,\" Trump urged his 36.1 million Twitter followers. \"There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nTrump was likely referring to a supposed practice of shooting Muslims with bullets dipped in pig's blood or burying them with the bodies of pigs. For some time, there have been rumors that claim Gen. John J. Pershing employed such tactics following the Philippine-American War in order to deter insurgents.\n\nTrump previously referred to this during a February 2016 rally. In the story Trump told at that time, Pershing's forces captured 50 Muslim prisoners. Pershing then, Trump said, \"took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said, 'You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened.' And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nThere is no evidence to support this claim. Snopes, a website that fact-checks Internet rumors, declared it to be false. Politifact, another fact-checking website, gave it a \"Pants on Fire\" rating.\n\nIn Pershing's memoir, \"My Life Before the World War, 1860-1917,\" he wrote of another commanding officer in the Philippines who had at least once buried Muslims \"in the same grave as a dead pig.\" But as Politifact noted, this anecdote does not support Trump's claim -- either the specific story he told, or the idea that it was effective at deterring future attacks.\n\n\"There is no evidence that Pershing himself committed these acts, there is nothing said about the use of 50 bullets dipped in pig's blood, and most important, there is no evidence to support Trump's claim that this tactic was effective in stopping violence -- or that it would provide a useful policy today,\" Politifact said in its story debunking the claim.\n\nMoreover, the idea that all Muslims believe that if they are shot with pigs' blood they would be sent to hell, the foundation of the supposed tactic, is incorrect. Islam forbids its followers from consuming pork, but \"there is no penalty for coming into contact with pork given by the Quran,\" Shannon Dunn, an assistant professor of religious studies at Gonzaga University, told HuffPost.\n\nA spokesperson for the White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nThursday's attack in Barcelona left at least 13 dead and 80 injured. Authorities have arrested two people. {"timeCrawl": "01:41:00", "uri": "711200306", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T19:14:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"title": "bustle.com", "uri": "bustle.com", "id": "16776"}, "url": "https://www.bustle.com/p/who-is-general-pershing-trump-is-urging-americans-to-study-him-77326", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "In a tweet published Thursday, President Donald Trump urged his followers to study what one U.S. general did to terrorists he caught, referencing a controversial legend that claims the general eradicated terrorism by shooting terrorists with bullets dipped in pigs blood. However, President Trump appears to have gotten his facts about the general in question wrong as there's no proof such an event happened. So, just who is Gen. John Pershing?\n\nIn urging people to \"study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught\" Trump is once again dredging up a widely debunked story about Pershing, the U.S. Army general who commanded the American Expeditionary Force in World War I and also served during the Philippine-American War.\n\nThis isn't the first time Trump has sought to use Pershing to advocate for a harsher response to terrorism. Trump first mentioned the unproven Pershing story while campaigning in South Carolina in February of 2016. At a rally in North Charleston, Trump used the story to advocate for the use of waterboarding, an interrogation technique the Obama administration considered to be torture. He claimed Pershing ordered 49 terrorists to be executed with bullets dipped in pigs blood with the 50th terrorist told to return home and tell his people what happened. \"And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem,\" Trump alleged.\n\nIn a tweet posted Thursday, Trump appeared to inflate his claim, alleging Pershing's actions had wiped out \"radical Islamic terror for 35 years.\"\n\nBut while some historians have noted there are recorded instances where American military members deliberately attempted to offend Filipino Muslims' through the use of pigs during the Philippine-American war, they also emphasized - in comments to Time - that there was no evidence to prove Pershing carried out the event Trump hinted at.\n\nThe myth-busting website Snopes also reported finding \"no references to this alleged incident in Pershing biographies,\" adding such myths did not match up with how Gen. Pershing is \"generally recorded as having dealt with the Moros in 1911.\" The fact-checking website PolitiFact also spoke with multiple historians and came to a similar conclusion last year.\n\n\"[Pershing] did a lot of what we would call 'winning hearts and minds' and embraced reforms which helped end [Moro] resistance,\" Lance Janda, a military historian at Cameron University, told PolitiFact. \"He fought too, but only when he had to, and only against tribes or bands that just wouldn't negotiate with him. He wasn't solely committed to fighting as people like Trump who tell the pig blood story imply.\"\n\nMilitary historian Dr. Frank E. Vandiver also refuted the story in 2003, telling ThoughtCo. he \"never found any indication that it was true in extensive research on [Pershing's] Moro experiences. Vandiver also argued such an incident \"would have run completely against [Pershing's] character.\"\n\nBorn near Laclede, Missouri in 1860, Pershing is one of only two people to have ever been promoted to \"General of the Armies\" for his service in World War I. From 1921 to 1924 Pershing served as U.S. Army Chief of Staff. He retired from the military at age 64 in 1924 and later died in his sleep in 1948. Pershing is buried at Arlington National Cemetery.", "id": "9806000", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Here's What You Need To Know About The General Trump Is Touting On Twitter", {"timeCrawl": "21:27:00", "uri": "711123169", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:27:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"title": "CNBC", "uri": "cnbc.com", "id": "722"}, "url": "https://www.cnbc.com/2017/08/17/trump-promotes-unfounded-story-about-mass-killing-of-terrorists.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "President Donald Trump on Thursday promoted a graphic, unfounded story about the mass killing of suspected terrorists in the early 20th century.\n\nFollowing a suspected terror attack in Barcelona, Trump tweeted: \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nTrump: Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\n\nThe president shared the purported story as a candidate in February 2016, as he brought up his support for waterboarding, according to The Washington Post. The tale, often characterized as a myth, has made rounds on the internet but historians do not see real evidence to back it, according to PolitiFact.\n\nTrump pushed the Pershing tale during a week in which he faced stark criticism from bipartisan lawmakers and business leaders for his response to an attack at a white nationalist rally in Virginia over the weekend. Trump appeared to suggest a moral equivalency between people marching in the white nationalist rally and other protesting against them.\n\nWhen Trump last year told the story about Gen. John Pershing, he said it took place in the early 1900s but did not specify a location, according to the Post. Pershing served as governor of a largely Muslim province in the Philippines from 1909-1913 as the United States tried to establish control of the area, PolitiFact said.\n\nHere's how Trump told the tale last year, according to the Post:\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do. And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pigs' blood -- you heard that, right? He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened. And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nAside from the story's questionable accuracy, it would be an extrajudicial, religiously charged mass killing.\n\nThe Council on American-Islamic Relations denounced the tale when Trump first told it.\n\n\"By directly stating that the only way to stop terrorism is to murder Muslims in graphic and religiously-offensive ways, he places the millions of innocent, law-abiding citizens in the American Muslim community at risk from rogue vigilantes,\" Nihad Awad, national executive director of CAIR, said in a February 2016 statement.\n\nThe tweet Thursday likely will not make life any easier for Trump during a week in which he has faced backlash for his response to racially charged violence.", "id": "9780122", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "22:01:00", "uri": "711134856", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:01:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"title": "erienewsnow.com", "uri": "erienewsnow.com", "id": "2128"}, "url": "http://www.erienewsnow.com/story/36161022/trump-responds-to-barcelona-terror-attack-by-spreading-debunked-rumor", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "NEW YORK (CNNMoney) -- President Donald Trump said on Tuesday that before he makes a statement on an important matter he likes to \"know the facts\" and \"be correct.\" On Thursday, he responded to the Barcelona terror attack by spreading a debunked rumor.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught,\" Trump urged his 36.1 million Twitter followers. \"There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nTrump was likely referring to a supposed practice of shooting Muslims with bullets dipped in pig's blood or burying them with the bodies of pigs. For some time, there have been rumors that claim Gen. John J. Pershing employed such tactics following the Philippine-American War in order to deter insurgents.\n\nTrump previously referred to this during a February 2016 rally. In the story Trump told at that time, Pershing's forces captured 50 Muslim prisoners. Pershing then, Trump said, \"took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said, 'You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened.' And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nThere is no evidence to support this claim. Snopes, a website that fact-checks Internet rumors, declared it to be false. Politifact, another fact-checking website, gave it a \"Pants on Fire\" rating.\n\nIn Pershing's memoir, \"My Life Before the World War, 1860-1917,\" he wrote of another commanding officer in the Philippines who had at least once buried Muslims \"in the same grave as a dead pig.\" But as Politifact noted, this anecdote does not support Trump's claim -- either the specific story he told, or the idea that it was effective at deterring future attacks.\n\n\"There is no evidence that Pershing himself committed these acts, there is nothing said about the use of 50 bullets dipped in pig's blood, and most important, there is no evidence to support Trump's claim that this tactic was effective in stopping violence -- or that it would provide a useful policy today,\" Politifact said in its story debunking the claim.\n\nMoreover, the idea that all Muslims believe that if they are shot with pigs' blood they would be sent to hell, the foundation of the supposed tactic, is incorrect. Islam forbids its followers from consuming pork, but \"there is no penalty for coming into contact with pork given by the Quran,\" Shannon Dunn, an assistant professor of religious studies at Gonzaga University, told HuffPost.\n\nA spokesperson for the White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nThursday's attack in Barcelona left at least 13 dead and 80 injured. Authorities have arrested two people. ISIS' media wing, Amaq, issued a statement through social media calling the perpetrators of the attack \"soldiers of the Islamic State.\"\n\nTM & \u00a9 2017 Cable News Network, Inc., a Time Warner Company. {"timeCrawl": "01:41:00", "uri": "711200201", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:14:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"title": "San Francisco Gate", "uri": "sfgate.com", "id": "530"}, "url": "http://www.sfgate.com/news/politics/article/AP-EXPLAINS-Trump-Pershing-and-terrorism-a-11882219.php", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Donald Trump is being criticized once again for lauding the alleged tactics of Gen. John Pershing in dealing with Islamic extremists in the Philippines at the turn of the last century.\n\nTrump tweeted on Thursday that people should \"study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nWhat is behind the tweet and the criticism? The AP explains:\n\nPERSHING AND THE PHILIPPINES\n\nGen. John \"Black Jack\" Pershing, who would rise to fame in World War I, was a U.S. Army commander and served as governor of the southern Philippines' mainly Muslim Moro province between 1909 and 1913. His tenure came as the U.S. was consolidating its control over the Philippines, which it had won as a result of the Spanish-American War. Pershing was confronted with a Moro insurgency, which he largely broke in June 1913 in a battle that killed some 500 Moro fighters.\n\nTRUMP AND TACTICS AGAINST TERRORISM\n\nIt's unclear. Trump did not cite any specific tactic employed by Pershing in his tweet on Thursday. But during the presidential campaign, he told a widely discredited story that Pershing had halted Muslim attacks in the Philippines by shooting rebels with bullets dipped in pigs' blood. Pork is taboo for Muslims, but that story has been widely debunked by historians as unsubstantiated or exaggerated. Fact-checking organizations such as Politifact rated Trump's claim as false.\n\nHowever, according to Politifact, Pershing wrote in a memoir that another U.S. commander in the Philippines had at least once \"seen to it\" that Muslim insurgents' bodies were buried in the same grave as a dead pig to serve as a warning to others. \"It was not pleasant to have to take such measures, but the prospect of going to hell instead of heaven sometimes deterred the would-be assassins,\" Pershing wrote. According to Politifact, a footnote to the 2013 edition of the memoir cited another general as telling Pershing in a letter that the practice had long been a custom \"to discourage crazy lunatics.\"\n\nTRUMP TWEETS A DEBUNKED STORY\n\nMany critical commentators believe Trump's tweet revived the specific story about Pershing and the bullets dipped in pigs' blood that he told during the campaign. But because Trump was not specific about the tactics he was referring to, it is not possible to tell with certainty. He could also have been referring to the burials cited in Pershing's memoirs. In either case, Trump's claim that Pershing's treatment of captured militants was the prime reason for the end of the insurgency is not supported by historical fact.", "id": "9805967", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "AP Explains: Why is Trump tweeting about a WWI general?", "image": "http://ww4.hdnux.com/photos/64/55/64/13819183/3/rawImage.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "concepts": [{"location": {"label": {"eng": "Philippines"}, "type": "country"}, "score": 5, "id": "177", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philippines", "label": {"eng": {"timeCrawl": "08:58:00", "uri": "711344843", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T07:28:00Z", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "source": {"title": "Washington Post", "uri": "washingtonpost.com", "id": "104"}, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/ap-explains-why-does-a-wwi-general-merit-a-trump-tweet/2017/08/18/8a87d944-83e5-11e7-9e7a-20fa8d7a0db6_story.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "WASHINGTON -- President Donald Trump is being criticized once again for lauding the alleged tactics of Gen. John Pershing in dealing with Islamic extremists in the Philippines at the turn of the last century.\n\nTrump tweeted on Thursday that people should \"study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nWhat is behind the tweet and the criticism? The AP explains:\n\nPERSHING AND THE PHILIPPINES\n\nGen. John \"Black Jack\" Pershing, who would rise to fame in World War I, was a U.S. Army commander and served as governor of the southern Philippines' mainly Muslim Moro province between 1909 and 1913. His tenure came as the U.S. was consolidating its control over the Philippines, which it had won as a result of the Spanish-American War. Pershing was confronted with a Moro insurgency, which he largely broke in June 1913 in a battle that killed some 500 Moro fighters.\n\nTRUMP AND TACTICS AGAINST TERRORISM\n\nIt's unclear. Trump did not cite any specific tactic employed by Pershing in his tweet on Thursday. But during the presidential campaign, he told a widely discredited story that Pershing had halted Muslim attacks in the Philippines by shooting rebels with bullets dipped in pigs' blood. Pork is taboo for Muslims, but that story has been widely debunked by historians as unsubstantiated or exaggerated. Fact-checking organizations such as Politifact rated Trump's claim as false.\n\nHowever, according to Politifact, Pershing wrote in a memoir that another U.S. commander in the Philippines had at least once \"seen to it\" that Muslim insurgents' bodies were buried in the same grave as a dead pig to serve as a warning to others. \"It was not pleasant to have to take such measures, but the prospect of going to hell instead of heaven sometimes deterred the would-be assassins,\" Pershing wrote. According to Politifact, a footnote to the 2013 edition of the memoir cited another general as telling Pershing in a letter that the practice had long been a custom \"to discourage crazy lunatics.\"\n\nTRUMP TWEETS A DEBUNKED STORY\n\nMany critical commentators believe Trump's tweet revived the specific story about Pershing and the bullets dipped in pigs' blood that he told during the campaign. But because Trump was not specific about the tactics he was referring to, it is not possible to tell with certainty. He could also have been referring to the burials cited in Pershing's memoirs. In either case, Trump's claim that Pershing's treatment of captured militants was the prime reason for the end of the insurgency is not supported by historical fact.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nWhile many scratched their heads over the oblique reference to US military history, Trump has told his story of General Pershing before.\n\nAnd it's definitely fake.\n\nHere's what he meant with this tweet Video Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8Cancel Play now\n\nSpeaking at a February 2016 campaign rally in South Carolina, he told a story about Pershing executing Muslim prisoners in the Philippine-American war, in which he served between 1909 and 1913.\n\nAs Governor of Moro province in the Philippines, Pershing had to contend with local Muslims who resisted the American occupying force.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Trump said. \"And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pigs' blood -- you heard that, right? He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood.\n\n\"And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened. And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nHe also told the crowd they could read about the story in the history books, \"but not a lot of the history books, because they don't like to teach it.\"\n\nIt didn't happen.\n\nWhere did the story come from?\n\nHistorians have noted newspaper articles from decades after the supposed event, which told a story of Pershing sprinkling pig blood on bullets to threaten prisoners with \"eternal damnation\", but even these accounts say there was no actual massacre, and prisoners were released.\n\nOther articles attributed the tale to other people, not Pershing.\n\nIn fact, according to historian William Lambers : \"Pershing was more inclined toward peace talks with the Moros rather than violence. The General met with the Moros and read from the Koran with them. Pershing wanted to build bridges.\"\n\nFact-checking website Politifact asked eight historians about the story, and reported: \"Most expressed skepticism that the specific story ever happened, and many added that Trump's takeaway is wrong-headed.\"\n\nThe story has, however, been circulated widely online in the years since 9/11.\n\nWow.\n\nYeah.\n\nOn Tuesday, Donald Trump excused himself from {"timeCrawl": "05:50:00", "uri": "711270652", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T18:58:00Z", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "source": {"title": "3TV, azfamily.com", "uri": "azfamily.com", "id": "10205"}, "url": "http://www.azfamily.com/story/36161057/trump-responds-to-barcelona-terror-attack-by-spreading-debunked-rumor", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "(CNN Money) -- President Donald Trump said on Thursday that before he makes a statement on an important matter he likes to \"know the facts\" and \"be correct.\" On Thursday, he responded to the Barcelona terror attack by spreading a debunked rumor.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught,\" Trump urged his 36.1 million Twitter followers. \"There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nTrump was likely referring to a supposed practice of shooting Muslims with bullets dipped in pig's blood or burying them with the bodies of pigs. For some time, there have been rumors that claim Gen. John J. Pershing employed such tactics following the Philippine-American War in order to deter insurgents.\n\nTrump previously referred to this during a February 2016 rally. In the story Trump told at that time, Pershing's forces captured 50 Muslim prisoners. Pershing then, Trump said, \"took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said, 'You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened.' And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nClick here to for the latest on Barcelona.\n\nThere is no evidence to support this claim. Snopes, a website that fact-checks Internet rumors, declared it to be false. Politifact, another fact-checking website, gave it a \"Pants on Fire\" rating.\n\nIn Pershing's memoir, \"My Life Before the World War, 1860-1917,\" he wrote of another commanding officer in the Philippines who had at least once buried Muslims \"in the same grave as a dead pig.\" But as Politifact noted, this anecdote does not support Trump's claim -- either the specific story he told, or the idea that it was effective at deterring future attacks.\n\n\"There is no evidence that Pershing himself committed these acts, there is nothing said about the use of 50 bullets dipped in pig's blood, and most important, there is no evidence to support Trump's claim that this tactic was effective in stopping violence -- or that it would provide a useful policy today,\" Politifact said in its story debunking the claim.\n\nMoreover, the idea that all Muslims believe that if they are shot with pigs' blood they would be sent to hell, the foundation of the supposed tactic, is incorrect. Islam forbids its followers from consuming pork, but \"there is no penalty for coming into contact with pork given by the Quran,\" Shannon Dunn, an assistant professor of religious studies at Gonzaga University, told HuffPost.\n\nA spokesperson for the White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nThursday's attack in Barcelona left at least 13 dead and 80 injured. Authorities have arrested two people. Well, he has referenced the legend of General \"Black Jack\" Pershing before - at a rally in South Carolina last year while Trump was on his campaign trail.\n\nAccording to Trump back then, Pershing had managed to halt Muslim attacks in the Philippines where he was based by shooting Islamic militants with bullets dipped in pig's blood - pork being a taboo in Muslim culture.\n\n\"He caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people,\" said Trump at the rally. \"They shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened.\"\n\nTrump claimed \"for 25 years there wasn't a problem\" - a number he has seemingly increased to 35 in his tweet.\n\nTrump's story was widely discredited and debunked, with fact-checking organisation Politifact rating the claims about Pershing as false. However, they note the general did write in a memoir that he saw other commanding officers publicly burying Muslim insurgents in the same grave as a dead pig.\n\n\"It was not pleasant to have to take such measures, but the prospect of going to hell instead of heaven sometimes deterred the would-be assassins,\" wrote Pershing.\n\nLacking more specifics, it is not certain Trump is referring to the {"timeCrawl": "07:41:00", "uri": "711315159", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T07:41:00Z", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "source": {"title": "Federal News Radio", "uri": "federalnewsradio.com", "id": "9518"}, "url": "https://federalnewsradio.com/government-news/2017/08/ap-explains-why-does-a-wwi-general-merit-a-trump-tweet/", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Donald Trump is being criticized once again for lauding the alleged tactics of Gen. John Pershing in dealing with Islamic extremists in the Philippines at the turn of the last century.\n\nTrump tweeted on Thursday that people should \"study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nWhat is behind the tweet and the criticism? The AP explains:\n\nPERSHING AND THE PHILIPPINES\n\nSponsored Content: How is your agency managing and maximizing its data? Share your opinions in a Federal News Radio survey.\n\nGen. John \"Black Jack\" Pershing, who would rise to fame in World War I, was a U.S. Army commander and served as governor of the southern Philippines' mainly Muslim Moro province between 1909 and 1913. His tenure came as the U.S. was consolidating its control over the Philippines, which it had won as a result of the Spanish-American War. Pershing was confronted with a Moro insurgency, which he largely broke in June 1913 in a battle that killed some 500 Moro fighters.\n\nTRUMP AND TACTICS AGAINST TERRORISM\n\nIt's unclear. Trump did not cite any specific tactic employed by Pershing in his tweet on Thursday. But during the presidential campaign, he told a widely discredited story that Pershing had halted Muslim attacks in the Philippines by shooting rebels with bullets dipped in pigs' blood. Pork is taboo for Muslims, but that story has been widely debunked by historians as unsubstantiated or exaggerated. Fact-checking organizations such as Politifact rated Trump's claim as false.\n\nHowever, according to Politifact, Pershing wrote in a memoir that another U.S. commander in the Philippines had at least once \"seen to it\" that Muslim insurgents' bodies were buried in the same grave as a dead pig to serve as a warning to others. \"It was not pleasant to have to take such measures, but the prospect of going to hell instead of heaven sometimes deterred the would-be assassins,\" Pershing wrote. According to Politifact, a footnote to the 2013 edition of the memoir cited another general as telling Pershing in a letter that the practice had long been a custom \"to discourage crazy lunatics.\"\n\nTRUMP TWEETS A DEBUNKED STORY\n\nMany critical commentators believe Trump's tweet revived the specific story about Pershing and the bullets dipped in pigs' blood that he told during the campaign. But because Trump was not specific about the tactics he was referring to, it is not possible to tell with certainty. He could also have been referring to the burials cited in Pershing's memoirs. In either case, Trump's claim that Pershing's treatment of captured militants was the prime reason for the end of the insurgency is not supported by historical fact.", "id": "9844543", "details": {}, {"timeCrawl": "22:55:00", "uri": "711152721", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:11:00Z", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "source": {"title": "Philly.com", "uri": "philly.com", "id": "314"}, "url": "http://www.philly.com/philly/news/politics/presidential/20170817_ap_db60451f01704628b0d1396a05511681.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - President Donald Trump is being criticized once again for lauding the alleged tactics of Gen. John Pershing in dealing with Islamic extremists in the Philippines at the turn of the last century.\n\nTrump tweeted on Thursday that people should \"study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nWhat is behind the tweet and the criticism? The AP explains:\n\nPERSHING AND THE PHILIPPINES\n\nGen. John \"Black Jack\" Pershing, who would rise to fame in World War I, was a U.S. Army commander and served as governor of the southern Philippines' mainly Muslim Moro province between 1909 and 1913. His tenure came as the U.S. was consolidating its control over the Philippines, which it had won as a result of the Spanish-American War. Pershing was confronted with a Moro insurgency, which he largely broke in June 1913 in a battle that killed some 500 Moro fighters.\n\nTRUMP AND TACTICS AGAINST TERRORISM\n\nIt's unclear. Trump did not cite any specific tactic employed by Pershing in his tweet on Thursday. But during the presidential campaign, he told a widely discredited story that Pershing had halted Muslim attacks in the Philippines by shooting rebels with bullets dipped in pigs' blood. Pork is taboo for Muslims, but that story has been widely debunked by historians as unsubstantiated or exaggerated. Fact-checking organizations such as Politifact rated Trump's claim as false.\n\nHowever, according to Politifact, Pershing wrote in a memoir that another U.S. commander in the Philippines had at least once \"seen to it\" that Muslim insurgents' bodies were buried in the same grave as a dead pig to serve as a warning to others. \"It was not pleasant to have to take such measures, but the prospect of going to hell instead of heaven sometimes deterred the would-be assassins,\" Pershing wrote. According to Politifact, a footnote to the 2013 edition of the memoir cited another general as telling Pershing in a letter that the practice had long been a custom \"to discourage crazy lunatics.\"\n\nTRUMP TWEETS A DEBUNKED STORY\n\nMany critical commentators believe Trump's tweet revived the specific story about Pershing and the bullets dipped in pigs' blood that he told during the campaign. But because Trump was not specific about the tactics he was referring to, it is not possible to tell with certainty. He could also have been referring to the burials cited in Pershing's memoirs. In either case, Trump's claim that Pershing's treatment of captured militants was the prime reason for the end of the insurgency is not supported by historical fact.\n\nPublished: August 17, 2017 \u00e2\u0080\" 3:01 AM EDT | Updated: August 17, 2017 \u00e2\u0080\" 4:43 PM EDT\n\nThanks for your continued support...\n\nWe recently asked you to support our journalism. The response, in a word, is heartening. You have encouraged us in our mission -- to provide quality news and watchdog journalism. Some of you have even followed through with subscriptions, which is especially gratifying. Our role as an independent, fact-based news organization has never been clearer. And our promise to you is that we will always strive to provide indispensable journalism to our community. The inflammatory tweet came just hours after a van plowed through a crowd of people in a popular tourist area in Spain, leaving at least 12 people killed and more than 80 injured.\n\nTrump suggested in the tweet that people should study the early 20th century general, John Pershing, and his actions during the US war in the Philippines.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught,\" Trump tweeted. \"There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nThe president seemed to be referring to a widely debunked myth that Pershing used bullets dipped in pig's blood to kill groups of Muslim insurgents. Another part of the tale is that he buried their bodies with pigs as well. In the Islamic faith, pigs are considered ritually unclean.\n\nThe story, which has been making the rounds online for years, has been widely discredited by historians.\n\nAccording to PolitiFact, \"there is no evidence that Pershing himself committed these acts, there is nothing said about the use of 50 bullets dipped in pig's blood, and most important, there is no evidence to support Trump's claim that this tactic was effective in stopping violence -- or that it would provide a useful policy today.\"\n\nTrump's claim has also been given a \"pants on fire\" rating by Politifact -- one that is given to the \"most ridiculous falsehoods.\"\n\nTrump has previously referred to Pershing during the election campaign in 2016 as well. Last year, his former campaign manager Corey Lewandowski revealed that Trump knew the story was a myth, but decided to tell it at rallies.\n\nThe president's controversial tweet comes amid fierce criticism over his response to the deadly violence at a white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nHe was referring to General John \"Black Jack\" Pershing who was the US governor of largely Muslim Moro province from 1909 to 1913.\n\nAt the time, the Philippines was a US colony. And Pershing's forces had to fight Muslim counterinsurgencies.\n\nThe debunked account -- which Trump has referred to in the past -- is as follows: Pershing's forces rounded up 50 Muslim insurgents and executed 49 of them with bullets dipped in pig's blood -- considered by Muslims to be unholy.\n\n\"You heard that, right?\" Trump said as a candidate during a rally in February 2016 in South Carolina, alluding to the pig blood part.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Trump said.\n\nAs the story goes, the 50th prisoner was released to tell his fellow fighters about what the Americans had done.\n\n\"And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Bush administration in its war on terror and halted by Barack Obama -- during the presidential campaign.\n\nOnce in office, however, after US generals advised him against reverting to waterboarding, The rebellion was an armed conflict between Muslims and the United States military.\n\nDuring the 2016 election campaign, Trump frequently told a tale of how Pershing had Moro Muslim prisoners in the Philippines executed with bullets soaked in pig's blood to quell rebellion against American rule.\n\nSpeaking at a rally in Charleston February last year, Trump said General Pershing \"took 50 bullets and he dipped them in pig's blood.\"\n\n\"And he had his men load his rifles and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said, 'You go back to your people and you tell them what happened.' And for 25 years there wasn't a problem,\" he said.\n\nAccording to some historians, Trump's tale is false. They have concluded it would have been \"out of character\" for Pershing.\n\nBut some other historians have suggested that American troops did use pigs or pig's blood to intimidate Muslims during the Philippine conflict in the early 20th century.\n\n\"So yes, there were deliberate efforts to offend Muslim Filipinos' religious sensibilities,\" Christopher Capozzola, a history professor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, told TIME last year.\n\n\"And yes, there was large-scale violence against their communities. But I know of no event like the one that Mr. Trump describes,\" he stated.\n\nMuslim advocacy groups have challenged Trump to debate a representative from the American-Muslim community \"on the issues\" he has \"raised about Islam and Muslims.\"\n\nEarlier in the day, Trump condemned the attack in Barcelona. John Pershing in battling Islamic terrorists following the Barcelona attack that killed 13 people and injured as many as 50.\n\nHere's the president's post:\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nTrump's post came after a terrorist attack in Barcelona in which a white van plowed a crowd in the central tourist area -- and authorities said they had arrested two suspects.\n\nPresident Trump has often used the Pershing anecdote to discuss ways to battle Islamic jihadism, saying that the four-star commander executed Muslim insurgents with bullets dipped in pig's blood during the Philippine-American War from 1899 to 1902.\n\n\"He took 50 bullets and dipped them in pig's blood,\" Trump told a rally just before the South Carolina primary in February 2016, Mother Jones reports.\n\nEating pork is a sin for Muslims. Pig's blood is considered unholy.\n\n\"And he has his men load up their rifles and he lined up the 50 people and they shot 49 of those people,\" Trump said. \"And the 50th person, he said, you go back to your people and you tell them what happened.\n\n\"And for 25 years there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nHowever, the Pershing story has been debunked by historians and by Snopes, the myth-busting website.\n\nOne historian, Brian McAllister Linn, a professor at Texas A&M University, told Time magazine in February 2016 that he and a co-author of a Pershing biography found no evidence of the story.\n\n\"We both checked our notes and found no evidence to support this,\" Linn said. His colleague, Frank Vandiver, died in 2005.\n\n\"We also concluded it was out of character,\" Linn said.\n\nSnopes.com also reached the same conclusion, in 2001.\n\n\"We haven't yet found any references to this alleged incident in Pershing biographies, however, nor does it match the way Pershing is generally recorded as having dealt with the Moros in 1911,\" the site concluded, the site {"timeCrawl": "07:27:00", "uri": "711310005", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T07:27:00Z", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4801788/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - President Donald Trump is being criticized once again for lauding the alleged tactics of Gen. John Pershing in dealing with Islamic extremists in the Philippines at the turn of the last century.\n\nTrump tweeted on Thursday that people should \"study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nWhat is behind the tweet and the criticism? The AP explains:\n\nFILE - In this Nov. 11, 1942, file photo, U.S. Gen. John J. Pershing appears in uniform at Armistice Day ceremonies at Arlington Cemetery in Arlington, Va. President Donald Trump is being criticized for lauding the alleged tactics of Gen. John Pershing in dealing with Islamic extremists in the Philippines. (AP Photo)\n\nPERSHING AND THE PHILIPPINES\n\nGen. John \"Black Jack\" Pershing, who would rise to fame in World War I, was a U.S. Army commander and served as governor of the southern Philippines' mainly Muslim Moro province between 1909 and 1913. His tenure came as the U.S. was consolidating its control over the Philippines, which it had won as a result of the Spanish-American War. Pershing was confronted with a Moro insurgency, which he largely broke in June 1913 in a battle that killed some 500 Moro fighters.\n\nTRUMP AND TACTICS AGAINST TERRORISM\n\nIt's unclear. Trump did not cite any specific tactic employed by Pershing in his tweet on Thursday. But during the presidential campaign, he told a widely discredited story that Pershing had halted Muslim attacks in the Philippines by shooting rebels with bullets dipped in pigs' blood. Pork is taboo for Muslims, but that story has been widely debunked by historians as unsubstantiated or exaggerated. Fact-checking organizations such as Politifact rated Trump's claim as false.\n\nHowever, according to Politifact, Pershing wrote in a memoir that another U.S. commander in the Philippines had at least once \"seen to it\" that Muslim insurgents' bodies were buried in the same grave as a dead pig to serve as a warning to others. \"It was not pleasant to have to take such measures, but the prospect of going to hell instead of heaven sometimes deterred the would-be assassins,\" Pershing wrote. According to Politifact, a footnote to the 2013 edition of the memoir cited another general as telling Pershing in a letter that the practice had long been a custom \"to discourage crazy lunatics.\"\n\nTRUMP TWEETS A DEBUNKED STORY\n\nMany critical commentators believe Trump's tweet revived the specific story about Pershing and the bullets dipped in pigs' blood that he told during the campaign. But because Trump was not specific about the tactics he was referring to, it is not possible to tell with certainty. He could also have been referring to the burials cited in Pershing's memoirs. In either case, Trump's claim that Pershing's treatment of captured militants was the prime reason for the end of the insurgency is not supported by historical fact.", "id": "9842482", "details": {}, {"timeCrawl": "21:48:00", "uri": "711130391", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:48:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"title": "Federal News Radio", "uri": "federalnewsradio.com", "id": "9518"}, "url": "https://federalnewsradio.com/government-news/2017/08/ap-explains-trump-pershing-and-terrorism-a-primer/", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Donald Trump is being criticized once again for lauding the alleged tactics of Gen. John Pershing in dealing with Islamic extremists in the Philippines at the turn of the last century.\n\nTrump tweeted on Thursday that people should \"study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nWhat is behind the tweet and the criticism? The AP explains:\n\nPERSHING AND THE PHILIPPINES\n\nSponsored Content: Sign up for a free webinar as DoD, Air Force and VA offer insights on cybersecurity strategies.\n\nGen. John \"Black Jack\" Pershing, who would rise to fame in World War I, was a U.S. Army commander and served as governor of the southern Philippines' mainly Muslim Moro province between 1909 and 1913. His tenure came as the U.S. was consolidating its control over the Philippines, which it had won as a result of the Spanish-American War. Pershing was confronted with a Moro insurgency, which he largely broke in June 1913 in a battle that killed some 500 Moro fighters.\n\nTRUMP AND TACTICS AGAINST TERRORISM\n\nIt's unclear. Trump did not cite any specific tactic employed by Pershing in his tweet on Thursday. But during the presidential campaign, he told a widely discredited story that Pershing had halted Muslim attacks in the Philippines by shooting rebels with bullets dipped in pigs' blood. Pork is taboo for Muslims, but that story has been widely debunked by historians as unsubstantiated or exaggerated. Fact-checking organizations such as Politifact rated Trump's claim as false.\n\nHowever, according to Politifact, Pershing wrote in a memoir that another U.S. commander in the Philippines had at least once \"seen to it\" that Muslim insurgents' bodies were buried in the same grave as a dead pig to serve as a warning to others. \"It was not pleasant to have to take such measures, but the prospect of going to hell instead of heaven sometimes deterred the would-be assassins,\" Pershing wrote. According to Politifact, a footnote to the 2013 edition of the memoir cited another general as telling Pershing in a letter that the practice had long been a custom \"to discourage crazy lunatics.\"\n\nTRUMP TWEETS A DEBUNKED STORY\n\nMany critical commentators believe Trump's tweet revived the specific story about Pershing and the bullets dipped in pigs' blood that he told during the campaign. But because Trump was not specific about the tactics he was referring to, it is not possible to tell with certainty. He could also have been referring to the burials cited in Pershing's memoirs. In either case, Trump's claim that Pershing's treatment of captured militants was the prime reason for the end of the insurgency is not supported by historical fact.", "id": "9782858", "details": {}, John J. Pershing dipped bullets in pig blood before putting down a group of Muslim terrorists while fighting in the Philippines. Another legend says that he buried the terrorist with pigs, leaving only one terrorist alive to tell his comrades.\n\nA pig is an unclean animal in the Muslim faith, and killing or burying someone with pig blood would be seen as a horrific insult and perhaps even preventing access to Heaven, Time reported in 2016.\n\nHowever glorified the stories are, there is little to no evidence that these claims did indeed happen. Some accounts attribute them to another officer someone serving under Pershing's command. Other fact-check sites have declared the claims flatly \"false.\"\n\nHowever, this is not the first time Trump has cited the story. According to the History News Network, Trump referenced it in an early 2016 campaign stop in Charleston, South Carolina:\n\nDuring a campaign rally on Friday night in South Carolina, Trump told his audience a story about General John Pershing executing Muslim prisoners in the Philippines. Trump said Pershing, in the early 1900's, \"caught 50 terrorists that did tremendous damage and killed many people and he took the 50 terrorists and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pig's blood.\"\n\nTrump went out to describe a mass execution shooting of 49 of the prisoners, with the last one being sent to tell the others what happened. It was Trump using this \"story\" to demonstrate that America needed to get tough on terrorism, using brutal methods, and that he would be the man to do it.\n\nBut the story is not true. There was no mass execution led by Pershing. John Pershing halting Muslim attacks in the Philippines by shooting rebels with bullets dipped in pigs' blood.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught,\" Trump wrote on his personal account. \"There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years.\"\n\nAnti-Hate Groups Seize Charlottesville as Teachable Moment\n\nIt was at least Trump's second reference to a story already labeled false last year, this time coming days after the president justified his equivocal response in assigning blame for violence in Charlottesville by saying that before he makes a statement, \"I need the facts.\"\n\nThe Pershing story, which Trump also recounted at the end of a rally in South Carolina in February 2016, has been debunked by several fact-checking organizations, including Politifact and Snopes. Politfact labeled it Pants on Fire! false on its Truth-O-Meter and Snopes called it \"false.\"\n\nMore GOP Fallout After Trump Decries Monument Removals\n\nThe story -- which according to Trump's telling had Pershing shooting 50 Muslim terrorists with 50 bullets dipped in pigs blood -- grew out of the Philippine-American War of 1899-1902. The United States had obtained the islands from Spain but faced armed opposition that continued after the war, when Pershing served as governor of the heavily Muslim Moro Province. Politifact found references to Muslim insurgents being buried with dead pigs but not being killed with bloodied bullets and not by Pershing.\n\nMuslims are prohibited from eating pork.\n\nExclusiveBen Carson Talks About Vandalism of Home, Charlottesville\n\n\"This story is a fabrication and has long been discredited,\" Brian McAllister Linn, a Texas A&M University historian and author of Guardians of Empire: The U.S. Army and the Pacific, 1902-1940, told Politifact. \"I am amazed it is still making the rounds.\"\n\nEven if the tale were true, Politifact wrote, it had no pacifying effect. The region remains in unrest until today.\n\nWhite House Reacts to Steve Bannon Comments\n\nSnopes noted that Pershing thought the best approach was not to encourage religious fanaticism.\n\n\"Nonetheless, the 'discouraging Muslim terrorists by burying them with pigs' concept is still invoked in the modern era, even if the evidence of its use (or success) remains nebulous,\" Snopes wrote.\n\nScholars Say Trump Went Afoul in Lumping Lee With Founders\n\nTrump's tweet Thursday came after Catalan officials had confirmed a terrorist attack but were still trying to identify the suspect they arrested.\n\nThat was in stark contrast to Trump's actions in the hours and days after an alleged white nationalist, James Allen Fields Jr., was accused of driving a car through a crowd in Charlottesville, North Carolina, over the weekend, killing counter-protester Heather Heyer.\n\nUpdatedAG Praises Miami for Ending 'Sanctuary City' Policy\n\nTrump defended his delayed response in calling out white supremacists by name until two days after the attack by saying he didn't \"know all the facts.\"\n\n\"I think there is blame on both sides,\" Trump went on to say this week, doubling down on his initial take that \"many sides\" were to blame for violence in Charlottesville.\n\nAs Trump CEO Panels Disband and Crumble, He Ends Both\n\nHis Pershing tweet Thursday followed an earlier, more restrained one, expressing sympathy for the people of Barcelona.\n\n\"The United States condemns the terror attack in Barcelona, Spain, and will do whatever is necessary to
