{"timeCrawl": "20:45:00", "uri": "711106701", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:45:00Z", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "source": {"title": "CNN Money", "uri": "money.cnn.com", "id": "50"}, "url": "http://money.cnn.com/2017/08/17/media/general-pershing-president-trump-pigs-blood-debunked/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught,\" Trump urged his 36.1 million Twitter followers. \"There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nTrump was likely referring to a supposed practice of shooting Muslims with bullets dipped in pig's blood or burying them with the bodies of pigs. For some time, there have been rumors that claim Gen. John J. Pershing employed such tactics following the Philippine-American War in order to deter insurgents.\n\nTrump previously referred to this during a February 2016 rally. In the story Trump told at that time, Pershing's forces captured 50 Muslim prisoners. Pershing then, Trump said, \"took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said, 'You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened.' And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nThere is no evidence to support this claim. Snopes, a website that fact-checks Internet rumors, declared it to be false. Politifact, another fact-checking website, gave it a \"Pants on Fire\" rating.\n\nIn Pershing's memoir, \"My Life Before the World War, 1860-1917,\" he wrote of another commanding officer in the Philippines who had at least once buried Muslims \"in the same grave as a dead pig.\" But as Politifact noted, this anecdote does not support Trump's claim -- either the specific story he told, or the idea that it was effective at deterring future attacks.\n\n\"There is no evidence that Pershing himself committed these acts, there is nothing said about the use of 50 bullets dipped in pig's blood, and most important, there is no evidence to support Trump's claim that this tactic was effective in stopping violence -- or that it would provide a useful policy today,\" Politifact said in its story debunking the claim.\n\nMoreover, the idea that all Muslims believe that if they are shot with pigs' blood they would be sent to hell, the foundation of the supposed tactic, is incorrect. Islam forbids its followers from consuming pork, but \"there is no penalty for coming into contact with pork given by the Quran,\" Shannon Dunn, an assistant professor of religious studies at Gonzaga University, told HuffPost.\n\nA spokesperson for the White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nThursday's attack in Barcelona left at least 13 dead and 80 injured. Authorities have arrested two people. {"timeCrawl": "05:50:00", "uri": "711270701", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T19:58:00Z", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "source": {"title": "Elite Daily", "uri": "elitedaily.com", "id": "9547"}, "url": "http://elitedaily.com/news/trumps-tweet-general-pershing-not-alarming-cant-proved/2047896/", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "Trump's Tweet About General Pershing Is Not Only Alarming, It Can't Be Proved\n\nAlthough we may currently be forced to bear witness to each rant and tweet Trump produces as president -- and watch as there are little consequences for him -- we can still fact check him. And that is precisely why he won't stop calling the news fake: He crumbles when he's called out. Today, not even a week after his failure to condemn neo-Nazi extremism, Trump posted an aggressive tweet citing an act allegedly carried out by an American general, which allegedly stopped Islamic extremist terrorism for 25 years. This tweet not only left many people disgusted, as it seems to encourage violence, but also left a lot of people with one burning question: Who is General Pershing?\n\nTrump's fixation on General John Pershing began during his candidacy, at a rally in South Carolina. He begins talking about Pershing to the crowd -- but not before almost shockingly coaxing them, as if he's the host of a daytime game show. He calls, \"Should I tell you? Or should I not?\" And the crowd responds with cheers.\n\nTrump admits early on in the speech that his story isn't exactly cited. He tells the crowd, \"This is something you can read in the history books. Not a lot of history books, because they don't like teaching it.\" Then he tells the story of General Pershing, who according to Trump, once rounded up 50 terrorists, and shot them all -- except one -- with bullets dipped in pig's blood. Instead of killing the last terrorist, he told him to go back to where he was from and explain what he had just witnessed, and that because of that, there was no terrorism in the country for 25 years.\n\nTrump's story is met with audible applause from the crowd, along with a final warning from Trump. \"So we better start getting tough and we better start getting vigilant and using our heads,\" he said. \"Or we're not going to have a country, folks.\"\n\nSo, Who Is General Pershing?\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\nTrump brought up General Pershing again today, when he tweeted,\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United states did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\n\nGeneral Pershing was, in fact, a real American general who was a senior Army officer, according to Wikipedia. He served as the commander of the American Expeditionary Force on the Western Front during WWI from 1917-1918. And also fought in Spanish-American war, particularly, in the Philippines, where this pig's blood tale is said to have taken place. However, according to Snopes, which did a full fact-check analysis of this story, there is no mention of General Pershing killing large amounts of terrorists with pig's blood with no remorse in order to prove a point about terrorism.\n\nIn fact, there is documentation that proves Pershing felt some remorse at what went down in the Philippines, particularly when he recalled his solders having to kill soldiers of the opposing side when they refused to turn over their weapons. The letter, written by Pershing according to Snopes, revealed the following:\n\nI write you this letter because I am sorry to know that you and your people refuse to do what the government has ordered. You do not give up your arms. Soldiers were sent to Taglibi so that you could come into camp and turn in your guns. When the soldiers went to camp a Taglibi, your Moros fired into camp and tried to kill the soldiers. Then the soldiers had to shoot all Moros who fired upon them.\n\nWhen the soldiers marched through the country, the Moros again shot at them, so the soldiers had to kill several others. I am sorry the soldiers had to kill any Moros. All Moros are the same to me as my children and no father wants to kill his own children ...\n\nThis letter reveals a far different man than the one Trump paints Pershing to be. Of course, a military leader could have many sides of him and many points of strength and weakness throughout his time leading troops in war, but the problem is, multiple news outlets report there being absolutely no evidence of Trump's pig's blood tall tale.\n\nSnopes even goes as far to suggest that Pershing was clear on his intent to avoid \"radical religious fanaticism\" in his enemies in Pershing's own published recounts of what happened.\n\nWhy Is This Tweet Problematic?\n\nThe United States condemns the terror attack in Barcelona, Spain, and will do whatever is necessary to help. Be tough & strong, we love you!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\nTrump brought up his believed tale of Pershing a few hours after a car plowed into pedestrians on a street in Barcelona, Spain. Like he has done so many times before, Trump used a moment when Americans and European countries around the world are hurting and frightened in the face of terrorism, and suggested a brutal solution (like the one he believed Pershing supplied) to Islamic extremist groups.\n\nA president who cites his own history books, and never waits until he hears all sides of the story -- unless he's looking for a reason to go easy on Nazi hate groups -- is making decisions about how to handle ISIS. It's time to stop making excuses for Donald Trump and start calling out the seriousness of his claims and the potential danger they can have for Americans and people around the world.\n\nSubscribe to John J. Pershing supposedly quelled an Islamic insurgency while serving in the Philippines in the early 20th century.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. The Islamic State group did, hours later, claim responsibility for the attack, though Trump's immediate connection to Islamic extremists - and his promotion of the long-debunked story about Pershing - appears to contradict his remarks from earlier in the week.\n\n\"Before I make a statement, I need the facts. So I don't want to rush into a statement,\" Trump said at a press conference on Tuesday, explaining his delayed response to issue a statement condemning the violence in Charlottesville. \"Unlike the media, before I make a statement, I like to know the facts.\"\n\nTrump first referenced a story about Pershing during a political rally in February 2016, when he told a crowd in North Charleston, South Carolina, that Pershing \"took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood\" before using them to shoot 49 Muslim rebels.\n\nSome Muslims believe that eating pork is forbidden and would prevent entrance into heaven, though many interpretations conclude it is not a sin to unknowingly or unwillingly do so.\n\n\"The 50th person, he said, 'You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened.' {"timeCrawl": "02:18:00", "uri": "711210767", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T02:18:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"title": "Firstpost", "uri": "firstpost.com", "id": "2530"}, "url": "http://www.firstpost.com/world/after-barcelona-terror-attack-donald-trump-hints-at-support-for-mass-executions-of-islamist-extremists-3943745.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "Washington: President Donald Trump on Thursday appeared to endorse the idea of mass executions for Islamist extremists, as he alluded to a widely debunked account of summary punishment by a US general in the Philippines in the early 1900s.\n\nIt was another provocative tweet from an increasingly isolated leader who uses Twitter to take shots at perceived opponents -- and even announce big policy changes.\n\nThursday's tweet also suggested Trump actually believes a story that many historians say is apocryphal.\n\nTrump first sent out a tweet offering aid to Spain after Thursday's van attack in Barcelona that left at least 13 dead and more than 50 wounded. About an hour later, Trump tweeted: \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\nHe was referring to General John \"Black Jack\" Pershing who was the US governor of largely Muslim Moro province from 1909 to 1913. At the time, the Philippines was a US colony. And Pershing's forces had to fight Muslim counter-insurgencies.\n\nThe debunked account -- which Trump has referred to in the past -- is as follows: Pershing's forces rounded up 50 Muslim insurgents and executed 49 of them with bullets dipped in pig's blood -- considered by Muslims to be unholy.\n\n\"You heard that, right?\" Trump said as a candidate during a rally in February 2016 in South Carolina, alluding to the pig blood part. \"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Trump said.\n\nFile image of US president Donald Trump. AP\n\nAs the story goes, the 50th prisoner was released to tell his fellow fighters about what the Americans had done. \"And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem,\" Trump said.\n\nHistorians have expressed skepticism or outright denial that this event took place.\n\nAccording to the fact checking website Politifact, the late military historian Frank Vandiver said in 2003, referring to Pershing: \"I never found any indication that it was true in extensive research on his Moro experiences. This kind of thing would have run completely against his character.\" Politifact quoted four historians who denied the account.\n\nTrump endorsed waterboarding -- widely held now to be a torture technique, used during the George W Bush administration in its war on terror and halted by Barack Obama -- during the presidential campaign.\n\nOnce in office, however, after US generals advised him against reverting to waterboarding, with some saying torture simply did not work as a way to extract information, Trump said he would yield to them. And he stopped making public endorsements of the technique.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 18, 2017 07:18 am | Updated Date: Aug 18, 2017 07:18 am\n\nTags :#Barcelona terror attack#Donald trump#General Trump claimed that during the Moro rebellion in the Philippines between 1901 and 1913, U.S. Gen. John Pershing executed Muslim insurgents with bullets dipped in pig's blood. Trump's retelling of the myth has changed each time\n\nThat story has been discredited by historians, some of whom concluded it would have been \"out of character\" for Pershing. But other accounts of the Philippine conflict have suggested that U.S. troops did use pigs or pig's blood to threaten or intimidate Muslims in other situations. Muslims consider pig's blood to be unholy and ingesting pork to be a sin.\n\n\"So yes, there were deliberate efforts to offend Muslim Filipinos' religious sensibilities,\" Christopher Capozzola, a history professor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, told TIME last year. \"And yes, there was large-scale violence against their communities. But I know of no event like the one that Mr. Trump describes.\"\n\nEarlier in the day, Trump condemned the attack in Barcelona, which police are treating as an act of terrorism. {"timeCrawl": "23:37:00", "uri": "711165845", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:37:00Z", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "source": {"title": "International Business Times UK", "uri": "ibtimes.co.uk", "id": "713"}, "url": "http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/trump-responds-barcelona-terror-attack-by-reviving-debunked-bloody-muslim-war-myth-1635537", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "US President repeated necdote about General Pershing dipping bullets in pig's blood.\n\nUS President Donald Trump has reacted to the Barcelona terror attack by repeating a war myth about a US general more than 100 years ago dipping bullets in pig's blood to fight Muslim insurgents.\n\nWorld leaders expressed sympathy after the Spanish city was rocked by a terror attack on Thursday (17 August) when a rented van mowed down dozens on Las Ramblas in the centre of the city.\n\nTrump joined them in condemning the attack, initially saying the US will \"do whatever is necessary to help\" and told Spaniards to \"be tough and strong\".\n\nBut in a follow-up tweet, the bombastic billionaire made a reference to an old war myth about Gen John Pershing who was governor of Moro province in the Philippines, between 1909 and 1913.\n\nThe tweet urged followers to: \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nThis tweet follows a similar claim Trump made at an election rally in South Carolina in February 2016 where he discussed \"getting tough\" on Islamic extremism and spoke of the insurgency in The Philippines.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems just like we do,\" Trump said according to Mother Jones. \"And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people.\n\n\"And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men, and he dipped 50 bullets in pig's blood.\"\n\nHe claimed Pershing then \"had his men load his rifles and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said, 'You go back to your people and you tell them what happened.'\"\n\nHe added: \"And for 25 years there wasn't a problem\" although he seems to have revised that figure up to 35 years.\n\nAfter the original claims, Time magazine spoke to two historians who found no evidence to support the claim with Snopes, a myth-busting site, coming to the same conclusion.\n\nHowever, the Time investigation references the History News Network which discovered a Chicago Daily Tribune article from 1927 describes Pershing sprinkling prisoners with pig's blood, then setting them free.\n\nAlso, Shannon Dunn, assistant professor of religious studies at Gonzaga University, told HuffPost the idea that Muslims believed they would go to hell if shot with pigs' blood, the reason behind the supposed tactic, was false.\n\nOther leaders however lent their support and solidarity to Spain. Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy said \"will never defeat a United people who love freedom from barbarism\" and added he was travelling to Barcelona to coordinate security efforts.\n\n\"Maximum coordination to arrest the attackers, reinforce security and attend to all those affected,\" he said.\n\nUK Prime Minister Theresa May said in a statement that she was \"sickened by the senseless loss of life in Barcelona\" and that the Foreign Office was trying to establish if any British nationals were injured in the attack.\n\nFrench president Emmanuel Macron also expressed his condolences with Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\nThe president's response to the Barcelona attack was far swifter than his delayed response to the white supremacist clashes in Charlottesville, Virginia on Saturday and his initial failure to flatly denounce white nationalists. Instead, Trump blamed \"many sides\" for the violence.\n\nAmid intense criticism over his equivocal remarks, Trump was forced to issue a stronger statement rejecting hate groups two days after the \"Unite the Right\" rally, where Heather Heyer was killed by a suspected white supremacist who drove through a crowd of counter-protesters.\n\nBy Tuesday, however, the president returned to his assertion that there were multiple sides to the violence, all but defending some white nationalists as \"very fine people.\" He also lashed out at reporters when asked why he did condemn white supremacists from the start, claiming he didn't have all the \"facts\" to do so on Saturday.\n\n\"I wanted to make sure, unlike most politicians, that what I said was correct,\" he said. \"Unlike the media, before I make a statement, I like to know the facts.\"\n\nTrump later followed up his condemnation Thursday with a second tweet that perhaps explains why the president was so quick to react to Barcelona and not Charlottesville. John Joseph \"Black Jack\" Pershing.\n\nDuring his campaign, Tump often told the anecdote from the aftermath of the 1899-1902 war between the Philippines and the United States. The U.S. had taken over the island nation from the Spanish, but met violent resistance in a conflict that led to the deaths of 4,000 Americans, more than 20,000 Filipino soldiers and thousands of civilians.\n\nPershing was the governor of the heavily Muslim Moro Province from 1909 to 1913, a period plagued by multiple uprisings, according to an exhaustive research piece in Politifact, a website that investigates claims by politicians to determine their truthfulness.\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nTrump repeated the story on multiple occasions at campaign rallies in 2016, telling the apocryphal story of a violent response by Pershing to the acts of \"50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people.\"\n\nPershing shot 49 of them with bullets dipped in pig's blood, Trump said, and told the last man to go back to his people and tell what had happened.\n\n\"And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. {"timeCrawl": "01:41:00", "uri": "711200294", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T18:14:00Z", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "source": {"title": "The Boston Globe", "uri": "bostonglobe.com", "id": "512"}, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2017/08/17/trump-trots-out-false-claim-about-pershing-treatment-muslims-again/e51fcwhI0Z5QNNjK5ZXo5H/story.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "Less than three hours after a terrorist attack in Barcelona killed at least 12 people Thursday, President Trump repeated a false assertion he made during the 2016 campaign about US General John Joseph \"Black Jack\" Pershing's treatment of Muslims over a century ago.\n\nNo indication of the motives or beliefs of the Barcelona suspects had yet been released by authorities.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught,\" Trump tweeted at 2 p.m. \"There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\n(The Islamic State claimed responsibility nearly two hours after Trump's tweet.)\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nGet Ground Game in your inbox: Daily updates and analysis on national politics from James Pindell. Sign Up Thank you for signing up! Sign up for more newsletters here\n\nTrump was referring to Pershing's time as governor of a majority-Muslim province in the Philippines from 1909 to 1913, in the wake of the Philippine-American War. His time there was marked by anti-American insurgencies. (The Philippines were a US colony during the first half of the 20th century.)\n\nThough he did not elaborate Thursday, in February 2016 at a campaign rally in South Carolina Trump made detailed -- but false -- claims about how Pershing dealt with the rebels.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Trump said, according to the Washington Post. \"And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pigs' blood -- you heard that, right? He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened. And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. OK? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAfter that rally, fact-checking sites Politifact and Snopes both found no basis to the story.\n\nAs Politifact put it in February 2016, \"After Trump told this story, critics called it apocryphal, misleading or outright false. Our friends at Snopes.com considered the evidence and called it a 'legend.' We decided to check with historians of the period to see what they thought of the story. We heard back from eight scholars. Most expressed skepticism that the specific story ever happened, and many added that Trump's takeaway is wrong-headed.\"\n\nThe Post reported that other versions of the Pershing tale say the executed prisoners were buried with dead pigs. Exposing Muslims to pigs and foods made from pigs is a popular idea with Islamophobes, based on the Islamic teaching that pigs are impure.\n\nBut aside from being false, the actions supposedly taken by Pershing are not even effective.\n\nAs Haroon Moghul put it in the Guardian after Trump's speech last year, \"What is it with bigots and bacon?\"\n\nTrump's false story about Pershing echoes a subset of hate crimes against Muslims in the United States in recent years. Moghul cited a number of incidents commtted by people who \"apparently believe that the sight of porcine products is kryptonite to Muslims.\"\n\nAmong them: \"A pig's head was thrown at a Philadelphia mosque in December. Bacon was found wrapped around the handles of mosque doors in Oklahoma last April and Las Vegas in December and on the doorstep of an Orlando mosque in January.\"\n\nMoghul ridiculed the idea that Muslims are terrified of pigs. \"Just put pork anywhere near us Muslims, some people seem to believe, and we'll soon keel over in psycho-spiritual distress.\"\n\n\"Republicans might like to say that guns don't kill people, people kill people -- but pig's blood doesn't kill Muslims or send us straight to hell, as some bigots reportedly believe,\" Moghul wrote. \"Telling a story about dipping bullets in pig's blood before killing 49 Muslims with impunity is particularly offensive, not least because the summary execution of so many people is a footnote to a story that traffics in crude stereotypes about our dietary restrictions. (It's not hard to imagine the deserved outcry if the victims were adherents of another major religion who eschew pork -- Jews.)\"\n\nBrian J. {"timeCrawl": "21:10:00", "uri": "711116283", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:10:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"title": "Los Angeles Times", "uri": "latimes.com", "id": "971"}, "url": "http://www.latimes.com/politics/washington/la-na-essential-washington-updates-trump-tweets-unsupported-claim-about-1503002456-htmlstory.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "Trump redoubles support for Confederate memorials and opposition to two GOP senators Aug. 17, 2017, 1:59 p.m.\n\nHere's our look at the Trump administration and the rest of Washington:\n\nThe president lauds GOP rival to Arizona's Sen. Flake and attacks Sen. Graham Trump laments removal of Confederate monuments as loss to history, cultureWhite House strategist Stephen Bannon unloads in unsolicited call to liberal writerTrump plans Arizona rally, his first in West, but mayor says don't come All updates Congress Economy Immigration Media Watch: On the Right North Korea Obamacare Russia White House Aug. 17, 2017, 1:59 p.m. Trump repeats claim about Gen. Pershing's treatment of Muslims prisoners that historians say probably never happened Colleen Shalby\n\nHours after a van plowed through a crowd in Barcelona and left at least 12 dead, Donald Trump tweeted condemnation of the attack and quickly followed with a statement about U.S. Army Gen. John Joseph Pershing that historians describe as urban legend.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\" he tweeted.\n\nThe full claim, which Trump repeated several times during his 2016 presidential campaign, is that in the aftermath of the Philippine-American War of 1899-1902, Pershing had his men dip 50 bullets in pig's blood and use them to kill 49 Muslim prisoners. The survivor was told to relay the experience to others.\n\nThe story claims that terrorism decreased for decades.\n\nIf true, the story would constitute a war crime under U.S. law, which prohibits execution of prisoners.\n\nThe tale has circulated across the Internet for years. Trump told it in February 2016 during a speech to supporters in North Charleston, S.C., in which he lauded the benefits of heavy-handed interrogation techniques.\n\n\"He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: 'You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened.' And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem,\" Trump told the crowd.\n\nThe Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) denounced those remarks shortly after.\n\n\"Donald Trump's inflammatory rhetoric has crossed the line from spreading hatred to inciting violence,\" national executive director of CAIR Nihad Awad said.\n\nTwo months later during a speech that criticized President Obama's acceptance of Middle Eastern war refugees into the U.S., Trump told the same story to supporters in Costa Mesa. This time, he altered the number of problem-free years from 25 to 42.\n\nIn a 2013 edition of Pershing's memoir, a letter from Maj. Gen. J. Franklin Bell to Pershing was added in the footnote. The letter described a long \"custom to bury (insurgents) with pigs when they kill Americans.\" Bell called the tactic \"a good plan.\"\n\nThe letter does indicate that pig blood was at one time used, or at the very least discussed, as an intimidation tactic against Muslim fighters, since Islam considers pigs unclean.\n\nBut there's no evidence that Pershing - who historians describe as less brutal than his predecessors - ever used such a technique.\n\n\"This story is a fabrication and has long been discredited,\" Brian McAllister Linn, a Texas A&M University historian, told Politifact. \"I am amazed it is still making the rounds.\"\n\nEven if the story about Pershing were true, the claim of 25, 35 or 42 years of peace and quiet would be false. Unrest continued long after the war, and the Philippines continues to have an active Muslim-based insurgency.\n\nLatest updates Copyright \u00a9 2017, Los Angeles Times", "id": "9777878", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Trump repeats claim about Gen. {"timeCrawl": "23:09:00", "uri": "711156955", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:09:00Z", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "source": {"title": "LAist", "uri": "laist.com", "id": "10147"}, "url": "http://laist.com/2017/08/17/pershing_trump.php", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "Downtown's Pershing Square is named for General John J. Pershing, an early 20th century U.S. Army general decorated for his service during World War I. He's also the unfortunate subject of a widely discredited myth about his odious treatment of Muslim \"terrorists\" sometime during or after the Philippine-American War of 1899-1902.\n\nThe \"story,\" which involves using pig's blood as a weapon against Muslims, has been rated false by Snopes and \"Pants on Fire\" by Politifact's Truth-o-Meter. Veracity aside, it remains a favorite of President Trump's, and he referenced it again in a tweet on Thursday, following an apparent terrorist attack in Barcelona:\n\nTrump further fleshed out his take on the unfounded Pershing claims (and, by extension, the example he would like his 36.1 million Twitter followers to act on) in February 2016, when he used the story as a means of justifying his support of waterboarding. Pershing, as Trump told a South Carolina rally, was a \"rough guy, rough guy\" fighting terrorism in the early 1900s. Here's how he described his understanding of the story, according to the Washington Post:\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Trump said. \"And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pigs' blood -- you heard that, right? He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened. And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nThe then-candidate's \"suggestion that executing Islamic terrorists using bullets soaked in pigs blood would be sign of toughness\" was met with \"astonishment from members of the American Muslim community\" back in February of last year, according to the New York Times.\n\n\"Donald Trump's inflammatory rhetoric has crossed the line from spreading hatred to inciting violence,\" Nihad Awad, executive director of the Council on American-Islamic Relations, said at the time. \"By directly stating that the only way to stop terrorism is to murder Muslims in graphic and religiously-offensive ways, he places the millions of innocent, law-abiding citizens in the American Muslim community at risk from rogue vigilantes.\"\n\nTrump is no longer just a candidate, and that line between spreading hatred and inciting violence has been crossed many times over. The story in question, however, remains unfounded.\n\n\"This story is a fabrication and has long been discredited,\" Brian McAllister Linn, a Texas A&M University historian and author of Guardians of Empire: The U.S. Army and the Pacific, 1902-1940, told Politifact. \"This kind of thing would have run completely against [Pershing's] character,\" Christopher Einolf, another professor and the literal author of a book called America in the Philippines, 1899-1902: The First Torture Scandal, told Politifact.\n\n\"Even if the tale is true, the pacifying effect that Trump claims is nonsense,\" a third historian told Politifact. The region \"remained in constant unrest during the period of American rule and into the period of independence, right down to the present.\"\n\nPershing Square, which was first dedicated for use {"timeCrawl": "01:41:00", "uri": "711200421", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:14:00Z", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "source": {"title": "Mic", "uri": "mic.com", "id": "8806"}, "url": "https://mic.com/articles/183910/trump-tweets-fake-story-about-us-general-killing-terrorists-with-bullets-dipped-in-pigs-blood", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "On Thursday, following a terrorism attack in Barcelona, Spain, that left at least 12 victims dead, President Donald Trump condemned the attackers on Twitter, who were allegedly members of the Islamic State.\n\nHowever, Trump didn't stop there. In a follow-up message Trump wrote, \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nAs Politifact noted, this isn't the first time Trump has referenced Pershing, who served as governor of Moro Province, a majority-Muslim area in the Philippines, following the Philippine-American War of 1899-1902.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Trump said during a rally in South Carolina in 2016, according to the Washington Post. Trump went on to add,\n\nAnd he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pigs' blood -- you heard that, right? He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened. And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem.\n\nIn his most recent tweet, that gap changed to 35 years.\n\nHowever, according to the history books, Pershing never dipped bullets in pigs blood or let the fiftieth person go, or really did any of the things Trump claimed.\n\nOff the bat, his biggest blunder in this tweet is equivocating the Muslim faith with terrorists.\n\n\"The Moros were fighting for a lot of reasons, not just because they were Muslims,\" Lance Janda, a military historian at Cameron University, told Politifact. \"This is another fact that gets lost in many modern discussions of terrorism.\"\n\nAdditionally, several historians noted that the events Trump described flat out never happened.\n\n\"This story is a fabrication and has long been discredited,\" Brian McAllister Linn, a Texas A&M University historian and author of Guardians of Empire: The U.S. Army and the Pacific, 1902-1940, told Politifact. \"I am amazed it is still making the rounds.\"\n\nMoreover, Frank E. Vandiver, professor of history at Texas A&M University and author of Black Jack: The Life and Times of John J. Pershing, told About.com that not only was the story untrue, it would have also \"run completely against his character.\"\n\n\"I never found any indication that it was true in extensive research on his Moro experiences,\" Vandiver said.\n\nInstead, Janda explained to Politifact that Pershing did a lot of \"what we would call 'winning hearts and minds' and embraced reforms which helped end their resistance.\"\n\n\"He fought too, but only when he had to, and only against tribes or bands that just wouldn't negotiate with him,\" Janda added. \"He wasn't solely committed to fighting as people like Trump who tell the pig blood story imply.\"\n\nHistorian after historian and expert after expert warned that not only was Trump completely off base with his versions of events (otherwise known as \"fake news\"), he's also off in believing that his made up version of pacifying insurgents would work.\n\n\"Where Trump's remark becomes ridiculous is in the idea that this actually worked,\" David J. Silbey, a Cornell University historian and author of A War of Frontier and Empire: The Philippine-American War, told Politifact. \"The Moro War did not end until 1913, and even that's a bit of a soft date, with violence continuing for quite a while afterward. Defilement by pig's blood isn't -- and wasn't -- some magical method of ending terrorism.\"", "id": "9806039", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Trump tweets fake story about US general killing terrorists with bullets dipped in pigs' blood", "image": {"timeCrawl": "22:49:00", "uri": "711150366", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:49:00Z", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "source": {"title": "SBS", "uri": "sbs.com.au", "id": "793"}, "url": "http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2017/08/18/trump-appears-endorse-mass-executions-islamic-extremists", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "The US president's provocative tweet followed the terror attack in Barcelona, and continued a pattern of behaviour of an increasingly isolated leader who uses Twitter to take shots at perceived opponents - and even announce big policy changes.\n\nThursday's tweet also suggested Trump actually believes a story that many historians say is apocryphal.\n\nTrump first sent out a tweet offering aid to Spain after Thursday's van attack in Barcelona that left at least 13 dead and more than 50 wounded.\n\nAbout an hour later, Trump tweeted: \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nHe was referring to General John \"Black Jack\" Pershing who was the US governor of largely Muslim Moro province from 1909 to 1913.\n\nAt the time, the Philippines was a US colony. And Pershing's forces had to fight Muslim counterinsurgencies.\n\nThe debunked account - which Trump has referred to in the past - is as follows: Pershing's forces rounded up 50 Muslim insurgents and executed 49 of them with bullets dipped in pig's blood - considered by Muslims to be unholy.\n\n\"You heard that, right?\" Trump said as a candidate during a rally in February 2016 in South Carolina, alluding to the pig blood part.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Trump said.\n\nAs the story goes, the 50th prisoner was released to tell his fellow fighters about what the Americans had done.\n\n\"And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem,\" Trump said.\n\nHistorians have expressed skepticism or outright denial that this event took place.\n\nAccording to the fact checking website Politifact, the late military historian Frank Vandiver said in 2003, referring to Pershing: \"I never found any indication that it was true in extensive research on his Moro experiences. This kind of thing would have run completely against his character.\"\n\nPolitifact quoted four historians who denied the account.\n\nTrump endorsed waterboarding - widely held now to be a torture technique, used during the George W. Bush administration in its war on terror and halted by Barack Obama - during the presidential campaign.\n\nOnce in office, however, after US generals advised him against reverting to waterboarding, with some saying torture simply did not work as a way to extract information, Trump said he would yield to them.\n\nAnd he stopped making public endorsements of the technique.", "id": "9789862", {"timeCrawl": "12:40:00", "uri": "711441978", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T12:40:00Z", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "source": {"title": "The Scottish Sun", "uri": "thescottishsun.co.uk", "id": "17001"}, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/1437000/disgust-as-donald-trump-quotes-fake-story-of-general-pershing-who-executed-muslim-terrorists-with-pigs-blood-soaked-bullets-following-barcelona-attack/", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "President Trump made reference to the mythical story in the wake of the Barcelona terror attack\n\nDONALD Trump quoted a FAKE story of a US general who \"executed Muslim terrorists with pigs' blood-soaked bullets\" after the Barcelona bloodbath.\n\nThe US President tweeted a message of support for the victims of the atrocity, saying he \"condemns the terror attack\" and \"will do whatever is necessary to help\".\n\nBut the message was followed up 45 minutes later with another, saying: \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nThe anecdote he is referring to is understood to be a myth about how General John Pershing executed dozens of Muslim terrorists in the Philippines with tainted ammunition during a guerrilla war in the early 1900s.\n\nThe story is understood to be a hoax spread by emails with no evidence it really occurred, according to rumour tracker Snopes.\n\nIt's not the first time Trump has made reference to the Pershing tale - according to MSNBC he told the story in South Carolina ahead of the state's Republican presidential primary in February 2016.\n\nHe said: \"He took fifty bullets, and he dipped them in pig's blood.\n\n\"And he had his men load his rifles and he lined up the fifty people, and they shot 49 of those people.\n\n\"And the fiftieth person he said 'You go back to your people and you tell them what happened.' And for 25 years there wasn't a problem, okay?\"\n\nTrump, getting to the \"moral\" of the story, concluded: \"We better start getting tough and we better start getting vigilant, and we better start using our heads or we're not gonna have a country, folks.\"\n\nThe tweet came after Trump said he wanted \"the facts\" before commenting on the Charlottesville violence that saw one woman killed while counter-protesting a white supremacist rally.\n\nBut social media users were quick to point out that the president had been promoting a \"lie\".\n\nPaula tweeted Trump directly: \"You are spreading a lie about a horrible, fictional account of history.\"\n\nAnother user said: \"So Trump yet again reveals that he thinks war crimes are acceptable\".\n\nDemocrat Ted Lieu said: \"@realDonaldTrump endorsing mass murder in his Pershing tweet is just to distract from negative stories about him endorsing Nazis.\"\n\nPresenter Jake Tapper tweeted: \"President Trump tells world to study lie about General Pershing\".\n\nAt least 13 people died and more than 100 people were injured in Barcelona on Thursday, making it the deadliest attack in Spain since the 2004 Madrid train bombs in which more than 190 people were killed.\n\nSince Trump's tweets, five terrorists were shot dead by police in the nearby seaside town of Cambrils in a second attack in Spain.\n\nThe men, wearing fake suicide vests, ploughed into pedestrians in an Audi A3, killing one woman and injuring five civilians including a police officer.\n\nIt came eight hours after a van hurtled through crowds in Las Ramblas, sending scores of people scattering, in an attack which was later claimed by ISIS.\n\nThree people have been arrested in connection with the attacks.\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May said she was \"sickened\" by the incident, while the Foreign Office said it was still trying to determine if there were British victims.", "id": "9893898", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", "title": "Disgust as {"timeCrawl": "10:04:00", "uri": "711372386", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T10:04:00Z", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "source": {"title": "The Scottish Sun", "uri": "thescottishsun.co.uk", "id": "17001"}, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/1436816/who-was-general-pershing-and-is-donald-trumps-claim-about-how-he-would-defeat-isis-true/", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "The United States Army officer served in World War I, achieving the highest possible rank during his lifetime\n\nHE was the most highly-ranked military officer in his lifetime, known for his leadership and tactical knowledge.\n\nNow, General John Pershing has been praised for the way he handled terrorism by Donald Trump - but how much of the story is true?\n\nGeneral John Joseph Pershing was born in Missouri, United States, in 1860.\n\nAt first working as a teacher, \"Black Jack\" then went on to successfully apply to join the United States Military Academy.\n\nFrom there, he worked his way up within the army, becoming an expert marksman.\n\nHe served in the US, as well as fighting in Cuba and Manila before the outbreak of World War I, even serving as governor of the Muslim Moro Province in the Philippines between 1909 and 1913.\n\nLater to become mentors to other generals including Douglas MacArthur and Dwight D Eisenhower, he was known for organising frontal assaults.\n\nHe was awarded with the highest possible rank in the army, receiving a promotion to General of the Armies.\n\nDonald Trump has repeatedly touted General Pershing's tactics in tackling terrorism.\n\nSpeaking in 2016, he referred to Pershing's time as governor over a majority-Muslim population in the Philippines, saying: \"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do.\n\n\"And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pigs' blood -- you heard that, right?\n\n\"He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people.\n\n\"And the 50th person, he said: 'You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened'.\n\n\"And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nThe United States President again referred to Pershing in the wake of the Barcelona terror attack, tweeting: \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nBut the reality star turned politician has been called out for the claims, with little evidence to back up the story.\n\nBrian McAllister Linn, a Texas A&M University historian told Politifact: \"This story is a fabrication and has long been discredited.\n\n\"I am amazed it is still making the rounds.\"\n\nThe only story similar to that touted by Trump comes from a letter written by a soldier who served in the Philippines, who wrote that Pershing was seen to hang a chieftain \"by the heels over an open grave, kill a pig, and then drop the Moro into the grave with the bloody animal\".\n\nOther historians have said that Pershing's success in the Phillipines came from his work to win the hearts and minds of locals as well as his There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nHe was referring to General John \"Black Jack\" Pershing who was the US governor of largely Muslim Moro province from 1909 to 1913.\n\nAt the time, the Philippines was a US colony. And Pershing's forces had to fight Muslim counterinsurgencies.\n\nThe debunked account - which Trump has referred to in the past - is as follows: Pershing's forces rounded up 50 Muslim insurgents and executed 49 of them with bullets dipped in pig's blood - considered by Muslims to be unholy.\n\n\"You heard that, right?\" Trump said as a candidate during a rally in February 2016 in South Carolina, alluding to the pig blood part.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Trump said.\n\nAs the story goes, the 50th prisoner was released to tell his fellow fighters about what the Americans had done.\n\n\"And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem,\" Trump said.\n\nHistorians have expressed skepticism or outright denial that this event took place.\n\nAccording to the fact checking website Politifact, the late military historian Frank Vandiver said in 2003, referring to Pershing: \"I never found any indication that it was true in extensive research on his Moro experiences. This kind of thing would have run completely against his character.\"\n\nPolitifact quoted four historians who denied the account.\n\nTrump endorsed waterboarding - widely held now to be a torture technique, used during the George W. Bush administration in its war on terror and halted by Barack Obama - during the presidential campaign.\n\nOnce in office, however, after US generals advised him against reverting to waterboarding, with some saying torture simply did not work as a way to extract information, Trump said he would yield to them.\n\nAnd he stopped making public endorsements of the technique.", "id": "9830186", {"timeCrawl": "01:34:00", "uri": "711199086", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T01:34:00Z", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "source": {"title": "themalaymailonline.com", "uri": "themalaymailonline.com", "id": "661"}, "url": "http://www.themalaymailonline.com/world/article/trump-again-cites-dubious-muslim-execution-story-after-spain-attack", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "Forensic police officers search for clues near the area where a van crashed into pedestrians at Las Ramblas in Barcelona, Spain, August 17, 2017. -- Reuters picWASHINGTON, Aug 18 -- President Donald Trump appeared yesterday to endorse the idea of mass executions for Islamist extremists, as he alluded to a widely debunked account of summary punishment by a US general in the Philippines in the early 1900s.\n\nIt was another provocative tweet from an increasingly isolated leader who uses Twitter to take shots at perceived opponents -- and even announce big policy changes.\n\nYesterday's tweet also suggested Trump actually believes a story that many historians say is apocryphal.\n\nTrump first sent out a tweet offering aid to Spain after yesterday's van attack in Barcelona that left at least 13 dead and more than 50 wounded.\n\nAbout an hour later, Trump tweeted: \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nHe was referring to General John \"Black Jack\" Pershing who was the US governor of largely Muslim Moro province from 1909 to 1913.\n\nAt the time, the Philippines was a US colony.\n\nAnd Pershing's forces had to fight Muslim counterinsurgencies.\n\nThe debunked account -- which Trump has referred to in the past -- is as follows: Pershing's forces rounded up 50 Muslim insurgents and executed 49 of them with bullets dipped in pig's blood -- considered by Muslims to be unholy.\n\n\"You heard that, right?\" Trump said as a candidate during a rally in February 2016 in South Carolina, alluding to the pig blood part.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Trump said.\n\nAs the story goes, the 50 prisoner was released to tell his fellow fighters about what the Americans had done.\n\n\"And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem,\" Trump said.\n\nHistorians have expressed skepticism or outright denial that this event took place.\n\nAccording to the fact checking website Politifact, the late military historian Frank Vandiver said in 2003, referring to Pershing: \"I never found any indication that it was true in extensive research on his Moro experiences. This kind of thing would have run completely against his character.\"\n\nPolitifact quoted four historians who denied the account.\n\nTrump endorsed waterboarding -- widely held now to be a torture technique, used during the George W. Bush administration in its war on terror and halted by Barack Obama -- during the presidential campaign.\n\nOnce in office, however, after US generals advised him against reverting to waterboarding, with some saying torture simply did not work as a way to extract information, Trump said he would yield to them.\n\nAnd he stopped making public endorsements of the technique. -- AFP", "id": There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nHe was referring to General John \"Black Jack\" Pershing who was the US governor of largely Muslim Moro province from 1909 to 1913.\n\nAt the time, the Philippines was a US colony. And Pershing's forces had to fight Muslim counterinsurgencies.\n\nThe debunked account - which Trump has referred to in the past - is as follows: Pershing's forces rounded up 50 Muslim insurgents and executed 49 of them with bullets dipped in pig's blood - considered by Muslims to be unholy.\n\n\"You heard that, right?\" Trump said as a candidate during a rally in February 2016 in South Carolina, alluding to the pig blood part.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Trump said.\n\nAs the story goes, the 50th prisoner was released to tell his fellow fighters about what the Americans had done.\n\n\"And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem,\" Trump said.\n\nHistorians have expressed skepticism or outright denial that this event took place.\n\nAccording to the fact checking website Politifact, the late military historian Frank Vandiver said in 2003, referring to Pershing: \"I never found any indication that it was true in extensive research on his Moro experiences. This kind of thing would have run completely against his character.\"\n\nPolitifact quoted four historians who denied the account.\n\nTrump endorsed waterboarding - widely held now to be a torture technique, used during the George W. Bush administration in its war on terror and halted by Barack Obama - during the presidential campaign.\n\nOnce in office, however, after US generals advised him against reverting to waterboarding, But the attack still prompted President Trump to tweet out his prescription for dealing with radical Islamic terror: \"Study what General Pershing ... did.\"\n\nTrump's referring to an apocryphal tale about U.S. Gen. John J. Pershing. According to the stories, Pershing put down a militant Muslim group in the Philippines by executing its members with bullets dipped in pig's blood. Supposedly, the Islamic prohibition against pork frightened the other militants into submission.\n\nTrump trotted out the canard several times on the campaign trail:\n\n\"You'll take a look at Gen. Pershing in 1919 in the Philippines, how he stopped terrorism.\"\n\nSEE MORE: President Trump's Top Generals Are Empowered And Working Overtime\n\nLike most apocryphal stories, the tale about Gen. Pershing isn't supported by facts. The closest historical analogue comes from a 1927 Chicago Daily Tribune article, which claims Pershing sprinkled pig's blood on Muslim captives before letting them go.\n\nSnopes, which has declared the story false, also notes Pershing was generally careful to avoid inciting religious extremism during his campaign against the militants and tried to avoid unnecessary bloodshed\n\nBut the idea of using pig-infused weapons to combat Islamic extremism has stuck around anyway -- an anti-Muslim militant group in Texas reportedly trains with bullets dipped in pig's blood.", "id": "9793415", One suspect is already in custody.\n\nIt's against this backdrop that Donald Trump, who says he always wants to have all the \"facts\" before speaking on any subject, thought it'd be appropriate to highlight one of his favorite stories.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nFor those who followed Trump's presidential campaign closely, this is familiar rhetoric. The Republican candidate loved to rile up far-right voters by telling them a myth about General John Pershing. Here, for example, is a Washington Post report from June 2016, following a Trump event in South Carolina.\n\nAs the crowd cheered him on, Trump told them about Pershing - \"rough guy, rough guy\" - who was fighting terrorism in the early 1900s. Trump didn't say where this happened, but variations of this story online usually state that it happened in the Philippines during the Philippine-American War - part of the island nation's protracted battle for independence - early in Pershing's career.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Trump said. \"And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pigs' blood - you heard that, right? He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened. And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nThe more Trump told the story, the more he'd change the details of the myth - in several instances, he said Pershing's solution stopped terrorism for 42 years, or 35 years, or sometimes 25 years - but ultimately, it doesn't much matter.\n\nBecause the myth isn't real.\n\nAs MSNBC reported in February 2016, the Pershing story \"appears to be a hoax spread via email forwards.\" There's no evidence to back the apocryphal tale up, and according to experts in the Philippine conflict, the myth doesn't even make sense.\n\nBut Trump continues to repeat and believe the myth, in part because of his anti-Muslim animus, in part because he's fond of easy solutions to difficult problems, and in part because he long ago gave up on caring about the difference between fact and fiction. The president likes the hoax; therefore, the hoax must be real.\n\nEven if we put aside Trump's strained relationship with reality, let's not lose sight of the underlying point the president is eager to emphasize: in his mind, war crimes and mass executions are effective and worthwhile elements of an effective national security strategy.\n\nHe's dangerously wrong.", "id": "9771937", "details": {}, From his presidential campaign trail, to his Twitter page, and everything in between, Trump isn't exactly renowned for his well thought-out insight and words of wisdom. He's been criticized for his response to numerous current events, both in the United States and around the world. And now, following a terror attack in Barcelona, Trump has once again taken to Twitter to express some rather controversial thoughts. So, who is Gen. John Pershing and why does Trump want Americans to study up on his tactics?\n\nWell, if you look further into history, you'll see that the president implied that he wants to fight terrorism using a debunked myth involving -- wait for it -- pig's blood.\n\nAfter sending off one particularly uncharacteristic tweet regarding the terrorist attack in Barcelona, in which the POTUS sounded sincere in his remorse, Trump then decided to crank things up a notch. by recalling a statement he made on his campaign trail: \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught,\" Trump tweeted on Thursday. \"There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nNot long after this claim hit people's news feeds, it was quickly fact-checked and found to be untrue by historians. But, that doesn't mean it isn't cause for concern. Why? Well, the method Trump is referring to involves killing Muslim prisoners with pig's blood, and is totally false.\n\nAccording to The Washington Post, Trump first delivered remarks about Pershing during a 2016 campaign rally in Charleston. Here is the tale he told:\n\nHistorically speaking, there is very little about Trump's story that is true. One historian, Brian McAllister Linn, who works at Texas A&M University, even said that \"This story is a fabrication and has long been discredited. I am amazed it is still making the rounds,\" according to PolitiFact.\n\nOn the contrary, historians have said that Pershing wasn't as violent as Trump made him out to be. \"He wasn't solely committed to fighting as people like Trump who tell the pig blood story imply,\" Lance Janda, a military historian at Cameron University, said, per Politifact. And even if Trump's remarks were true (although, according to The Hill, his own campaign manager knows that they aren't), it wouldn't really matter.\n\nUsing Islamophobia tactics to attack an entire culture is not OK. {"timeCrawl": "01:41:00", "uri": "711200414", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:14:00Z", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "source": {"title": "Independent Journal Review", "uri": "ijr.com", "id": "11712"}, "url": "http://ijr.com/2017/08/950185-trump-re-ups-debunked-pigs-blood-claim-new-tweet-hours-spain-terrorist-attack/", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "President Donald Trump says he prefers to get his facts straight and doesn't like to rush into statements. At least that was what he told reporters after he didn't make a statement on an attack against counter-protesters at a pro-white rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, for two days.\n\nBut he may want to double-check the claim he made about United States Army Gen. John J. Pershing on Twitter on Thursday afternoon, hours after a terrorist attack in Spain.\n\nTrump plugged Pershing's supposed actions against Islamic terrorists during the Philippine-American War.\n\nIt wasn't the first time Trump referenced Pershing. He went into further detail about the general in February 2016, telling a South Carolina rally crowd:\n\n\"He took 50 bullets and dipped them in pig's blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people, and the 50th person -- he said, 'You go back to your people and you tell them what happened.'\n\n\"And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. For 25 years, there wasn't a problem. All right? So we better start getting tough.\"\n\nExperts say the claim about the pig's blood is bunk.\n\nEight historians told Politifact that Trump's claim was false, and Snopes determined the same. Journalist William Lambers found a 1927 Chicago Tribune story suggesting Pershing sprinkled Moros-supporting swordsmen, Juramentados, with pig's blood. He also pointed out that there were no mass executions led by Pershing, like the 49-man killing Trump described:\n\nThe Tribune article says Pershing sprinkled some prisoners with pig's blood, which the Juramentados believed would condemn them for eternity. But then Pershing let the prisoners go. He issued a warning to others about being sprinkled with the pig's blood. The Tribune article said \"those drops of porcine gore proved more powerful than bullets.\"\n\nThere is some evidence to suggest American military officers may have used swine in the burial proceedings for Muslim enemies in the war in the Philippines. As Politifact noted, Pershing's memoir recounted another officer burying a Muslim in the same grave as a pig.\n\nHowever, the specific claim about Pershing's execution of 49 soldiers with bullets dipped in pig's blood remains unsubstantiated.", "id": "9806035", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Trump Re-ups Debunked 'Pig's Blood' Claim in New Tweet Hours After Spain Terrorist There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\" Trump wrote.\n\nHours after Trump's tweet, newspapers quickly pointed out the US president's incautiousness.\n\nThe independent said: \"He appeared to be referring to a widely debunked story that Pershing overcame militant Muslims in the Philippines by killing them and burying their bodies with pigs.\"\n\n\"Another part of the legend is that he killed them with bullets dipped in pigs' blood.\"\n\nAccording to The Independent, historians who have studied Pershing's activities in the Moro province from 1909 to 1913 had discredited these claims.\n\nThe Washington Post also has a take on Trump's outrageous claims.\n\nIt said Brian M. {"timeCrawl": "01:42:00", "uri": "711200510", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T01:42:00Z", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "source": {"title": "philstar.com", "uri": "philstar.com", "id": "10155"}, "url": "http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/08/18/1730369/trump-false-historical-claim-pershing-moros-mindanao-philippines", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "MANILA, Philippines -- Under fire for his racially charged remarks, American President Donald Trump set another round of Twitter firestorm on Friday (Manila time) calling Moros in Mindanao during the American occupation \"terrorists.\"\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 Years!\" Trump tweeted, reviving a debunked legend about a United States Army Gen. John Joseph \"Black Jack\" Pershing subduing Moro rebels a century ago in the aftermath of the Philippine-American War.\n\nPershing, according to the historical myth, curbed the rebellion in the Philippines' south by shooting the rebels with bullets dipped in pig blood.\n\nAmericans faced Filipino armed opposition from 1899 to 1902 as they tried to occupy the archipelago following centuries of Spanish rule.\n\nPershing was installed governor of Moro areas in the south, but his four-year tenure starting 1909 was beset by insurgencies as the general tried to disarm the Muslim locals. Around 1,200 American troops led by Pershing faced a fierce resistance of 800 Moros in Jolo in the Second Battle of Bud Dajo.\n\nThis was not the first time that Trump referred to the offensive urban legend about pig's blood used to defeat the Muslim inhabitants of the islands.\n\nIn a speech in North Charleston in 2016, Trump claimed that Pershing and Americans in the south had a \"tremendous problem with terrorism.\"\n\n\"(Pershing) took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pig's blood. And he had his men load his rifles and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said, 'You go back to your people and you tell them what happened.' And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem,\" he said.\n\nHistorians have long debunked the story, saying it was uncharacteristic of Pershing to do so and there has been no evidence to confirm it.\n\nTrump's latest historically inaccurate comment about the Philippines was a followup to another tweet condemning violence in Barcelona, where more than a dozen people were killed when a van peered onto a sidewalk and sped down a busy pedestrian zone in what authorities called a terror attack.\n\nThe tweet referring to the rebellion in Mindanao was among the string of comments Trump made defending Confederate figures, bemoaning rising efforts to remove them as an attack on America's \"history and culture.\"\n\nTrump has berated his critics who, with increasingly sharper language, have denounced his initially slow and then ultimately combative comments on the racial violence at a white supremacist rally last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nTrump's unpredictable, defiant and, critics claim, racially provocative behavior has clearly begun to wear on his Republican allies.\n\nTennessee Sen. Bob Corker, whom Trump considered for a Cabinet post, declared Thursday that \"the president has not yet been able to demonstrate the stability nor some of the competence that he needs to\" in dealing with crises. And Sen. Dan Sullivan of Alaska tweeted, \"Anything less than complete & unambiguous condemnation of white supremacists, neo-Nazis and the KKK by the @POTUS is unacceptable. Period.\"\n\nSen. Tim Scott of South Carolina said Trump's \"moral authority is compromised.\"\n\nTrump, who is known to try to change the focus of news coverage with an attention-grabbing declaration, sought to shift Thursday from the white supremacists to the future of statues.\n\n\"You can't change history, but you can learn from it,\" he tweeted. \"Robert E. Lee. Stonewall Jackson -- who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish. ...\n\n\"Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\"\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments,\" he tweeted. -- Camille Diola with reports from the Associated Press (New Jersey)", "id": "9806104",
