Pershing"}, "id": "486790", "score": 5, "type": "person", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_J._Pershing"}], "location": {"country": {"label": {"eng": "Philippines"}, "type": "country"}, "label": {"eng": "City of Manila"}, "type": "place"}, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 285, "label": "dmoz/Society/History", "uri": "dmoz/Society/History"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 298, "label": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 705, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Race-Ethnic-Religious Relations", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Race-Ethnic-Religious_Relations"}], "time": "01:42:00"}
{"timeCrawl": "06:28:00", "uri": "711288561", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T06:28:00Z", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "source": {"title": "Washington Post", "uri": "washingtonpost.com", "id": "104"}, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/retropolis/wp/2017/08/18/after-barcelona-attack-trump-said-to-study-general-pershing-heres-what-the-president-got-wrong/", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "Gen. John J. Pershing is shown on horseback in front of his summer home and general headquarters at Chaumont, Haute-Marne, France, in 1918. (AP)\n\nA sordid tale of General John J. Pershing executing Muslim insurgents in the Philippines at the turn of the century is a favorite of President Trump.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Trump told a throng of cheering supporters in South Carolina in February 2016.\n\n\"[Pershing] caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pigs' blood -- you heard that, right? He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened. And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nIt's a story Trump has repeated, and echoed again Thursday after what authorities have called a terrorist attack in Barcelona that killed at least 13 people and left many more wounded when a driver smashed his van onto a busy sidewalk.\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\n[Trump recycles discredited Islamic pigs' blood tale after terrorist attack in Barcelona]\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\" he tweeted.\n\nBrian M. Linn, a history professor at Texas A&M University, did just that nearly two decades ago when he published \"Guardians of Empire,\" a book on the U.S. military presence in Asia from 1902 to 1940.\n\nHis verdict on Trump's claim?\n\n\"There is absolutely no evidence this occurred,\" he told The Washington Post.\n\n\"It's a made-up story. It doesn't seem to matter how many times people say this isn't true. No one can say where or when this occurred.\"\n\nBut Trump's claims, and the wider belief in a routinely debunked story, has far-reaching effects. Not only is the story untrue, but the convenient twist -- of an insurgency defeated only with the use of brutal war tactics -- points to precisely the opposite lessons Pershing and his troops learned in the Philippines campaign from 1899 to 1913, Linn said.\n\n\"The U.S. military learned escalating counterterrorism was not effective, and they took great steps, including Pershing, to de-escalate,\" Linn said.\n\nWho was John J. Pershing?\n\nPershing was a U.S. Military Academy graduate who first earned distinction in the Indian-American Wars, and later his nickname, \"Black Jack,\" after commanding the all-African American Buffalo Soldiers unit.\n\nHe was an astute and battle-experienced captain who first arrived in the Philippines in 1899, where he learned the value of defusing tribal grievances among the Moro, the followers of Islam on the archipelago engaged in tribal violence and insurrection against the United States. The Philippines were acquired after the United States won the Spanish-American War in 1898, and an insurrection arose following attempts to pacify the country as it sought independence from colonial rule.\n\nPershing studied the Koran and drank tea with tribal leaders to emphasize he was there to put down violence, not continue a religious war the Spanish had waged for centuries.\n\n\"He did a lot of what we would call 'winning hearts and minds' and embraced reforms which helped end their resistance,\" Lance Janda, a military historian at Cameron University, told PolitiFact. \"He fought too, but only when he had to, and only against tribes or bands that just wouldn't negotiate with him.\"\n\nIn one series of campaigns between 1902 and 1903 around Lake Lanao on the southern island, Pershing would focus on more violent religious groups in fortified positions, allowing them room to escape, Linn said.\n\nPershing then bypassed other factions in the area to show he could easily move his forces around but would not deliberately attack, demonstrating to other tribes he understood which groups posed a threat.\n\nBut Pershing was also the commander of aggressive offensives that killed women and children after insurrectionists occupied positions with their families. Still, Pershing was made an honorary Moro chieftain, Linn said.\n\n[Van swerves into crowds in Barcelona's popular Las Ramblas district; 13 reported dead and scores injured]\n\nOther atrocities were committed by U.S. forces during the conflict. After a garrison of Army soldiers was overrun and massacred, a unit of Marines was dispatched in September 1902 to root out insurgents on the island of Samar on the central coast. Major Little Waller, who led the Marine unit, arrived from China and was unfamiliar with the terrain. Fever overtook him, his men panicked and the Filipino porters carrying his equipment mutinied.\n\nEleven porters were executed in a remote area, but news of the act quickly spread. \"Dead men tell no tales, but they leave an awful smell\" became a common American saying afterward, Linn said. Waller was later acquitted in a court-martial.\n\nBut the episode points to an example of what happens when news of deliberate killings spreads, Linn said, and if Pershing had committed a theatrical massacre, a similar result would have been likely.\n\nRise of the Pershing myth\n\nLinn began to encounter the Pershing pig blood bullet story after Sept. 11, 2001, when Internet users searched for religious-themed military operations in the wake of the terror attacks in the United States.\n\n\"It seemed to me to be coming from sources that were strongly anti-Muslim, not military historians or scholars,\" Linn said.\n\nConcerned faculty at the U.S. Military Academy asked him to disprove the story of arguably one of its most storied graduates. Pershing would later head the American Expeditionary Forces in World War I as Commander of the Armies, a rank only held by two generals in U.S. history -- Pershing and George Washington, who was posthumously awarded the rank in 1976.\n\nLinn told the U.S. Military Academy, along with fellow Texas A&M professor Frank Vandiver and author of Pershing's biography, that no evidence existed to back up the story.\n\n[Trump embraces culture war with call to preserve Confederate statues]\n\nStill, the myth persists with another twist of burying insurgents with dead pigs. In Pershing's memoir \"My Life Before the World War, 1860 -- 1917,\" he says fellow officer Col. Frank West told him at least one Muslim fighters was \"publicly buried in the same grave with a dead pig.\"\n\n\"It was not pleasant to have to take such measures, but the prospect of going to hell instead of heaven sometimes deterred the would-be assassins,\" Pershing wrote about juramentados, knife-wielding religious extremists who targeted Christians.\n\nLinn said it probably did happen at one point, but he doubts Pershing was involved or ordered subordinates to commit religiously insulting acts. Other artifacts, like letters and memoirs from soldiers there describing similar events, do not point to credible claims of Pershing's involvement, Linn said. A 1939 movie about the conflict starring Gary Cooper, \"The Real Glory,\" also includes a scene that resemble those moments and likely fuels the myth, the historian said.\n\nThe Philippine-American War ended in 1902, with the death of more than 4,200 American and 20,000 Filipino combatants. As many as 200,000 Filipino civilians died from violence and widespread famine and disease, according to the State Department. The Moro Insurrection continued for years.\n\nPershing served as governor of the mostly Muslim Moro Province from 1909 to 1913, as the rebellion festered. Pershing's decision to disarm the Moro in 1913 triggered more unrest, culminating in the Battle of Bud Bagsak in the south.\n\nPershing annihilated the Moro, but Trump's suggestion of a fabled mass execution leading to peace is incorrect, Linn said.\n\n\"There was still lawlessness, homicide and banditry\" that arguably continued for decades up to now, he said, as the government continues its brutal crackdown over drug traffickers and users.\n\nLost in Trump's falsehood, Linn said, is the distortion of an officer who dedicated his life to a certain code of conduct.\n\n\"It's a terrible defamation of the American soldier,\" Linn said. \"What does it say about Americans that they would take 50 people and shoot them? It's a major war crime.\"\n\nRead more:\n\nTrump equates Robert E. Lee with George Washington. The truth about Lee is he wasn't very good at his job\n\n'Assassins!': A Confederate spy was accused of helping kill Abraham Lincoln. {"timeCrawl": "10:31:00", "uri": "711385326", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T10:31:00Z", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "source": {"title": "The Sun", "uri": "thesun.co.uk", "id": "16"}, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/4269699/donald-trump-general-pershing-barcelona-attack-fake-story/", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "President Trump made reference to the mythical story in the wake of the Barcelona terror attack\n\nDONALD Trump quoted a FAKE story of a US general who \"executed Muslim terrorists with pigs' blood-soaked bullets\" after the Barcelona bloodbath.\n\nThe US President tweeted a message of support for the victims of the atrocity, saying he \"condemns the terror attack\" and \"will do whatever is necessary to help\".\n\nBut the message was followed up 45 minutes later with another, saying: \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nThe anecdote he is referring to is understood to be a myth about how General John Pershing executed dozens of Muslim terrorists in the Philippines with tainted ammunition during a guerrilla war in the early 1900s.\n\nThe story is understood to be a hoax spread by emails with no evidence it really occurred, according to rumour tracker Snopes.\n\nIt's not the first time Trump has made reference to the Pershing tale - according to MSNBC he told the story in South Carolina ahead of the state's Republican presidential primary in February 2016.\n\nHe said: \"He took fifty bullets, and he dipped them in pig's blood.\n\n\"And he had his men load his rifles and he lined up the fifty people, and they shot 49 of those people.\n\n\"And the fiftieth person he said 'You go back to your people and you tell them what happened.' And for 25 years there wasn't a problem, okay?\"\n\nTrump, getting to the \"moral\" of the story, concluded: \"We better start getting tough and we better start getting vigilant, and we better start using our heads or we're not gonna have a country, folks.\"\n\nHe appeared to take a similar stance yesterday as he told the people of Barcelona: \"Be tough & strong, we love you!\"\n\nBut social media users were quick to point out that the president had been promoting a \"lie\".\n\nPaula tweeted Trump directly: \"You are spreading a lie about a horrible, fictional account of history.\"\n\nAnother user said: \"So Trump yet again reveals that he thinks war crimes are acceptable\".\n\nDemocrat Ted Lieu said: \"@realDonaldTrump endorsing mass murder in his Pershing tweet is just to distract from negative stories about him endorsing Nazis.\"\n\nPresenter Jake Tapper tweeted: \"President Trump tells world to study lie about General Pershing\".\n\nAt least 13 people died and more than 100 people were injured in Barcelona on Thursday, making it the deadliest attack in Spain since the 2004 Madrid train bombs in which more than 190 people were killed.\n\nSince Trump's tweets, five terrorists were shot dead by police in the nearby seaside town of Cambrils in a second attack in Spain.\n\nThe men, wearing fake suicide vests, ploughed into pedestrians in an Audi A3, injuring six civilians including a police officer.\n\nIt came eight hours after a van hurtled through crowds in Las Ramblas, sending scores of people scattering, in an attack which was later claimed by ISIS.\n\nThree people have been arrested in connection with the attacks.\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May said she was \"sickened\" by the incident, while the Foreign Office said it was still trying There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\u00e2\u0080\u009d Trump tweeted, repeating an outright lie he first uttered on the campaign trail.\n\nTrump told the story of Gen. John Pershing \u00e2\u0080\" and his efforts to quell the Moro Rebellion \u00e2\u0080\" during the 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nSpanish authorities investigated Thursday\u00e2\u0080\u0099s incident as a terrorist attack, and the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) calimed responsibility for the violence.\n\nTrump repeated the Pershing lie after condemning the deadly attack in Barcelona, where a car ploughed down pedestrians in the bustling Las Ramblas district. At least 12 people were killed and dozens injured, many of them seriously.\n\nTrump also says in a statement on Twitter that the U.S. will do \u00e2\u0080\u009cwhatever is necessary to help.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Trump tells Spain: \u00e2\u0080\u009cBe tough & strong, we love you!\u00e2\u0080\u009d\n\nThe White House has said Trump \u00e2\u0080\" who is on a working vacation at his private golf club in New Jersey \u00e2\u0080\" is being updated on developments by chief of staff John Kelly.\n\nTrump\u00e2\u0080\u0099s wife, first lady Melania Trump, tweeted her {"timeCrawl": "21:33:00", "uri": "711125009", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:33:00Z", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "source": {"title": "outsidethebeltway.com", "uri": "outsidethebeltway.com", "id": "451"}, "url": "http://www.outsidethebeltway.com/once-again-trump-lies-and-the-truth-dies/#comment-2236966", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "As I noted in my post about today's terror attack in Spain, President Trump reacted to the tragedy fairly quickly after the incident was first reported. One of those posts on Twitter included this claim against General John Pershing, who for a time commanded American forces in The Phillippines in the years shortly after the United States took control over the island nation after its victory over Spain in the Spanish-American War:\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\nDuring the time that Trump is referring to, Pershing and the forces he commanded were forced to deal with pro-independence rebels who were resorting to attacks on the civilian population and on American targets in a war that had started when Spain still controlled the territory. This all took place at the turn of the 20th Century, a decade or more prior to the World War One, which is when Pershing would become nationally famous due to his leadership of the American expeditionary force that fought alongside the British and French against Germany and the remaining Central Powers until the war ended in November 1918.\n\nAccording to legends that appear to have started long after Pershing's death, and which started to become widely circulated among conservatives in the year after the September 11th attacks, Pershing dealt with these terror attacks, which were largely committed by groups that arose out of the Muslim population of The Phillippines, by ordering his troops to dip their bullets in pigs blood and to bury the bodies of executed terrorists with pigs, which is supposedly some sign of disrespect that was meant to horrify the terrorists. The legend goes on to claim that the terror attacks largely ceased after the groups committing them got wind of what Pershing was doing.\n\nAs it turns out, there is absolutely no historical evidence to substantiate this apparent myth:\n\nThe idea of subduing militant Muslims by threatening to bury them with pigs has held currency for many years. Just a few weeks before the September 11 terrorist attacks on America in 2001, Deputy Israeli police minister Gideon Esra suggested in the Israeli newspaper Yediot Aharonot that Palestinian suicide bombers be buried in pig skin or blood. In the 1939 film The Real Glory, Gary Cooper portrays Dr. Bill Canavan, an American Army doctor in 1906 Manila who \"tries to protect the native population from ruthless invaders\" (i.e., \"Muslim fanatics\"). At one point in the film, the Dr. Canavan character drapes a captured Muslim in a pigskin and proclaims that henceforth all slain Muslim rebels will be buried in pig skins, thereby discouraging their \"savagery\" by threatening to prevent their entry into paradise. And, of course, the above-cited anecdote about General Pershing's handling of terrorists in the Philippines has circulated widely on the Internet ever since 9/11 and even made the rounds at the top levels of U.S. government\n\n(...)\n\nSuffice it to say that General John J. \"Black Jack\" Pershing was part of the process as Governor of the troublesome Moro Province between 1909 and 1913. We found no references to this alleged incident in Pershing biographies, however, nor does it match the way Pershing is generally recorded as having dealt with the Moros in 1911. When they refused to obey Pershing's order banning firearms by surrendering their weapons, his response was to draft a letter to the Moros expressing sorrow that his soldiers had to resort to killing them to enforce the order:\n\nI write you this letter because I am sorry to know that you and your people refuse to do what the government has ordered. You do not give up your arms. Soldiers were sent to Taglibi so that you could come into camp and turn in your guns. When the soldiers went to camp a Taglibi, your Moros fired into camp and tried to kill the soldiers. Then the soldiers had to shoot all Moros who fired upon them. When the soldiers marched through the country, the Moros again shot at them, so the soldiers had to kill several others. I am sorry the soldiers had to kill any Moros. All Moros are the same to me as my children and no father wants to kill his own children ...\n\nWhen negotiations stalled and matters came to a head, Pershing was still reluctant to be responsible for any more loss of life than was necessary:\n\n[Pershing] went to his offices on [14 December 1911] only to hear a message from the Sulu district governor: hundreds of hostiles gathered on Jolo's Bud Dajo! The message had dread portent. Mount Dajo, awesomely high and capped with the creater of an extinct volcano, meant sacred things to Moros. It was the refuge against fate, the last bastion of the hopeless, the place where their ancestors stood off great waves of enemies. Once on the mountain, esconced in its big cotta, Moros would die gladly, as Leonard Wood had grimly learned. Retreat to Dajo meant a clear declaration of war.\n\nSobered and depressed, Jack wrote of an overriding worry: \"I am sorry these Moros are such fools, but ... I shall lose as few men and kill as few Moros as possible.\" Memories of Wood's massacre of men and families on Dajo rankled in the army and still bothered the chief of staff. Obviously another such slaughter in the winter of 1911 could adversely influence the 1912 elections in the States.\n\nPershing's strategy was to surround the Moros and wait them out while attempting to induce them to surrender, a strategy that worked effectively: the Bud Dajo campaign ended with only twelve Moro casualties. But in his report Pershing seemed keenly aware that the best approach was not to take any action that would encourage religious fanaticism:\n\nThere was never a moment during this investment of Bud Dajo when the Moros, including women, on top of the mountain, would not have fought to the death had they been given the opportunity. They had gone there to make a last stand on this, their sacred mountain, and they were determined to die fighting ... It was only by the greatest effort that their solid determination to fight it out could be broken. The fact is that they were completely surprised at the prompt and decisive action of the troops in cutting off supplies and preventing escape, and they were chagrined and disappointed in that they were not encouraged to die the death of Mohammedan fanatics.\n\nThe Snopes article linked above does go on to note that there were some contemporaneous reports that at least part of the legend may be accurate in that some Moro rebels were buried with pigs and Pershing was apparently aware of this practice via reports from junior officers. However, there is absolutely no evidence that the practice had any impact at all on the attacks by the rebels, or that there was even any correlation between the practice and the eventual reduction in terror attacks that was apparent by the time Pershing left The Phillippines in 1913. Instead, that drop off appears to be related to a combination of efforts to resolve the rebellion by peaceful means and simply the fact that many of the rebels gave up their fight as the reality of American rule over the islands, which was at least far less severe than the way Spain treated the native population, sank in during the decade after the Spanish-American War ended.\n\nThis isn't the first time that Trump has made this claim, of course. He cited the legend several times during the course of his campaign, prompting historian William Lambers to look into the matter and concludes that there was no merit to Trump's claims:\n\nDuring a campaign rally in South Carolina, [Donald] Trump told his audience a story about General John Pershing executing Muslim prisoners in the Philippines. Trump said Pershing, in the early 1900's, \"caught 50 terrorists that did tremendous damage and killed many people and he took the 50 terrorists and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pig's blood.\"\n\nTrump went out to describe a mass execution shooting of 49 of the prisoners, with the last one being sent to tell the others what happened. It was Trump using this \"story\" to demonstrate that America needed to get tough on terrorism, using brutal methods, and that he would be the man to do it.\n\nBut the story is not true. There was no mass execution led by Pershing. That is a rumor created on the Internet.\n\nA Chicago Daily Tribune article from 1927 has a story where Pershing had prisoners from the Moro Rebellion in the Philippines. The Moros were Muslims who resisted American or any other occupying force.\n\nThe Moros had swordsmen, called Juramentados, who were killing Christians in this uprising. It had to be stopped. General Pershing was given this difficult task.\n\nThe Tribune article says Pershing sprinkled some prisoners with pig's blood, which the Juramentados believed would condemn them for eternity. But then Pershing let the prisoners go. He issued a warning to others about being sprinkled with the pig's blood. The Tribune article said \"those drops of porcine gore proved more powerful than bullets.\"\n\nThere were no executions as described by Trump.\n\nIn fact, Pershing was more inclined toward peace talks with the Moros rather than violence.\n\n(...)\n\nIf Pershing were around today he would be advocating food for the hungry child refugees, which are at unprecedented levels today because of the war in Syria. They never talk about hunger during the presidential debates, but it's a top foreign policy issue, which Pershing and other great leaders have understood. Pershing was also deeply concerned about high levels of military spending. He often spoke about achieving global arms reductions and disarmament. Nations could work together to achieve this noble goal.\n\nAs a man who understood more about warfare than perhaps anyone in our country's history, Pershing knew well the danger of excessive armament. He might have some questions for Trump or others who talk about pouring on the military spending.\n\nBut instead of trying to learn from Pershing, Trump cites a false story in an attempt to sound tough and get a sound bite on TV. The last thing this world needs is more people talking or advocating violence, especially someone running for President.\n\nJake Tapper also talked about Trump's lie in its report on the terror attacks:\n\nSo, once again, Trump is telling a lie, and he's insulting the memory of one of most decorated Generals and war heroes in the process. Not that he cares about the truth, of course.", "id": "9780788", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Once Again, Trump Lies And The Truth Dies", "image": Cooper"}, "id": "482873", "score": 3, "type": "person", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Cooper"}, {"label": {"eng": "John J. Pershing"}, "id": "486790", "score": 5, "type": "person", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_J._Pershing"}, {"location": null, "score": 3, "id": "509610", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Powers", "label": {"eng": "Central Powers"}, "type": "loc"}, {"label": {"eng": "Leonard Wood"}, "id": "851074", "score": 2, "type": "person", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leonard_Wood"}], "location": null, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 286, "label": "dmoz/Society/History/By Time Period", "uri": "dmoz/Society/History/By_Time_Period"}], "time": "21:33:00"}
{"timeCrawl": "02:08:00", "uri": "711208232", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T02:08:00Z", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "source": {"title": "outsidethebeltway.com", "uri": "outsidethebeltway.com", "id": "451"}, "url": "http://www.outsidethebeltway.com/once-again-trump-lies-and-the-truth-dies/#comment-2237063", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "As I noted in my post about today's terror attack in Spain, President Trump reacted to the tragedy fairly quickly after the incident was first reported. One of those posts on Twitter included this claim against General John Pershing, who for a time commanded American forces in The Phillippines in the years shortly after the United States took control over the island nation after its victory over Spain in the Spanish-American War:\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\nDuring the time that Trump is referring to, Pershing and the forces he commanded were forced to deal with pro-independence rebels who were resorting to attacks on the civilian population and on American targets in a war that had started when Spain still controlled the territory. This all took place at the turn of the 20th Century, a decade or more prior to the World War One, which is when Pershing would become nationally famous due to his leadership of the American expeditionary force that fought alongside the British and French against Germany and the remaining Central Powers until the war ended in November 1918.\n\nAccording to legends that appear to have started long after Pershing's death, and which started to become widely circulated among conservatives in the year after the September 11th attacks, Pershing dealt with these terror attacks, which were largely committed by groups that arose out of the Muslim population of The Phillippines, by ordering his troops to dip their bullets in pigs blood and to bury the bodies of executed terrorists with pigs, which is supposedly some sign of disrespect that was meant to horrify the terrorists. The legend goes on to claim that the terror attacks largely ceased after the groups committing them got wind of what Pershing was doing.\n\nAs it turns out, there is absolutely no historical evidence to substantiate this apparent myth:\n\nThe idea of subduing militant Muslims by threatening to bury them with pigs has held currency for many years. Just a few weeks before the September 11 terrorist attacks on America in 2001, Deputy Israeli police minister Gideon Esra suggested in the Israeli newspaper Yediot Aharonot that Palestinian suicide bombers be buried in pig skin or blood. In the 1939 film The Real Glory, Gary Cooper portrays Dr. Bill Canavan, an American Army doctor in 1906 Manila who \"tries to protect the native population from ruthless invaders\" (i.e., \"Muslim fanatics\"). At one point in the film, the Dr. Canavan character drapes a captured Muslim in a pigskin and proclaims that henceforth all slain Muslim rebels will be buried in pig skins, thereby discouraging their \"savagery\" by threatening to prevent their entry into paradise. And, of course, the above-cited anecdote about General Pershing's handling of terrorists in the Philippines has circulated widely on the Internet ever since 9/11 and even made the rounds at the top levels of U.S. government\n\n(...)\n\nSuffice it to say that General John J. \"Black Jack\" Pershing was part of the process as Governor of the troublesome Moro Province between 1909 and 1913. We found no references to this alleged incident in Pershing biographies, however, nor does it match the way Pershing is generally recorded as having dealt with the Moros in 1911. When they refused to obey Pershing's order banning firearms by surrendering their weapons, his response was to draft a letter to the Moros expressing sorrow that his soldiers had to resort to killing them to enforce the order:\n\nI write you this letter because I am sorry to know that you and your people refuse to do what the government has ordered. You do not give up your arms. Soldiers were sent to Taglibi so that you could come into camp and turn in your guns. When the soldiers went to camp a Taglibi, your Moros fired into camp and tried to kill the soldiers. Then the soldiers had to shoot all Moros who fired upon them. When the soldiers marched through the country, the Moros again shot at them, so the soldiers had to kill several others. I am sorry the soldiers had to kill any Moros. All Moros are the same to me as my children and no father wants to kill his own children ...\n\nWhen negotiations stalled and matters came to a head, Pershing was still reluctant to be responsible for any more loss of life than was necessary:\n\n[Pershing] went to his offices on [14 December 1911] only to hear a message from the Sulu district governor: hundreds of hostiles gathered on Jolo's Bud Dajo! The message had dread portent. Mount Dajo, awesomely high and capped with the creater of an extinct volcano, meant sacred things to Moros. It was the refuge against fate, the last bastion of the hopeless, the place where their ancestors stood off great waves of enemies. Once on the mountain, esconced in its big cotta, Moros would die gladly, as Leonard Wood had grimly learned. Retreat to Dajo meant a clear declaration of war.\n\nSobered and depressed, Jack wrote of an overriding worry: \"I am sorry these Moros are such fools, but ... I shall lose as few men and kill as few Moros as possible.\" Memories of Wood's massacre of men and families on Dajo rankled in the army and still bothered the chief of staff. Obviously another such slaughter in the winter of 1911 could adversely influence the 1912 elections in the States.\n\nPershing's strategy was to surround the Moros and wait them out while attempting to induce them to surrender, a strategy that worked effectively: the Bud Dajo campaign ended with only twelve Moro casualties. But in his report Pershing seemed keenly aware that the best approach was not to take any action that would encourage religious fanaticism:\n\nThere was never a moment during this investment of Bud Dajo when the Moros, including women, on top of the mountain, would not have fought to the death had they been given the opportunity. They had gone there to make a last stand on this, their sacred mountain, and they were determined to die fighting ... It was only by the greatest effort that their solid determination to fight it out could be broken. The fact is that they were completely surprised at the prompt and decisive action of the troops in cutting off supplies and preventing escape, and they were chagrined and disappointed in that they were not encouraged to die the death of Mohammedan fanatics.\n\nThe Snopes article linked above does go on to note that there were some contemporaneous reports that at least part of the legend may be accurate in that some Moro rebels were buried with pigs and Pershing was apparently aware of this practice via reports from junior officers. However, there is absolutely no evidence that the practice had any impact at all on the attacks by the rebels, or that there was even any correlation between the practice and the eventual reduction in terror attacks that was apparent by the time Pershing left The Phillippines in 1913. Instead, that drop off appears to be related to a combination of efforts to resolve the rebellion by peaceful means and simply the fact that many of the rebels gave up their fight as the reality of American rule over the islands, which was at least far less severe than the way Spain treated the native population, sank in during the decade after the Spanish-American War ended.\n\nThis isn't the first time that Trump has made this claim, of course. He cited the legend several times during the course of his campaign, prompting historian William Lambers to look into the matter and concludes that there was no merit to Trump's claims:\n\nDuring a campaign rally in South Carolina, [Donald] Trump told his audience a story about General John Pershing executing Muslim prisoners in the Philippines. Trump said Pershing, in the early 1900's, \"caught 50 terrorists that did tremendous damage and killed many people and he took the 50 terrorists and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pig's blood.\"\n\nTrump went out to describe a mass execution shooting of 49 of the prisoners, with the last one being sent to tell the others what happened. It was Trump using this \"story\" to demonstrate that America needed to get tough on terrorism, using brutal methods, and that he would be the man to do it.\n\nBut the story is not true. There was no mass execution led by Pershing. That is a rumor created on the Internet.\n\nA Chicago Daily Tribune article from 1927 has a story where Pershing had prisoners from the Moro Rebellion in the Philippines. The Moros were Muslims who resisted American or any other occupying force.\n\nThe Moros had swordsmen, called Juramentados, who were killing Christians in this uprising. It had to be stopped. General Pershing was given this difficult task.\n\nThe Tribune article says Pershing sprinkled some prisoners with pig's blood, which the Juramentados believed would condemn them for eternity. But then Pershing let the prisoners go. He issued a warning to others about being sprinkled with the pig's blood. The Tribune article said \"those drops of porcine gore proved more powerful than bullets.\"\n\nThere were no executions as described by Trump.\n\nIn fact, Pershing was more inclined toward peace talks with the Moros rather than violence.\n\n(...)\n\nIf Pershing were around today he would be advocating food for the hungry child refugees, which are at unprecedented levels today because of the war in Syria. They never talk about hunger during the presidential debates, but it's a top foreign policy issue, which Pershing and other great leaders have understood. Pershing was also deeply concerned about high levels of military spending. He often spoke about achieving global arms reductions and disarmament. Nations could work together to achieve this noble goal.\n\nAs a man who understood more about warfare than perhaps anyone in our country's history, Pershing knew well the danger of excessive armament. He might have some questions for Trump or others who talk about pouring on the military spending.\n\nBut instead of trying to learn from Pershing, Trump cites a false story in an attempt to sound tough and get a sound bite on TV. The last thing this world needs is more people talking or advocating violence, especially someone running for President.\n\nJake Tapper also talked about Trump's lie in its report on the terror attacks:\n\nSo, once again, Trump is telling a lie, and he's insulting the memory of one of most decorated Generals and war heroes in the process. Not that he cares about the truth, of course.\n\nUpdate: The New York Times fact checked the story, and similarly found it implausible given the available evidence:\n\nVarious versions of this myth began circulating around the time of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, often in email chains and on discussion boards online. In one version, Pershing also buried the rebels with \"hog guts dumped atop the bodies.\" And in another, in a column published in National Review in December 2002, a few months before the invasion of Iraq, the act was attributed to unnamed troops under Pershing's command.\n\n\"This is a repeated myth that has no basis in truth,\" said James R. Arnold, the author of \"Moro War: How America Battled a Muslim Insurgency in the Philippine Jungle, 1902-1913.\"\n\nMr. Arnold's view was echoed by eight other historians who were interviewed by PolitiFact when Mr. Trump made his original claim. (It earned him the website's lowest rating, \"Pants on Fire.\")\n\nFurther dispelling this event and the suggestion that it was highly effective and ushered in an enduring peace is its dubious timeline. Most versions of the tale say the episode occurred around 1911, but the Moro Rebellion officially lasted another two years. After 1913, Americans back home lost interest and United States troops withdrew.\n\nStudying Pershing's historically documented actions during the Moro Rebellion -- generally \"a carrots and stick\" approach, Mr. Arnold said -- confers no silver bullets on how to approach terrorism.\n\nPershing \"understood the imperative of having American forces involved at the grass-roots level,\" wrote Col. Robert M. Cassidy of the Army, a professor of strategy and policy at the U.S. Naval War College. But Pershing could also be brutal, killing women and children in one large battle, for instance.\n\nTo the extent that the Americans \"won\" over the rebels, Mr. Arnold attributes that to an outsize battle: The Moros had no outside support, were insulated on an island and were outgunned.\n\nAnd, as noted above, Politifact also examined the claim when Trump made it on the campaign trail:\n\nhe idea that pig's blood could serve as a weapon against Muslims has been around in popular culture for decades.\n\nFor instance, a 1939 Hollywood movie, The Real Glory, stars Gary Cooper as a doctor on the Philippine island of Mindanao who drapes a captive in pigskin \"to serve as an abject lesson to all would-be attackers,\" Luis H. Francia, a Filipino-born professor of Asian American Studies at Hunter College, wrote recently.\n\nSnopes has been tracking Internet-based rumors of this sort since 2001, and a California National Guard facility removed a poster telling the Pershing story in 2005.\n\nBut the only historical evidence that something like this actually happened appears to come from a letter written by a soldier who served in the Philippines.\n\n\"Mr. C.C. Booth of Dallas, Texas, who served in Mindanao under Pershing, recalls seeing him hang a Moro chieftain by the heels over an open grave, kill a pig, and then drop the Moro into the grave with the bloody animal,\" according to a 1962 article by Donald Smythe in the Pacific Historical Review, an academic journal.\n\nHowever, David J. Silbey, a Cornell University historian and author of A War of Frontier and Empire: The Philippine-American War, 1899-1902, raised red flags about its sourcing. This claim came from one letter -- and one that was written in 1960, more than half a century after the events in question. (And for the sake of this fact-check, the details differ significantly from the story Trump told.)\n\nOther historians agreed that the evidence is thin, to say the least.\n\n\"This story is a fabrication and has long been discredited,\" said Brian McAllister Linn, a Texas A&M University historian and author of Guardians of Empire: The U.S. Army and the Pacific, 1902-1940. \"I am amazed it is still making the rounds.\"\n\nChristopher Einolf, a professor at DePaul University and author of America in the Philippines, 1899-1902: The First Torture Scandal, added that he trusted the conclusion of the late military historian Frank E. Vandiver, who told About.com in 2003 that \"I never found any indication that it was true in extensive research on his Moro experiences. This kind of thing would have run completely against his character.\"\n\nIndeed, other historians noted that Pershing pursued a less brutal approach to \"pacifying\" the rebels in the southern Philippines than Leonard Wood, one of his predecessors.\n\n\"He did a lot of what we would call 'winning hearts and minds' and embraced reforms which helped end their resistance,\" said Lance Janda, a military historian at Cameron University. \"He fought too, but only when he had to, and only against tribes or bands that just wouldn't negotiate with him. He wasn't solely committed to fighting as people like Trump who tell the pig blood story imply.\"\n\nAnother wrinkle: Historians said the premise that the rebels would have been motivated by a fear of pigs is not as certain as Trump suggests. It's unclear how religiously observant the insurgents were and whether such a policy would have made a difference in their actions.\n\n\"The Moros were fighting for a lot of reasons, not just because they were Muslims,\" Janda said. \"This is another fact that gets lost in many modern discussions of terrorism.\"\n\nThe site also notes that, in the end, it was effectively an edict from the Sultain of the Ottoman Empire that persuaded the Moro rebels to lay down their arms:\n\n\"Even if the tale is true, the pacifying effect that Trump claims is nonsense,\" said Michael H. Hunt, an emeritus historian at the University of North Carolina and author of Arc of Empire: America's Wars in Asia from the Philippines to Vietnam. The region \"remained in constant unrest during the period of American rule and into the period of independence, right down to the present.\"\n\nSilbey of Cornell agreed. \"Where Trump's remark becomes ridiculous is in the idea that this actually worked,\" he said. \"The Moro War did not end until 1913, and even that's a bit of a soft date, with violence continuing for quite a while afterward. Defilement by pig's blood isn't -- and wasn't -- some magical method of ending terrorism.\"\n\nIf anything, a more complete account of the Moro insurgency involves some subplots that run contrary to Trump's narrative.\n\n\"The Ottomans under Sultan Abdul Hamid II sent a letter to the Sulu Moros asking them not to resist the Americans at the start of the Moro Rebellion, and the Moros on Sulu complied,\" Janda said. \"It's a nice example of diplomacy working to our advantage, and a reminder that then and now, not all Muslims or Moros are the same and that many were and are U.S. allies.\"\n\nAs John Adams once put it, facts are stubborn images.", "id": "9808783", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", "title": "Once Again, Trump Lies And The Truth Dies", "image": {"timeCrawl": "09:36:00", "uri": "711361746", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:45:00Z", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "source": {"title": "Talk Media News", "uri": "talkmedianews.com", "id": "18955"}, "url": "http://www.talkmedianews.com/featured/2017/08/17/trump-condemns-barcelona-terror-attack/", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "WASHINGTON - President Donald Trump condemned the attack Thursday in Barcelona by Twitter, calling it a terror attack and offering Spain any support that the U.S. can lend.\n\nEarlier in the day a van drove into a pedestrian area in Barcelona's historic Las Ramblas district, leaving at least 12 people dead and more than 80 injured. Law enforcement in Barcelona labeled the incident an act of terrorism, and ISIS later claimed responsibility.\n\nThe United States condemns the terror attack in Barcelona, Spain, and will do whatever is necessary to help. Be tough & strong, we love you!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\nObservers though were quick to point out that Trump just two days ago, while explaining his muted response to the violence in Charlottesville, Va., said that he prefers to wait for the facts before talking about attacks.\n\n\"I didn't wait long. I wanted to make sure, unlike most politicians, that what I said was correct. Not make a quick statement,\" Trump said.\n\nTrump later tweeted out support for a legend about U.S. General John Pershing, who the story goes in the turn of the 20th century successfully discouraged Islamist terrorists in the Philippines by killing them and burying their bodies along with those of pigs.\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\nTrump while campaigning for the Presidency in February of last year gave his own twist to the legend.\n\n\"He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? First, President Trump tweeted support for Spain saying the U.S. condemns the terror attack. Then a second curious message referenced the late U.S. Army Gen. John J. Pershing.\n\nBefore Pershing rose to fame in World War I, he was a governor in the Philippines, a U.S. territory at the time facing a Muslim revolt in the early 1900s.\n\nFrom the President: \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. All were skeptical that these events ever happened.\n\n\"There is no evidence that Pershing himself committed these acts, there is nothing said about the use of 50 bullets dipped in pig's blood, and {"timeCrawl": "20:21:00", "uri": "711098237", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:10:00Z", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "source": {"title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com", "id": "260"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/aug/17/donald-trump-barcelona-reaction-general-pershing-myth", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "In responding more quickly than with Charlottesville, president cites fictitious story of general dipping bullets in pig's blood before execution of Islamic soldiers\n\nDonald Trump responded to the Barcelona attack by reviving an already debunked anecdote about a US general dipping bullets in pig's blood to fight Islamic militants over a hundred years ago.\n\nAfter a relatively conventional response to the attack in which he went on to Twitter to call on the people of Barcelona to be \"tough and strong\" and offer US help, he posted another, more cryptic, tweet, saying: \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nThe tweet echoed a highly controversial claim Trump made at an election rally in South Carolina in February 2016, in which he talked admiringly about a counter-insurgency in the Philippines conducted by Gen John Pershing between 1909 and 1913, when he was governor of Moro province.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems just like we do. And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men, and he dipped 50 bullets in pig's blood,\" Trump said.\n\nHe claimed that Pershing then \"had his men load his rifles and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: you go back to your people and you tell them what happened.\"\n\nIn 2016, Trump claimed such mass executions ended the Islamic insurgency for a quarter-century. \"Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem,\" he said. In his new tweet he revised that estimated upward to 35 years.\n\nThis account of Pershing's actions has circulated on the internet since 2001 but historians say there is very little if any evidence to support it, and Trump was denounced for his support of mass killing aggravated by racist insults. But the outburst solidified his support among the US far right, and did nothing to impede his victory in the Republican primaries and then the election last November. Trump appears to have had domestic politics in mind when he sent out his tweet in response to the Barcelona attack.\n\nHis relationship with that section of his support has come under renewed scrutiny since the attack on a crowd in Charlottesville, Virginia, by a white supremacist on Saturday. It took him two days to assign blame directly on the far right, only to contradict himself the next day with a claim that \"both sides\" were to blame for the incident.\n\nTrump was much faster in pointing the finger of blame in the wake of Barcelona, but his erratic response echoed the controversy over Charlottesville, in which conventional political language, apparently drafted by aides, has alternated with a personal gut reaction that has had an explosive and divisive effect.\n\nThe French president, Emmanuel Macron, appeared to take on Trump in his Twitter reaction to the Barcelona attack. An initial tweet offered solidarity for the victims of and the pledge: \"We remain united and determined.\" But in a follow-up, Macron - who has repeatedly acted as a foil to Trump on the world stage - said: \"We stand beside those who fight racism and xenophobia. It is our common fight, in past and present.\" He added the hashtag: #Charlottesville.\n\nBefore Trump took to Twitter, the US secretary of state, Rex Tillerson, said the administration stood ready to help Spanish law enforcement and national authorities and advised Americans in Spain to call home to reassure relatives.\n\n\"Terrorists around the world should know that the United States and our allies are resolved to find you and bring you to justice,\" Tillerson said.\n\nIn the UK, Theresa May, said: \"My thoughts are with the victims of today's terrible attack in Barcelona and the emergency services responding to this ongoing incident.\n\n\"The UK stands with Spain against terror,\" she added.\n\nThe UK foreign secretary, Boris Johnson said he was \"concerned and saddened\" by the attack and said the foreign office was \"doing all we can to identify whether Brits need help\".\n\nSadiq Khan, the London mayor who has had had to handle a string of recent terrorist attacks in Westminster, London Bridge and Finsbury Park, wrote on Twitter: \"\"My thoughts are with the victims of this barbaric terrorist attack in the great city of Barcelona and with their brave emergency services.\n\n\"London stands with Barcelona against the evil of terrorism.\"\n\nThe Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, tweeted about the \"terrible reports from Barcelona\", saying: \"My thoughts are with those killed and injured, and the emergency services working to save lives.\"\n\nAnd the German foreign minister, Sigmar Gabriel, said he was \"deeply shocked\" by the incident. {"timeCrawl": "00:09:00", "uri": "711174797", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:09:00Z", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "source": {"title": "The New Zealand Herald", "uri": "nzherald.co.nz", "id": "1424"}, "url": "http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=11906556", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "Hours after an apparent terrorist attack in Barcelona, President Trump on Thursday recycled a largely discredited Internet tale that he promoted on the campaign trail as a way to call attention to what he has called \"radical Islamic terrorism.\"\n\nIn a Twitter message, Trump instructed his 36 million followers to look to the example of Gen. John J. Pershing, who is said, in stories circulating online, to have dipped bullets in pigs' blood to execute Islamic terrorists in the Philippines whose religion forbid contact with the animals.\n\nThe story has been found to be unsubstantiated by numerous fact-checkers in the media. But Trump first told the story during a campaign rally in February 2016, as he defended his position of supporting methods of torture, such as waterboarding, on terrorist suspects.\n\nTrump's tweet came hours after a man in Barcelona drove a van at high speeds into a crowd at a popular tourist destination, killing 12 and injuring 50 more, according to local police who are calling the attack an act of terrorism. One man is reportedly in custody in the investigation.\n\nTrump also tweeted message of support for the victims, in which he said the United States \"condemns the terror attack.\"\n\nThe message stood in sharp contrast to Trump's reaction Saturday to an attack in Charlottesville, when a man drove a car into a group of people protesting a white nationalist rally, killing a woman and injuring 19 others. An alleged Nazi sympathizer who had attended the rally is charged with second-degree murder in the case.\n\nAfter than incident, Trump blamed the actions of people \"on many sides\" of the violent clashes.\n\nThough he denounced the white supremacist hate groups directly two days later, Trump then reversed course and again blamed \"both sides\" on Tuesday, prompting a widespread political backlash. The president on Tuesday explained that his initial reaction had been muted because he did not have all the \"facts\" in the case and wanted to be cautious.\n\nIn his February recitation of the Pershing story, Trump told a crowd of supporters that the general was having trouble dealing with terrorist attacks and caught 50 suspects.\n\n\"He took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pigs' blood - you heard that, right? He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood,\" Trump continued. \"And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened. And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nAt one point in telling this story, Trump said: \"By the way, this is something you can read in the history books - not a lot of history books because they don't like teaching this.\"\n\nAlthough Trump never used the word \"Muslim\" in this story, he was clearly referring to Muslim terrorists and at one point commented: \"There's a whole thing with swine and animals and pigs, and - you know the story, you know they don't like that.\" Pigs are deemed impure by the Koran.\n\nThere are several versions of the tale circulating, including one in which the prisoners were buried with dead pigs. The pigs' blood on the bullets, according to at least one version, would keep a Muslim from entering heaven.\n\nThe Council on American-Islamic Relations denounced Trump's remarks last year in a There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\n\n-- Donald J. {"timeCrawl": "22:06:00", "uri": "711136745", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:06:00Z", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "source": {"title": "TheJournal.ie", "uri": "thejournal.ie", "id": "979"}, "url": "http://www.thejournal.ie/trump-barcelona-3551833-Aug2017/", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "US PRESIDENT DONALD Donald Trump appeared to endorse the idea of mass executions for Islamist extremists, as he alluded to a widely debunked account of summary punishment by a US general in the Philippines in the early 1900s.\n\nIt was another provocative tweet from an increasingly isolated leader who uses Twitter to take shots at perceived opponents - and even announce big policy changes.\n\nThe tweet also suggested Trump actually believes a story that many historians say is apocryphal.\n\nTrump first sent out a tweet offering aid to Spain after the van attack in Barcelona that left at least 13 dead and more than 50 wounded.\n\nAbout an hour later, Trump tweeted:\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\n\nSource: Donald J. Trump/Twitter\n\nHe was referring to General John \"Black Jack\" Pershing who was the US governor of largely Muslim Moro province from 1909 to 1913.\n\nAt the time, the Philippines was a US colony. And Pershing's forces had to fight Muslim counterinsurgencies.\n\nThe debunked account - which Trump has referred to in the past - is as follows:\n\nPershing's forces rounded up 50 Muslim insurgents and executed 49 of them with bullets dipped in pig's blood - considered by Muslims to be unholy.\n\n\"You heard that, right?\" Trump said as a candidate during a rally in February 2016 in South Carolina, alluding to the pig blood part.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Trump said.\n\nAs the story goes, the 50th prisoner was released to tell his fellow fighters about what the Americans had done.\n\n\"And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem,\" Trump said.\n\nHistorians have expressed skepticism or outright denial that this event took place.\n\nAccording to the fact checking website Politifact, the late military historian Frank Vandiver said in 2003, referring to Pershing:\n\nI never found any indication that it was true in extensive research on his Moro experiences. This kind of thing would have run completely against his character.\n\nPolitifact quoted four historians who denied the account.\n\nTrump endorsed waterboarding - widely held now to be a torture technique, used during the George W. Bush administration in its war on terror and halted by Barack Obama - during the presidential campaign.\n\nOnce in office, however, after US generals advised him against reverting to waterboarding, with some saying torture simply did not work as a way to extract information, Trump said he would yield to them.\n\nAnd he stopped making public endorsements of the technique.\n\n- \u00a9 AFP {"timeCrawl": "01:41:00", "uri": "711200216", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T17:14:00Z", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "source": {"title": "Vox", "uri": "vox.com", "id": "5790"}, "url": "https://www.vox.com/2017/8/17/16163746/trump-pershing-tweet", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "After he struggled to condemn a white supremacist terrorist attack in the United States, reluctantly condemned it, and then pivoted back to the idea that not every participant in a neo-Nazi rally that ended with a woman's murder was necessarily bad, a deadly terrorist attack in Barcelona offered President Trump the more comfortable terrain of talking about Islamic terrorism.\n\nSpecifically, he suggested on Twitter that the long-dead American Gen. John Pershing has the fix that the world needs today.\n\nThis is a reference to a story Trump has told in the past about efforts undertaken by the United States to subdue an insurgency in the Philippines. The United States took control of the islands after a brief war with Spain in 1898, and then fought a three-year war against the locals to secure control over it. But localized unrest continued in some areas, and Pershing served as governor of Moro Province, which is predominantly Muslim, between 1909 and 1913 before going on to his better-known career as the leader of American military forces in World War I.\n\nAt a February 19, 2016, rally in South Carolina, Trump offered this account:\n\nThey were having terrorism problems, just like we do. And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pigs' blood -- you heard that, right? He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened. And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem.\n\nAfter Trump told this story, Louis Jacobson of PolitiFact looked into it with eight historians, all of whom were deeply skeptical that it ever happened. The notion that pig's blood was used as an anti-Muslim weapon appears to derive from a 1939 Gary Cooper movie and a single letter written in 1960.\n\nAnd of course while observant Muslims avoid eating pork products, they're not vampires who can only be killed by special bullets. There's no precept of Muslim doctrine that would suggest being shot at with pig blood-soaked bullets would imperil one's immortal soul. In the bigger picture, unrest in the Philippines didn't actually taper off while Pershing was governor -- let alone stop for 25 years. Plus, you can't execute suicide attackers anyway.\n\nSo while the story seems to appeal to Trump's predilection for the grotesque -- and appears to revive the direct advocacy of torture and war crimes that were a hallmark of his presidential campaign -- all indications are that it's false and completely nonsensical.", "id": "9805980", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Trump calls for {"timeCrawl": "21:21:00", "uri": "711119881", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:21:00Z", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4800786/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "President Donald Trump appears to have embraced as true a widely debunked account of US forces executing Muslim rebels in the Philippines in the early 1900s with bullets dipped in pig blood\n\nPresident Donald Trump appeared Thursday to endorse the idea of mass executions for Islamist extremists, as he alluded to a widely debunked account of summary punishment by a US general in the Philippines in the early 1900s.\n\nIt was another provocative tweet from an increasingly isolated leader who uses Twitter to take shots at perceived opponents -- and even announce big policy changes.\n\nThursday's tweet also suggested Trump actually believes a story that many historians say is apocryphal.\n\nTrump first sent out a tweet offering aid to Spain after Thursday's van attack in Barcelona that left at least 13 dead and more than 50 wounded.\n\nAbout an hour later, Trump tweeted: \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nHe was referring to General John \"Black Jack\" Pershing who was the US governor of largely Muslim Moro province from 1909 to 1913.\n\nAt the time, the Philippines was a US colony. And Pershing's forces had to fight Muslim counterinsurgencies.\n\nThe debunked account -- which Trump has referred to in the past -- is as follows: Pershing's forces rounded up 50 Muslim insurgents and executed 49 of them with bullets dipped in pig's blood -- considered by Muslims to be unholy.\n\n\"You heard that, right?\" Trump said as a candidate during a rally in February 2016 in South Carolina, alluding to the pig blood part.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Trump said.\n\nAs the story goes, the 50th prisoner was released to tell his fellow fighters about what the Americans had done.\n\n\"And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Bush administration in its war on terror and halted by Barack Obama -- during the presidential campaign.\n\nOnce in office, however, after US generals advised him against reverting to waterboarding, {"timeCrawl": "22:41:00", "uri": "711148016", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:41:00Z", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "source": {"title": "The Business Times", "uri": "businesstimes.com.sg", "id": "10474"}, "url": "http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/government-economy/trump-again-cites-dubious-muslim-execution-story-after-spain-attack", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "[WASHINGTON] President Donald Trump appeared Thursday to endorse the idea of mass executions for Islamist extremists, as he alluded to a widely debunked account of summary punishment by a US general in the Philippines in the early 1900s.\n\nIt was another provocative tweet from an increasingly isolated leader who uses Twitter to take shots at perceived opponents - and even announce big policy changes.\n\nThursday's tweet also suggested Mr Trump actually believes a story that many historians say is apocryphal.\n\nMr Trump first sent out a tweet offering aid to Spain after Thursday's van attack in Barcelona that left at least 13 dead and more than 50 wounded.\n\nAbout an hour later, Mr Trump tweeted: \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\" He was referring to General John \"Black Jack\" Pershing who was the US governor of largely Muslim Moro province from 1909 to 1913.\n\nAt the time, the Philippines was a US colony. And Mr Pershing's forces had to fight Muslim counterinsurgencies.\n\nThe debunked account - which Mr Trump has referred to in the past - is as follows: Mr Pershing's forces rounded up 50 Muslim insurgents and executed 49 of them with bullets dipped in pig's blood - considered by Muslims to be unholy.\n\n\"You heard that, right?\" Mr Trump said as a candidate during a rally in February 2016 in South Carolina, alluding to the pig blood part.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Mr Trump said.\n\nAs the story goes, the 50th prisoner was released to tell his fellow fighters about what the Americans had done.\n\n\"And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem,\" Mr Trump said.\n\nHistorians have expressed skepticism or outright denial that this event took place.\n\nAccording to the fact checking website Politifact, the late military historian Frank Vandiver said in 2003, referring to Mr Pershing: \"I never found any indication that it was true in extensive research on his Moro experiences. This kind of thing would have run completely against his character.\"\n\nPolitifact quoted four historians who denied the account.\n\nMr Trump endorsed waterboarding - widely held now to be a torture technique, used during the George W Bush administration in its war on terror and halted by Barack Obama - during the presidential campaign.\n\nOnce in office, however, after US generals advised him against reverting to waterboarding, with some saying torture simply did not work as a way to extract information, Mr Trump said he would yield to them.\n\nAnd he stopped making public endorsements of {"timeCrawl": "01:41:00", "uri": "711200405", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:14:00Z", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "source": {"title": "Metro", "uri": "metro.us", "id": "354"}, "url": "http://www.metro.us/president-trump/trump-repeats-debunked-pershing-pigs-blood-lie", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "President Donald Trump tweeted on Thursday that the United States should take a page from history. No. 45 (in 140 characters or less) referred to Army Gen. John Joseph \"Black Jack\" Pershing ending \"Radical Islamic Terror\" for 35 years by dipping bullets in pig's blood when fighting Muslims in the Philippine-American War of 1899-1902... except this porcine parable never happened.\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nThough not as glaringly false as Kellyanne Conway's mention of the Bowling Green Massacre, this isn't the first time Trump referred to this debunked tale.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" then-candidate Trump said during a February 2016 rally in South Carolina. \"And [Pershing] caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pigs' blood -- you heard that, right? He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: 'You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened.' And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nIgnoring the fact that in the course of the year between the rally and Thursday's tweet, the number of \"Radical Islamic Terror-free\" years increased by a decade per POTUS, \"this is something you can read in the history books -- not a lot of history books because they don't like teaching this.\"\n\nIt isn't in history books because it's false, as is the story that Pershing buried the bodies of Muslim fighters in graves with dead pigs.\n\nIf Snopes can't convince you not to believe the bloody hype, PolitiFact checked with some experts and rated the legend \"[Liar, Liar] Pants on Fire.\"\n\n\"This story is a fabrication and has long been discredited,\" said Brian McAllister Linn, a Texas A&M University historian and author of \"Guardians of Empire: The U.S. Army and the Pacific, 1902-1940.\" \"I am amazed it is still making the rounds.\"\n\nThe Philippine-American War occurred during the Moro Rebellion, which lasted from 1899 to 1913. It ended 11 years after the supposed pigs blood bullet mission. The \"Moros\" (ethnic Muslims who lived in the Southern Philippines) fought against foreign rule for hundreds of years and rose up against the United States when the nation claimed rule of the island.\n\n\"The Moros were fighting for a lot of reasons, not just because they were Muslims,\" Lance Janda, a military historian at Cameron University, told PolitiFact. \"This is another fact that gets lost in many modern discussions of terrorism.\"\n\nAnother issue with the Pershing story is that it runs contrary to his character, according to historians.\n\n\"He did a lot of what we would call 'winning hearts and minds' and embraced reforms which helped end their resistance,\" Janda explained. \"He fought too, but only when he had to, and only against tribes or bands that just wouldn't negotiate with him. He wasn't solely committed to fighting as people like Trump who tell the pig blood story imply.\"\n\nA letter surfaced claiming Pershing, in charge of controlling territories gained during the Spanish-American War, did actually bury a Muslim's body with the dead body of a pig, but that letter was written half a century after the alleged double burial, according to historians.\n\nThat isn't to say that the threat of not going to heaven by exposure to swine hasn't been tried as a deterrent when fighting Muslims, but it's also important to note that the Moro Rebellion was not a religious war. It was a revolt against foreign occupation.\n\nAlso, as we should know today, not all people of one race, religion or creed are the same.\n\n\"The Ottomans under Sultan Abdul Hamid II sent a letter to the Sulu Moros asking them not to resist the Americans at the start of the Moro Rebellion, and the Moros on Sulu complied,\" Janda added in the 2016 PolitiFact article. \"It's a nice example of diplomacy working to our advantage, and a reminder that then and now, not all Muslims or Moros are the same and that many were and are U.S. allies.\"", "id": "9806040", "details": {}, "date": There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!'\n\nTerror attack in Barcelona leaves at least 13 dead after van crashes into crowds\n\nIt's a story he resurrected from his 2016 election campaign trail.\n\nTalking about the general -- who served in the Philippines in the early 1900s -- during a rally, he said: 'He took 50 men and dipped 50 bullets in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles and he lined up the 50 people and they shot 49 of those people, and the 50th person, he said \"you go back to your people and you tell them what happened\", and for 25 years there wasn't a problem. So we better start getting stuff.'\n\nHowever, the story has since been debunked.\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\nThere is little to no evidence to support the fact that this ever happened other than in movies, reports politifact.com.\n\nIt comes just days after he told journalists at a press conference that his initial reaction to Charlottesville was short and blunt because he didn't know the facts.\n\nHe blasted 'fake news' media at the time and stressed he would never just come out and say something about an event of enormous magnitude without checking he had the correct fakes first.\n\nThe president has also said the United States 'loves' Spain and has offered to 'do whatever is necessary to help'.\n\nAt least 13 people are dead after a van plowed into a group of people in Las Ramblas on Thursday.\n\nAround 80 people are also injured.\n\nThe president said on Twitter: 'The United States condemns the terror attack in Barcelona, Spain, and will do whatever is necessary to help. Be tough & strong, we love you!'\n\nHis words were echoed by Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who sent condolences to the families and victims.\n\nSpeaking to reporters at the State Department, he said US diplomats in Spain are currently assisting Americans there and asked those who are safe to notify their friends and families.\n\nThe United States condemns the terror attack in Barcelona, Spain, and will do whatever is necessary to help. Be tough & strong, we love you!\n\n-- Donald J. Police identified Driss Oukabir as one of the suspects.\n\nEx-gang member lifts the lid on life inside London's most violent gangs\n\nCatalan police are still hunting for the van driver after he jumped out of the vehicle and fled on foot.\n\nHorrific footage shot from overhead showed terrified pedestrians screaming as they ran away from the scene, while others taken in the aftermath show at least 19 people lying on the floor covered in blood.\n\nCatalan emergency services said people should not go to the area around Pla\u00e7a Catalunya, and should stay away from the centre of {"timeCrawl": "22:14:00", "uri": "711139408", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:56:00Z", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "source": {"title": "Mediaite", "uri": "mediaite.com", "id": "674"}, "url": "https://www.mediaite.com/online/tapper-trumps-lie-about-general-pershing-does-nothing-to-provide-moral-clarity-to-nation/", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": ".@jaketapper: In the face of a horrific terror attack, President Trump told the world to study a story that's not true, a lie. pic.twitter.com/95dURyipWw\n\nFollowing the deadly terror attack in Barcelona today, President Donald Trump tweeted out condolences to the victims and stated that the United States condemned the attacks. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\nThis claim is something Trump used on the campaign trail, telling rallygoers that General Pershing lined up 50 terrorists, shot 49 of them with the pigs blood dipped bullets, and stopped terrorism for decades. It's about the quashing of a Muslim rebellion in the Philippines in the early 20th century, but there's just one little problem with it.... It's not true.\n\nSpeaking to a South Carolina campaign rally in February last year, Trump touted the governor's approach.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" he said. \"And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people.\n\n\"And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pigs' blood -- you heard that, right? He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood.\n\n\"And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: 'You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened'.\n\n\"And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. OK? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nHistorians say the story, which first popped up in 2001, has very little evidence to support it.\n\nMoreover, the suggestion that such a tactic, if it had happened, had ended tensions is completely wrong.
