{"timeCrawl": "01:41:00", "uri": "711200374", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:14:00Z", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "source": {"title": "Axios", "uri": "axios.com", "id": "18528"}, "url": "https://www.axios.com/trump-again-pushes-debunked-claim-on-wwi-era-general-2474154601.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "President Trump tweeted a fictional claim about WWI-era General John Pershing Thursday afternoon, telling his followers to \"study it.\" This is one of several times Trump has cited the debunked claim about Pershing.\n\nThe fictional story he's referring to: Pershing, around the time of the Philippine-American War, killed 49 Muslims with bullets dipped in pigs' blood, and spared the 50th person so that he would take the last bullet to his people and tell them what happened.\n\nWhy? Trump has referenced this story repeatedly at rallies both during his campaign and his presidency as a way to give credence to his claim that the U.S. should \"go much further\" than waterboarding suspected terrorists.", "id": "9806012", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Trump again pushes debunked claim on WWI-era general", "image": "https://axios-img.rbl.ms/simage/https%3A%2F%2Fassets.rbl.ms%2F10252296%2F1200x600.png/2000%2C2000/5pjASPJ5r9VuZBLm/img.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "concepts": [{"label": {"eng": "Twitter"}, "id": "302546", "score": 4, "type": "org", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter"}, {"label": {"eng": "Muslim"}, "id": "303629", "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslim"}, {"label": {"eng": "Presidency of Barack Obama"}, "id": "304051", "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidency_of_Barack_Obama"}, {"label": {"eng": "President of the United States"}, "id": "304262", "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_the_United_States"}, {"label": {"eng": "World War I"}, "id": "309993", "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_I"}, {"label": {"eng": "John J. {"timeCrawl": "20:48:00", "uri": "711107973", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:48:00Z", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "source": {"title": "Daily News", "uri": "nydailynews.com", "id": "422"}, "url": "http://www.nydailynews.com/opinion/trump-dangerous-lie-john-pershing-article-1.3420689", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "BAGHDAD -- Nothing is quite as bad as the President of the United States equating white supremacists with their enemies and defending statues that glorify the slave-owning Confederacy. But the President implicitly endorsing atrocities against Muslims comes close.\n\nThat's what Donald Trump did on Thursday following the van attack, claimed by Islamic State, which killed a dozen people in Barcelona. \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught,\" Trump tweeted. \"There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nThe average person probably has no idea what Trump is talking about. But this is a reference to a historical myth that he repeated constantly on the campaign trail in spite of valiant efforts by historians and journalists to correct him. He is referring to efforts by Gen. John Pershing, later commander of U.S. forces in France during World War I, to suppress a Muslim revolt in the Philippines in the early years of the 20th century, at a time when that country was an American colony. This is the story as Trump told it last year:\n\n\"General Pershing was a rough guy, He caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage . . . and he took the 50 terrorists and he took 50 men and dipped 50 bullets in pig's blood. You heard about that? He took 50 bullets and dipped them in pig's blood. And he has his men load up their rifles and he lined up the 50 people and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said, you go back to your people and you tell them what happened. And for 25 years there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nThere is, in fact, no evidence that Pershing ever committed any such atrocity in his battles against the so-called Moros -- the ancestors of the Muslim fighters who continue to fight against the central government in Manila to this day.\n\n\"This story is a fabrication and has long been discredited,\" says Brian McAllister Linn, a Texas A&M University historian who is one of the foremost scholars of the Philippine War. \"I am amazed it is still making the rounds.\"\n\nWhile some U.S. troops did commit atrocities in the Philippines such as the use of the \"water cure\" (i.e., waterboarding), Pershing was known for being more enlightened and more successful. As I wrote in \"The Savage Wars of Peace: Small Wars and the Rise of American Power,\" \"Captain Pershing preferred to win over the Moros with outstretched hand rather than mailed fist. So successful was his campaign that he was made a datto, or chieftain.\"\n\nIn other words, Pershing pursued precisely the kind of \"hearts and minds\" policy that has become a hallmark of the \"population-centric\" counterinsurgency strategy that U.S. commanders, including Gens. H.R. McMaster, Jim Mattis, and John Kelly, have employed in recent years in Iraq and Afghanistan.\n\nWhat's deeply troubling here is not only that Trump continues to lie about an issue where he has been corrected time and again. It is that he is advocating that those fighting Islamist terrorists -- including our own troops -- commit atrocities such as executing prisoners and burying them with pig's blood. As it happens I am currently in Iraq, where U.S. troops are having a great deal of success in helping Iraqi forces to battle ISIS while keeping their honor clean.\n\nUp in Erbil, in the Kurdish region not far from Mosul, I actually asked on Thursday a U.S. Air Force colonel who is directing air strikes against ISIS in support of Iraqi army operations whether he has taken to heart Trump's injunction to \"bomb the shit\" out of the enemy. \"No, sir,\" he told me. \"We follow the laws of armed conflict. Proportionality, proportionality, proportionality.\"\n\nWhat he meant is that the use of force has to be proportionate to the threat and designed to minimize the risk of civilian casualties. There are even lawyers sitting in every U.S. operations center, including the one in Erbil, to make sure that air strikes comply with the laws of war.\n\nThis is apparently an alien concept to the commander in chief, but it is part and parcel of how the U.S. military operates -- and it is not an obstacle to defeating the enemy but an essential condition to that end. When U.S. forces have committed war crimes of the kind that Trump advocates -- whether at My Lai or Abu Ghraib -- the news has always gotten out and undermined support for the U.S. war effort. Leaving aside morality -- an alien concept for Trump -- it is simply stupid for our troops to engage in unlawful conduct because doing so will lead to mission failure.\n\nIt is deeply troubling that after more than six months in office Trump still does not understand this. It is further evidence, if any were needed, that he is unfit to be President.\n\nBoot is a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations and author of the forthcoming book, \"The Road Not Taken: Edward Lansdale and the American Tragedy in Vietnam.\"\n\nSend a Letter to the Editor Join the Conversation: facebook Tweet", "id": "9774566", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Trump's dangerous lie about John Pershing", "image": "http://assets.nydailynews.com/polopoly_fs/1.3420688.1503002224!/img/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/landscape_1200/boot18e-1-web.jpg", {"timeCrawl": "09:36:00", "uri": "711361784", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:45:00Z", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "source": {"title": "bustle.com", "uri": "bustle.com", "id": "16776"}, "url": "https://www.bustle.com/p/what-is-general-pershing-famous-for-heres-a-hint-its-not-what-trump-claims-77363", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "In a tweet published Thursday, President Donald Trump urged his followers to study how Gen. John J. Pershing allegedly eradicated terrorism in the early 1900s. However, Trump's claim that Pershing shot terrorists with bullets dipped in pigs blood during the Philippine-American war has been largely debunked. So, what is Gen. Pershing actually famous for?\n\nWhile Pershing had a lengthy military career, he is perhaps most famous for commanding the American Expeditionary Force during World War I. A year after the war ended, Congress approved then-President Woodrow Wilson to recognize Pershing for his service by promoting him to \"General of the Armies.\" Pershing is one of only two people (the other having been George Washington) to have ever been promoted to this prestigious rank.\n\nBorn near Laclede, Missouri, in 1860, Pershing did not always have military ambitions. According to Biography.com, Pershing worked as a teacher for more than two years before he decided to sit for the exam required for entry to West Point. With his graduation from West Point in 1886, Pershing began his nearly four-decade long military career.\n\nPrior to his service in World War I, Pershing fought in the Spanish-American War and in the Philippine-American War along with leading the Mexican Expedition to capture Pancho Villa during the Mexican Revolution.\n\nAs America entered World War I in 1917, Pershing was named commander in chief of the American Expeditionary Force (AEF) and although the AEF was initially expected to merely bolster depleted European troops, Pershing argued they would be more effective as an independent army. On Sept. 12, 1918, Pershing led the AEF in its first major offensive as an independent army on European soil in the Battle of Saint-Mihiel. He would go on to lead the AEF into other battles, including the Battle of Cantigny and the Meuse-Argonne offensive, which hastened the end of the war.\n\nFollowing the end of World War I, Pershing served as U.S. Army Chief of Staff from 1921 to 1924 before retiring from active service at the age of 64. In his later years, Pershing published an autobiography entitled My Experiences in the World War, which earned him a Pulitzer Prize in 1932.\n\nOn July 15, 1948, at the age of 87, Pershing died in his sleep while reportedly recovering from a stroke. He is buried at Arlington National Cemetery and continues to be one of American history's most honored and revered soldiers.", "id": "9863249", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "The Reason General Pershing Is Famous Isn't What Trump Thinks It Is", "image": {"timeCrawl": "01:41:00", "uri": "711200280", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:14:00Z", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "source": {"title": "Hot Air", "uri": "hotair.com", "id": "2962"}, "url": "http://hotair.com/archives/2017/08/17/trump-barcelona-study-gen-pershing-muslims-fought/", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "The media's in a fact-checking frenzy over this but I think they're missing the point.\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\nHe's referring to stories about Pershing's campaign in the Philippines against Muslim rebels at the start of the 20th century. Many a right-wing blog post and email chain since 9/11 has featured tales of Pershing using pigs or pig's blood to terrify the Islamic enemy into submission, sending them into the afterlife with the promise of damnation after they'd been tainted by an unclean animal. The most famous story, told by Trump himself on the campaign trail last year, involves Pershing supposedly having 50 bullets dipped in pig's blood in preparation for executing Muslim fighters. He had 49 shot, then freed the 50th so that he could go warn the rest of his comrades what the U.S. had in store for them if they continued fighting. Allegedly they quaked in horror, were pacified, and the Philippines had no \"Muslim problem\" for decades. It's a parable about the foolishness of political correctness, especially in war. If you want to beat a vicious enemy, you fight as dirty as you need to. If that means turning their religious beliefs against them, go for it.\n\nTthere's no evidence that that specific incident happened. There are reports of intimidation tactics involving pigs being used in that conflict, though. Pershing himself wrote that another American commander had had a dead pig buried with Muslim rebels. (\"It was not pleasant to have to take such measures, but the prospect of going to hell instead of heaven sometimes deterred the would-be assassins.\") Another commander told Pershing in a letter, \"I understand it has long been a custom to bury (insurgents) with pigs when they kill Americans.\" Sean Davis notes a report of Pershing having prisoners sprinkled with pig's blood and bringing a pig's head to a negotiation with a Muslim leader. The \"50 bullets\" story may be apocryphal but using pigs as a religious weapon probably isn't. Maybe Trump got wind of that since last year and made his tweet about Pershing today less specific for that reason. Or maybe he still thinks the \"50 bullets\" story is true but just ran out of characters in his tweet.\n\nAgain, though, all of this is beside the point. The point is that he's all talk. No one seriously believes he'd try to implement a policy like this, of using pigs in Afghanistan to intimidate the Taliban. It wouldn't work, for one thing. Jihadis would get propaganda mileage out of it; the tactic might end up boosting their numbers rather than pacifying them. But even if it did work, Trump wouldn't give the order. Mattis, McMaster, Kelly, Dunford and other officers wouldn't implement it if he did, and they'd almost certainly be able to talk him out of doing it if he ever semi-seriously proposed it. Remember, talking tough about waterboarding was one of Trump's signatures during the primaries as a way of showing voters that he wouldn't be soft on the enemy the way the other politically correct Republican candidates were. Then he got elected and talked to Mattis, and presto change-o -- he wasn't for waterboarding anymore. He isn't for deploying pig's blood either. This is just blowhard-ery he puts out for his fans to signal \"toughness\" with no intention of acting on it. True to his past, it's a show. Imagine spending 15 years after 9/11 talking about taking off the gloves with jihadis, getting elected president of the United States, and your main initiative to actually take off those gloves is tweeting.\n\nJulius Krein is, or was, a hardcore Trump fan who founded the website Journal of American Greatness last year to advocate for Trumpian nationalism and then founded the magazine American Affairs to put some meat on the bone policy-wise. Today he has an op-ed in the Times declaring that he's done:\n\nYet after more than 200 days in office, Mr. Trump's behavior grows only more reprehensible. Meanwhile, his administration has no significant legislative accomplishments -- and no apparent plan to deliver any. Wilbur Ross's Commerce Department has advanced some sensible and appropriately incremental changes to trade policy, but no long-term agenda has been articulated. Senators Tom Cotton and David Perdue's recently proposed legislation offers a sound basis for reforming immigration policy, but seems to have no prospects and has received comparatively little attention. The administration inexplicably downgraded infrastructure and corporate tax reform -- issues with potentially broad-based support -- to pursue a warmed-over version of Paul Ryan's Obamacare repeal, which ended, predictably, in a humiliating failure.\n\nNothing disastrous has occurred on the foreign policy front -- yet -- but the never-ending chaos within the administration hardly inspires confidence. Many senior-level appointees are still not in place, including the assistant secretaries of state, for example. And too many of those who are in office appear to be petty, clueless, and rather repulsive ideologues, like Steve Bannon, who seem to spend most of their time accusing one another of being \"swamp creatures.\" It's pathetic. No wonder an increasing number of officials are simply ignoring the president, an alarming but understandable development.\n\nThe Trumpian bargain on the right last year was that the policy payoffs would more than make up for his personal peccadilloes. He's going to fart out nonsense on Twitter but he's also going to get you ObamaCare repeal, tax reform, a jobs stimulus in the form of a giant new infrastructure bill, and all sorts of other goodies. You'll take the bitter with the sweet. He delivered on Gorsuch but that's basically been it -- it's all bitter Twitter nonsense and West Wing chaos. The Pershing tweet is almost an unintentional parody of his own ineffectiveness. He's touting a terrible policy as a model for what should be done in the war on terror knowing he doesn't have a whisper of a chance of actually making it happen. {"timeCrawl": "20:55:00", "uri": "711110611", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:55:00Z", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "source": {"title": "nationalreview.com", "uri": "nationalreview.com", "id": "3914"}, "url": "http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/450574/donald-trump-tweet-fake-history-libel-war-crime", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "Just minutes ago the president of the United States - the man who just yesterday said, \"When I make a statement, I like to be correct. I want the facts\" - fired out a tweet apparently in response to the dreadful terror attack in Barcelona, Spain. Here it is:\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nTrump is almost certainly referring to a story he told during the campaign. He claimed that General John J. Pershing crushed an Islamic insurgency in the Philippines by committing a heinous war crime. Here's Trump at a South Carolina rally:\n\nThey were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Trump said. \"And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pigs' blood -- you heard that, right? He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened. And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem\n\nThere are multiple problems with this story. First, it's false. There's no evidence Pershing did such a thing. In fact, he got the history exactly backwards. Pershing worked hard to avoid inflaming religious fanaticism and worked hard to avoid unnecessary loss of life. For example, read this excerpt from a letter Pershing wrote to the insurgents. The language comes from his own memoir:\n\nI write you this letter because I am sorry to know that you and your people refuse to do what the government has ordered. You do not give up your arms. Soldiers were sent to Taglibi so that you could come into camp and turn in your guns. When the soldiers went to camp a Taglibi, your Moros fired into camp and tried to kill the soldiers. Then the soldiers had to shoot all Moros who fired upon them. When the soldiers marched through the country, the Moros again shot at them, so the soldiers had to kill several others. I am sorry the soldiers had to kill any Moros. All Moros are the same to me as my children and no father wants to kill his own children.\n\nThose are not the words of a man who commits a religious war crime. A comprehensive report over at Snopes contains a number of other, similar reports in Pershing's own words. Simply put, Trump libeled an American hero, the man who led American troops through the crucible of the First World War. The president who relentlessly attacks \"fake news\" keeps advancing \"fake history.\"\n\nTrump isn't just spreading falsehoods, he's doing so in a context that puts a presidential stamp of approval on war crimes. Even worse, he's doing it in direct defiance of the warrior ethos of the American military. There is no possible way that any of Trump's generals would approve of this sentiment. I've never met an American officer who would carry out an order to commit an atrocity like this.\n\nTrump is careening out of control. He says what he wants, when he wants, and neither truth nor consistency nor wisdom nor prudence dictates a single syllable that comes out of his mouth. By many accounts he's taken to directly defying his advisers simply for the sake of declaring that he's in charge. This isn't leadership. It's a collection of temper tantrums. Unfortunately, those tantrums have consequences.\n\nOne final note - if Trump thinks this tweet is the least bit intimidating to actual jihadists, he's fundamentally wrong. In fact, it illustrates that he flat-out doesn't understand our enemy. They respond to actions not words, and words like this serve only to facilitate the radicalization of angry jihadist minds.\n\nIn one tweet Trump spread fake history, libeled an American hero, and signaled a willingness - even eagerness - to commit war crimes. That's conduct unbecoming the lowliest officer in the military. {"timeCrawl": "03:08:00", "uri": "711222983", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T03:08:00Z", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "source": {"title": "msn.com", "uri": "msn.com", "id": "152"}, "url": "http://www.msn.com/en-gb/news/world/trump-responds-to-barcelona-attack-by-reviving-debunked-myth/ar-AAqgj5s", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "Donald Trump has responded to the Barcelona attack by reviving an already debunked anecdote about a US general dipping bullets in pig's blood to fight Islamic militants more than a hundred years ago.\n\nAfter a relatively conventional response to the attack, in which he went on to Twitter to call on the people of Barcelona to be \"tough and strong\" and offer help from the US, he posted another, more cryptic, tweet\n\nStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nThe tweet echoed a highly controversial claim Trump made at an election rally in South Carolina in February 2016, in which he talked admiringly about a counter-insurgency in the Philippines conducted by Gen John Pershing between 1909 and 1913, when he was governor of Moro province.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems just like we do,\" Trump said. \"And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men, and he dipped 50 bullets in pig's blood.\"\n\nHe claimed that Pershing then \"had his men load his rifles and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said, 'You go back to your people and you tell them what happened.'\"\n\nIn 2016, Trump claimed such mass executions ended the Islamic insurgency for a quarter-century. \"Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem,\" he said. In his new tweet he revised that estimated upward to 35 years.\n\nThis account of Pershing's actions has circulated on the internet since 2001 but historians say there is very little if any evidence to support it, and Trump was denounced for his support of mass killing aggravated by racist insults. But the outburst solidified his support among the US far right, and did nothing to impede his victory in the Republican primaries and then the election last November. Trump appears to have had domestic politics in mind when he sent out his tweet in response to the Barcelona attack.\n\nHis relationship with that section of his support has come under renewed scrutiny since the attack on a crowd in Charlottesville, Virginia, by a white supremacist on Saturday. It took him two days to assign blame directly on the far right, only to contradict himself the next day with a claim that \"both sides\" were to blame for the incident.\n\nTrump was much faster in pointing the finger of blame in the wake of Barcelona, but his erratic response echoed the controversy over Charlottesville, in which conventional political language, apparently drafted by aides, has alternated with a personal gut reaction that has had an explosive and divisive effect.\n\nThe French president, Emmanuel Macron, appeared to take on Trump in his Twitter reaction to the Barcelona attack. An initial tweet offered solidarity for the victims of and the pledge: \"We remain united and determined.\"\n\nBefore Trump took to Twitter, the US secretary of state, Rex Tillerson, said the administration stood ready to help Spanish law enforcement and national authorities and advised Americans in Spain to call home to reassure relatives.\n\n\"Terrorists around the world should know that the United States and our allies are resolved to find you and bring you to justice,\" Tillerson said.\n\nIn the UK, Theresa May, said: \"My thoughts are with the victims of today's terrible attack in Barcelonaand the emergency services responding to this ongoing incident.\n\n\"The UK stands with Spain against terror,\" she added.\n\nThe UK foreign secretary, Boris Johnson said he was \"concerned and saddened\" by the attack and said the foreign office was \"doing all we can to identify whether Brits need help\".\n\nSadiq Khan, the London mayor who has had to handle a string of recent terrorist attacks in Westminster, London Bridge and Finsbury Park, wrote on Twitter: \"\"My thoughts are with the victims of this barbaric terrorist attack in the great city of Barcelona and with their brave emergency services.\n\n\"London stands with Barcelonaagainst the evil of terrorism.\"\n\nThe Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, tweeted about the \"terrible reports from Barcelona\", saying: \"My thoughts are with those killed and injured, and the emergency services working to save lives.\"\n\nAnd the German foreign minister, Sigmar Gabriel, said he was \"deeply shocked\" by the incident. This is a heartbreaking reminder that evil is real and the United States is not alone in fighting it.\"\n\nHe applauded Trump for tweeting \"the right thing\" after it happened: \"'The United States condemns the terror attack in Barcelona, Spain, and will do whatever is necessary to help. Be tough and strong, we love you!'\"\n\n\"Thank you, sir,\" Colbert said. \"Simple. Dignified. Presidential. That's what you want. That's what you hope for. That's all you can ask. He's right. In Barcelona, a speeding rented van plowed through people in a popular pedestrian plaza, killing 13 and injuring more than 100. Two terror suspects were arrested, but the driver of the van escaped.\n\nLater, an attack was thwarted in the coastal town of Cambrils, about 75 miles south of Barcelona. Five attackers were killed and six people were injured. Suicide belts worn by the attackers were detonated by police. The two incidents are believed to be linked.\n\nISIS has claimed responsibility for the Barcelona attack. It marks the deadliest terror attack in Spain since 2004, when bombs were placed in Madrid commuter trains, killing nearly 200 people.\n\nAccording to NBC News, the Barcelona plaza incident was the sixth vehicle-based terror attack in Europe in the past 13 months. It could have been even worse. The terror suspect who rented the van, reportedly wanted to rent a truck instead.\n\nVehicles have become terrorists new favorite weapon of mass destruction. Instead of expensive, sophisticated, long-planned operations like the 9/11 attack, ISIS has urged its terror cells and ISIS inspired lone wolfs to use easily attainable weapons to carry out smaller scale, but still deadly, terror attacks. Ever since then, their have been multiple attacks using vehicles to drive into crowds.\n\nAt the white supremacist rally in Charlottesvile, Virgina, an alleged Nazi-sympathizer used the ISIS tactic to plow his car into counter-protesters, killing Heather Heyer and injuring over 30 people. In 2016, a car plowed into pedestrians on The Ohio State University campus.\n\nPresident Trump responded to the Barcelona attack far quicker than he did the deadly violence in Charlottesville. But as with Charlottesville, his response was haphazard. Trump followed a tweet that gave the a standard presidential response with a tweet that spread a debunked, racially-tinged fake story about General Pershing fighting Muslim insurgents in the Philippines in the early 1900's\n\nFirst Trump tweeted:\n\n\"The United States condemns the terror attack in Barcelona, Spain, and will do whatever is necessary to help. Be tough & strong, we love you!\"\n\nThen Trump tweeted:\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was o more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years.!\"\n\nDuring the campaign, Trump told a rally crowd about Pershing having Muslim insurgents in the Philippines executed with bullets dipped in pigs blood. And the 50th person, he said, you go back to your people and you tell them what happened . And for 25 years there wasn't a problem,\" Trump told the crowd.\n\nThe Pershing story is a debunked, email chain myth, but it fits with Trump's Islamophobic narrative and rhetoric. Trump's daughter, son-in-law, and grand children also have religion-based diet restrictions as observant Jews.\n\nTrump endangered Americans when he emboldened the white supremacists and Nazi wannabes marching in Charlottesville. {"timeCrawl": "01:41:00", "uri": "711200202", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:14:00Z", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "source": {"title": "Vanity Fair", "uri": "vanityfair.com", "id": "2690"}, "url": "https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/08/donald-trump-pigs-blood-pershing-story", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "Why the president should really stop repeating this wild, false story.\n\nOn Thursday, a van careened into pedestrians along Las Ramblas in Barcelona, killing 13 and injuring at least 100 in a terror attack for which ISIS later claimed responsibility. (The degree to which the group communicated with attackers beforehand, if at all, remains to be seen.) It was the deadliest such incident in Spain since the 2004 Madrid train bombings that killed nearly 200 people, and world leaders responded with a wave of solidarity and sympathy. Initially, U.S. President Donald Trump seemed to join in.\n\n\"The United States condemns the terror attack in Barcelona, Spain, and will do whatever is necessary to help,\" he tweeted, shortly after. Later, he added \"Be tough & strong, we love you!\"\n\nWithin 45 minutes, the president had changed his tone, directing followers to Google the work of early 20th Century U.S. General John Pershing.\n\nPresumably, Trump meant to direct readers to the claim that in 1911, during the Spanish-American War, Pershing had put down a Muslim insurgency in the Philippines by forcing a group six rebels to watch them kill six of their comrades, using bullets dipped in pig fat, then wrapped their corpses in pigskin and entrails -- a desecration, given that pork products are forbidden in Islam. Trump's own version of the tale, which he told often on the campaign trail, inflated the number to 49 Muslims being killed with \"bullets dipped in pigs' blood,\" and one lone survivor left to warn his people.\n\nAccording to Snopes, the urban legend fact-checking service, any version of the story is false. Snopes found no reference to the incident in any of Pershing's biographies. Furthermore, it could not find evidence that he executed any Muslims or Moros during this rebellion. Instead, Pershing made a specific effort to prevent them from taking radical action: rather than storming the sacred mountain where they had hoped to make a last stand, he simply surrounded the hill and cut off their supplies. \"The fact is that they were completely surprised at the prompt and decisive action of the troops in cutting off supplies and preventing escape,\" he wrote in his official report of the battle, per Snopes, \"and they were chagrined and disappointed in that they were not encouraged to die the death of Mohammedan fanatics.\"\n\nAs Americans have learned in recent months, though, facts do not particularly matter to Donald Trump. Nor does consistency: when he first told the story in 2016, he claimed that Pershing's actions ended \"radical Islamic terrorism\" for a mere 25 years, not 35, and Trump did not retract the story after it had been repeatedly proven false. Politifact also reported that the rest of Trump's premise is untrue: the region was still wracked with instability long after Pershing fought there, the Moros rebels were not simply motivated by religion, and that defiling Muslims' bodies with pig parts had any deterrent effect. Not that the relative truths of a given historical argument have ever stopped Trump from making a hasty pronouncement for a call to arms.", "id": "9805969", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", with 13 dead.\n\nTrump appeared to have cited the urban legend of US General John Perishing as way to deal with terrorists as he responded on Twitter.\n\nModern myth states the commander dipped bullets in pig's blood before executing 49 terrorists in the Philippines during World War One.\n\nTrump tweeted: \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught.\n\n\"There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nHis tweets have been condemned for celebrating \"torture and mass executions\" and for \"glorifying war crimes\".\n\nGETTY/TWITTER\n\nDONALD TRUMP: The US President tweeted the bizarre urban legend of General Perishing BARCELONA: Terror attack in Spanish tourist hotspot A white van has mounted the pavement and driven towards pedestrians in the Spanish city's tourist hotspot of Las Ramblas 1 / 16 Las Ramblas after a vehicle mounted the pavement and drove towards crowds\n\n\"He took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men, and he dipped 50 bullets in pig's blood\"\n\nDonald Trump\n\nHis tweet came just hours after the incident in Barcelona and after he called for the world to be \"strong and tough\" on terrorists.\n\nTrump previously citied the urban legend of Perishing on the campaign trail at a rally in February, 2016.\n\nSpeaking at the event last year, he told the story: \"They were having terrorism problems just like we do. And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people.\n\n\"And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men, and he dipped 50 bullets in pig's blood.\"\n\nTWITTER\n\nBARCELONA: 80 people were injured and 13 killed in the attack on Las Ramblas\n\nAFP\n\nTERRORIST ATTACK: Barcelona was put on lockdown after the attack\n\nHe continued Perishing then \"had his men load his rifles and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people.\n\n\"And the 50th person he said: you go back to your people and you tell them what happened.\"\n\nThis urban legend has previously been debunked and stems from Perishing's help to put down a rebellion in the Muslim region of Mindanao.\n\nCharlottesville: Shocking photos show the BRUTALITY of sick neo-Nazi rally Escalating violence at the \"Unite the Right\" rally in Charlottesville, Virginia ended in tragedy after a car was driven into a group of counter-protestors. {"timeCrawl": "23:30:00", "uri": "711163349", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:30:00Z", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "source": {"title": "JournalStar.com", "uri": "journalstar.com", "id": "3417"}, "url": "http://journalstar.com/news/state-and-regional/federal-politics/unl-pershing-scholar-corrects-trump/article_c9b90ab5-704e-5c68-bf00-99c065b483f0.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "Wrong again.\n\nThat's what University of Nebraska-Lincoln Professor Barney McCoy told President Donald Trump on Thursday after the president referred to an oft-debunked tale about Gen. John J. Pershing dipping bullets in pig's blood before executing Muslim insurgents in the Phillipines in the early 1900s.\n\nAfter Trump repeated the tale in a Tweet responding to the apparent terrorist attack in Barcelona, McCoy replied with a Tweet directed at the president.\n\n\"You do Gen. John J. Pershing a disservice by misrepresenting history again,\" McCoy told Trump.\n\nMcCoy, a professor of journalism with wide experience in broadcasting, recently completed a one-hour documentary about Pershing that will air on NET on Nov. 11.\n\nPershing, who led 2 million troops as commander of the American Expeditionary Forces in France during World War I, was the commander of cadets at the University of Nebraska in Lincoln from 1891 to 1895 and earned a law degree while he was here.\n\nPershing is a member of the Nebraska Hall of Fame and his bust adorns the Great Hall at the State Capitol.\n\nMcCoy's documentary is the culmination of five years of research about the general, which included multiple trips to the Library of Congress and National Archives.\n\nThis was not Trump's first reference to the tale about Pershing in the Philippines.\n\nDuring a campaign stop in South Carolina last year, Trump spun the same story and it prompted a blog response from McCoy at the time.\n\nIn that blog, McCoy said Trump \"bungles facts (and) history\" with his claims.\n\nIn his research, McCoy did discover a reference to the burial of some of the insurgents in the same grave He waited just over two hours to decry the bloodshed as a \"terror attack.\"\n\nThe swift finger pointing as the tragedy was still unfolding stood in stark contrast to his controversial and slow public reaction to violence in Charlottesville, Va., over the weekend.\n\nAt least 13 dead in Barcelona van attack claimed by ISIS\n\n39 photos view gallery New Yorkers protest Trump's response to Charlottesville\n\nBy comparison, hours passed on Saturday as white nationalists clashed with counter-protesters before Trump tweeted: \"Charlottesville sad!\"\n\nHe later blamed \"many sides\" for the violence at the rally where 32-year-old paralegal Heather Heyer was killed by a suspected neo-Nazi who drove through a crowd of counter-protesters, and would not refer to what happened as terrorism.\n\nAmid intense criticism, Trump relented and issued a stronger statement condemning the Klansmen, neo-Nazis and white supremacists at the rally two days later.\n\nOn Tuesday, he defiantly defended his decision to wait to condemn the hate groups by saying that \"before I make a statement, I like to know the facts.\"\n\n3 dead, 34 injured in violent rally, crashes in Charlottesville\n\nBut Trump's turning to Twitter to issue responses before all the facts are known is a far more common occurrence than a metered acknowledgment of a tragedy -- especially if speculation about ISIS is involved.\n\nIn another tweet an hour after his first on the Barcelona attack, the President encouraged people to \"study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\n31 photos view gallery Van plows into crowds in Barcelona\n\nThe line was a reference to a debunked legend about World War I-era General John Pershing that Trump repeatedly recounted in his speeches on the campaign trail.\n\nIt also echoed his quick, shoot-from-the-hip reactions to a number of recent deadly incidents across the globe.\n\nMom of Charlottesville victim says daughter's cause won't stop\n\nSeveral times, Trump has characterized events as \"terrorist attacks\" long before authorities have issued officials statements, and not always accurately.\n\nIn June, Trump condemned an unfolding incident at a casino in the Philippines as a \"terrorist attack.\"\n\nAuthorities in Manila later said it wasn't -- it was a robbery gone bad involving a 42-year-old with a gambling problem who was deep in debt. Thirty-seven people died in the botched robbery from fires set by the crook.\n\nThat same month, Trump's knee-jerk reaction to a horrific attack on London Bridge that left seven dead and 48 injured earned him widespread criticism as he shared unconfirmed information, used the tragedy to champion his travel ban and then berated London mayor Sadiq Khan.\n\nNew York has no place for Charlottesville-style hate\n\nTrump retweeted a report labeling the carnage as terror-related before authorities in London characterized the nature of the attack.\n\nHe also chose to politicize the carnage, cheerleading his effort to bar people from several Muslim-majority countries from entering the U.S.\n\n\"We need the courts to give us back our rights,\" he wrote. \"We need the Travel Ban as an extra level of safety!\"\n\nFollowing the mass shooting at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando last June, Trump issued a tone deaf tweet saying, \"Appreciate the congrats for being right on radical Islamic terrorism, I don't want congrats, I want toughness & vigilance. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\n* Trump used this story during the campaign.\n\nAs the crowd cheered him on, Trump told them about Pershing -- \"rough guy, rough guy\" -- who was fighting terrorism in the early 1900s. Trump didn't say where this happened, but variations of this story online usually state that it happened in the Philippines during the Philippine-American War -- part of the island nation's protracted battle for independence -- early in Pershing's career.\n\n\"They were having terrorism problems, just like we do,\" Trump said. \"And he caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage and killed many people. And he took the 50 terrorists, and he took 50 men and he dipped 50 bullets in pigs' blood -- you heard that, right? He took 50 bullets, and he dipped them in pigs' blood. And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened. And for 25 years, there wasn't a problem. Okay? Twenty-five years, there wasn't a problem.\"\n\nThere is no truth to this story and since it's not the first time Trump has used it, we have every reason to believe that he's been fact-checked about it. He just doesn't give a damn.\n\n* Fairly early on in Trump's presidency, it became clear that he gets his news from right wing media. So Philip Bump came up with an interesting idea.\n\nMuch of what Trump learns about the world is filtered through two lenses: what he watches on cable news (particularly Fox) and what he sees on Twitter...\n\nUsers of Twitter will understand, however, that it can be tricky to know what someone else sees when he or she fires up the application. Everyone follows a different group of people, and that colors the information they receive.\n\nTo that end, we've created @trumps_feed, an account that checks whom Trump follows every five minutes and then retweets any new tweets from them over that period.\n\n* Remember when Trump talked about how the so-called \"alt-left\" was equally as violent in Charlottesville over the weekend as the Nazis and white supremacists? Well...last night there was another protest in Charlottesville. Only there was a big difference this time. The Nazis and white supremacists didn't attend. You'll never guess what happened.\n\nIn Charlottesville, a candlelight vigil was a striking peaceful contrast to torches wielded by white supremacists https://t.co/0Pk4MET66U pic.twitter.com/M9VnHLgHLq\n\n-- The New York Times (@nytimes) August 17, 2017\n\n* Another one bites the dust.\n\nPresident Donald Trump will not move forward with a planned Advisory Council on Infrastructure, a person familiar with the matter said Thursday.\n\nThe infrastructure council, which was still being formed, would have advised Trump on his plan to spend as much as $1 trillion upgrading roads, bridges and other public works. Its cancellation follows Trump's announcement Wednesday that he was disbanding two other business advisory panels.\n\nCorporate chief executive officers this week had started to quit both the American Manufacturing Council and the Strategic and Policy Forum in protest over Trump's remarks that appeared to confer legitimacy on white supremacists following a violent rally Aug. 12 in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\n* I find myself agreeing with Josh Marshall a lot when he shares his observations about the current occupant of the White House.\n\nEverything we are seeing stems almost inevitably from the decisions the country made, collectively, last November. We elected a President driven by white racial grievance. That is the fulcrum and driving force of his politics. It's no surprise that a big outbreak of white supremacist violence would lead us to a moment like this. We also elected a President who is an abuser and a predator. I've analogized him before to an abusive man in an abused household - only his house is now the country, now with all the cumulative exhaustion, warped perceptions and damage that are the common lot of people living with and trapped with violent predators, addicts or people with certain profound mental illnesses.\n\nAs things get worse, as more people turn against him, Trump gets more wild and unbridled. He lashes out more aggressively. There's no kill switch on this escalating aggression. It only builds...\n\nTrump will clearly, happily destroy the GOP if he feels the party has proven disloyal to him...He would happily destroy the country too to sate his own anguished feelings of {"timeCrawl": "09:57:00", "uri": "711370203", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T09:57:00Z", "sim": 0.4235294163227081, "source": {"title": "Newsday", "uri": "newsday.com", "id": "5559"}, "url": "http://www.newsday.com/long-island/dubious-tale-of-a-past-u-s-general-mars-anti-isis-message-1.14070603", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "Ready, willing and fable\n\nEven for those willing to hear him out, President Donald Trump may have shot himself in the rhetorical foot when, after an encouraging first message after a deadly terror attack in Spain, he repeated a debunked tale of America's past.\n\nMost Popular PSEG gives go-ahead to sisters' Dairy Queen New details of pol's alleged abuse emerge in court docs Five great white sharks tagged off Hamptons Plans for LGBT-friendly senior housing unveiled Fresh hope for justice in archbishop's slaying\n\nThe first tweet on Thursday after the ISIS-linked van-ramming massacre was just what to expect from a president, offering support and concluding: \"Be tough & strong, we love you!\"\n\nThe second tweet was another story: \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nCampaign redux\n\nTrump thus stirred recollections of an unfounded internet tale he used on the campaign trail last year: that Gen. John Pershing, governor of the Moro province of the Philippines between 1909 and 1913, executed Muslim insurgents with bullets dipped in pigs' blood.\n\nAs told in 2016, the quiet epilogue lasted only 25 years, not 35. Now Trump can say truthfully that he only told others on Twitter to \"study\" what Pershing did -- the general did face insurgencies. But Trump never retracted or revised the pig's-blood myth.\n\nadvertisement | advertise on newsday\n\nWaiting for facts\n\nThe Pershing canard chafes against the president's credibility in two ways. One is his claim on Tuesday that he delayed a targeted denunciation of violent white supremacists in Charlottesville, Virginia, for two days because, unlike other pols, he wanted the facts first. His grasp of facts is again at issue.\n\nThe other problem is Trump's emphasis on actual history in opposing the removal of Confederate statues. \"You can't change history, but you can learn from it,\" he tweeted, echoing a familiar point in a very long-running debate over the icons.\n\n\"Robert E. Lee. Stonewall Jackson -- who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish.\" He decried \"the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart.\"\n\nBannon fodder\n\nTrump aide Steve Bannon owns the profile of a curious, well-read intellectual versatile enough to have made millions at Goldman Sachs and then craft a populist campaign for his boss.\n\nSo it's no shock that he contacted Robert Kuttner at the left-wing American Prospect to talk about their common views on one topic -- trade rivalry with China. Way more surprising was what he reportedly told Kuttner: \"There's no military solution [to North Korea's nuclear threats], forget it... There's no military solution here, they got us.\"\n\nRep. King: Fire away!The words might well serve Trump-loyal Bannon detractors. Rep. Peter King (R-Seaford) tweeted Thursday: \"How long can Trump Administration survive Bannon using race as political issue and undermining @POTUS and Cabinet on N Korea?\" Bannon also trash-talked White House rivals as \"wetting themselves\" and called white supremacists \"clowns\" and losers.\"Upping veterans' entitlements\n\nTrump at his Bedminister, New Jersey golf club privately signed into law a bill that gives military veterans unlimited access to college. The Forever GI Act removed a 15-year limit on using the benefits, effective immediately, as the Associated Press reports. Aid will be boosted by $3 billion over 10 years, officials said.\n\nWhat else is happening:Four were arrested in the toppling of a Confederate soldier statue in Durham, North Carolina.University of Arkansas professor Kyle Quinn was interviewed by NPR about hiding at a friend's house after internet vigilantes falsely branded him a neo-Nazi demonstrator.Sen. Bob Corker (R-Tenn.), who was considered for a Cabinet post, said Trump \"has not yet been able to demonstrate the stability nor some of the competence he needs to.\"Two other Senate critics, both Republicans, drew nasty morning tweets from the commander-in-chief.Trump canceled plans for an infrastructure advisory panel that he announced only last month, following disbanding of others in the {"timeCrawl": "09:06:00", "uri": "711348565", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T09:06:00Z", "sim": 0.4117647111415863, "source": {"title": "Frontpage Mag", "uri": "frontpagemag.com", "id": "937"}, "url": "http://www.frontpagemag.com/point/267622/general-pershing-pigs-philippines-and-islamic-daniel-greenfield", "eventUri": "eng-3369972", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369972", "body": "\"These Juramentado attacks were materially reduced in number by a practice that the Mohamedans held in abhorrence. The bodies were publicly buried in the same grave with a dead pig. It was not pleasant to have to take such measures, but the prospect of going to hell instead of heaven sometimes deterred the would-be assassins.\"\n\nThese were the words of General Pershing in his autobiography. According to the New York Times (despite having reported on it at the time) it's a myth. The Washington Post agrees. They both cite fact checks by Politifact and Snopes. The problem with all the fact checks is... the facts.\n\nThe media has avoided the problem by consulting \"experts\" who tell them exactly what they want to hear. And what they want to hear is that it never happened. But not only was it written up in the New York Times, the Scientific American, a number of other publications, and mentioned by a number of other military officers, General Pershing had written about it.\n\nGeneral Pershing fell ill and died while working on his unpublished autobiography. The materials remained at the Library of Congress Manuscripts Division. Some contain his handwritten notes. They can be examined by the public.\n\nJohn T. Greenwood, who assembled, edited and published the manuscript, was the former chief of the Office of Medical History, Office of the Surgeon General, US Army. He is also the author of a number of other military history books.\n\nThe book was positively reviewed as a military studies text. It was published by the University of Kentucky Press. At no point in time, until this issue came up, did anyone question its legitimacy.\n\n\"So many who achieve great things become fixed in stone as monuments. My Life before the War is a reminder that John J. Pershing was a real, living, breathing man who lived through and shaped extraordinary times. For any with an interest in either the man or the times, this book is highly recommended.\" -- The Journal of Military History\n\n\"What distinguishes My Life Before the World War is the author's sense of service. It is not about Pershing the man but Pershing the public servant.\" -- The Historian\n\nA fascinating read. Pershing comes across as diplomatically and politically astute -- a far more nuanced officer than one gets from his standard biographers. -- Timothy K. Nenninger, editor of The Way of Duty, Honor, Country: The Memoir of General Charles Pelot Summerall\n\nA significant contribution to American military history. Pershing had a remarkable memory, and this memoir details his life from his childhood in a small Missouri town to his arrival at West Point and his military assignments across the globe. Greenwood's scholarship is excellent. -- Edward M. Coffman, author of The War to End All Wars: The American Military Experience in World War I\n\n\"To the resulting 366-page memoir, Greenwood has added a comprehensive, immaculately researched 143-page biographical appendix on officers and individuals, both American and international, whom Pershing interacted with over his lifetime. It is an invaluable contribution to the study of the US Army officer corps from 1886 to 1917. Greenwood includes no less than ten additional appendices: a lecture Pershing gave on his service in Cuba during the Spanish-American War, eight reports he made during operations against the Moros in the Philippine War, and one official investigation he conducted regarding a reverse sustained during operations in Mexico. Although these various supplements swell the volume to over seven hundred pages, they constitute a significant contribution to history in their own right. Exhaustive endnotes with Greenwood's extremely informative annotations comprise another sixty-eight pages. The book also features a comprehensive index and very fine maps. The University Press of Kentucky and the AUSA are to be congratulated for cartography far surpassing that found in most military histories published today.\" - Michigan War Studies Review\n\nAnd yet, those few history deniers who have bothered to address the autobiography have begun acting as if Greenwood were a shady character passing off some dubious papers as Pershing's own.", "id": "9857652", Trump legte der Welt nahe, im Kampf gegen Terrorismus die Methoden des US-Generals John Pershing zu studieren.\n\nEiner mehrfach widerlegten Legende nach soll Pershing vor mehr als 100 Jahren auf den Philippinen 50 muslimische Gefangene mit Projektilen exekutiert haben, die er zuvor in Schweineblut getaucht hatte. Mit dem Blut der f\u00fcr gl\u00e4ubige Muslime unreinen Tiere sei ihnen der Weg ins Paradies versperrt gewesen. Trump: \"Danach gab es 35 Jahre keinen islamistischen Terror mehr!\"\n\nTrump hatte diese Legende bereits mehrfach im Wahlkampf 2016 zitiert. Laut Historikern gibt es keinerlei Anlass, die Geschichte um Pershing f\u00fcr wahr zu halten, die sich angeblich in den Jahren der Moro-Rebellion (1899-1913) zugetragen haben soll.\n\nTrump, der Medien die Verbreitung von gef\u00e4lschten Nachrichten (Fake News) vorwirft, interessierte sich schon im Wahlkampf nicht daf\u00fcr, dass seine Behauptung nicht wahr ist. Auch die moralisch fragw\u00fcrdige Ebene seiner Einlassungen und ein klarer Versto\u00df gegen das V\u00f6lkerrecht, h\u00e4tte Pershing denn tats\u00e4chlich so gehandelt wie behauptet, waren ihm gleichg\u00fcltig.\n\nIn zahlreichen Reaktionen auf Trumps Tweet hie\u00df es in sozialen Netzwerken und anderen Medien, w\u00e4hrend die Welt noch um die Toten von Barcelona trauere, verweise der Pr\u00e4sident der Vereinigten Staaten auf eine L\u00fcge, in der die Exekution Gefangener glorifiziert werde.\n\nDie \"New York Times\" schrieb, der US-Pr\u00e4sident lasse in offensichtlich gro\u00dfer Bedr\u00e4ngnis wieder ganz den ungez\u00fcgelten Wahlk\u00e4mpfer heraus. Andere US-Medien wiesen darauf hin, dass Trump nur Stunden gebraucht habe, um sich zu Barcelona in eindeutigster Weise zu positionieren. Dagegen wolle er die t\u00f6dliche Gewalt bei einer Rassistenkundgebung in Charlottesville auch nach mehr als f\u00fcnf Tagen nicht als Terrorismus brandmarken.\n\nAbgesehen vom fehlenden Wahrheitsgehalt des Trump-Tweets wiesen Historiker auf die m\u00f6glicherweise weitreichenden Folgen hin, wenn ein Pr\u00e4sident der Vereinigten Staaten nahelege, man k\u00f6nne Terroristen nur mit brutalsten Kriegstechniken beikommen.\n\nIn einer ersten Reaktion auf Barcelona hatte Trump getwittert, die Vereinigten Staaten verurteilten die Terrorattacke. \"Bleibt stark und hart, wir lieben Euch!\"\n\nF\u00fcr Trump geht eine bemerkenswert schlechte Woche zu Ende. Kommentatoren sahen dies als Wendepunkt und potenziellen Bruch seiner Pr\u00e4sidentschaft. Trump legte der Welt nahe, im Kampf gegen Terrorismus die Methoden des US-Generals John Pershing zu studieren.\n\nEiner mehrfach widerlegten Legende nach soll Pershing vor mehr als 100 Jahren auf den Philippinen 50 muslimische Gefangene mit Projektilen exekutiert haben, die er zuvor in Schweineblut getaucht hatte. Mit dem Blut der f\u00fcr gl\u00e4ubige Muslime unreinen Tiere sei ihnen der Weg ins Paradies versperrt gewesen. Trump: \"Danach gab es 35 Jahre keinen islamistischen Terror mehr!\"\n\nTrump hatte diese Legende bereits mehrfach im Wahlkampf 2016 zitiert. Laut Historikern gibt es keinerlei Anlass, die Geschichte um Pershing f\u00fcr wahr zu halten, die sich angeblich in den Jahren der Moro-Rebellion (1899-1913) zugetragen haben soll.\n\nAnzeige\n\nTrump, der Medien die Verbreitung von gef\u00e4lschten Nachrichten (Fake News) vorwirft, interessierte sich schon im Wahlkampf nicht daf\u00fcr, dass seine Behauptung nicht wahr ist. Auch die moralisch fragw\u00fcrdige Ebene seiner Einlassungen und ein klarer Versto\u00df gegen das V\u00f6lkerrecht, h\u00e4tte Pershing denn tats\u00e4chlich so gehandelt wie behauptet, waren ihm gleichg\u00fcltig.\n\nIn zahlreichen Reaktionen auf Trumps Tweet hie\u00df es in sozialen Netzwerken und anderen Medien, w\u00e4hrend die Welt noch um die Toten von Barcelona trauere, verweise der Pr\u00e4sident der Vereinigten Staaten auf eine L\u00fcge, in der die Exekution Gefangener glorifiziert werde.\n\nDie \"New York Times\" schrieb, der US-Pr\u00e4sident lasse in offensichtlich gro\u00dfer Bedr\u00e4ngnis wieder ganz den ungez\u00fcgelten Wahlk\u00e4mpfer heraus. Andere US-Medien wiesen darauf hin, dass Trump nur Stunden gebraucht habe, um sich zu Barcelona in eindeutigster Weise zu positionieren. Dagegen wolle er die t\u00f6dliche Gewalt bei einer Rassistenkundgebung in Charlottesville auch nach mehr als f\u00fcnf Tagen nicht als Terrorismus brandmarken.\n\nAnzeige\n\nAbgesehen vom fehlenden Wahrheitsgehalt des Trump-Tweets wiesen Historiker auf die m\u00f6glicherweise weitreichenden Folgen hin, wenn ein Pr\u00e4sident der Vereinigten Staaten nahelege, man k\u00f6nne Terroristen nur mit brutalsten Kriegstechniken beikommen.\n\nIn einer ersten Reaktion auf Barcelona hatte Trump getwittert, die Vereinigten Staaten verurteilten die Terrorattacke. \"Bleibt stark und hart, wir lieben Euch!\"\n\nF\u00fcr Trump geht eine bemerkenswert schlechte Woche zu Ende. Ihm schl\u00e4gt besonders scharfe Kritik entgegen, weil er nach gewaltt\u00e4tigen Zusammenst\u00f6\u00dfen in Charlottesville Rassisten und Gegendemonstranten auf eine Stufe gestellt hatte. Kommentatoren sahen dies als Wendepunkt und potenziellen Bruch seiner Pr\u00e4sidentschaft. Andere verweisen darauf, dass Trump bisher alles politisch \u00fcberlebt hat.\n\nTrump beendete zwei Wirtschafts-Beratungsgremien im Wei\u00dfen Haus, bevor diese sich - als Reaktion auf seine Haltung zu Charlottesville - selber aufl\u00f6sen konnten. Ein drittes Gremium will Trump gar nicht mehr weiterplanen. Das belegt seine Entfremdung von der Wirtschaft.\n\nVonseiten der Republikaner kam die sch\u00e4rfste und direkteste Kritik vom prominenten US-Republikaner Bob Corker: \"Der Pr\u00e4sident war bisher nicht f\u00e4hig, die Stabilit\u00e4t oder etwas von der Kompetenz an den Tag zu legen, die er braucht, um erfolgreich zu sein\", sagte er.\n\nDer Senator sprach Trump das Verst\u00e4ndnis f\u00fcr das Wesen der USA ab. \"Er hat zuletzt nicht zu erkennen gegeben, dass er verstanden h\u00e4tte, was dieses Land gestern und heute gro\u00df gemacht hat\", sagte Corker.\n\nCorker (64) ist Senator von Tennessee. Der au\u00dfenpolitische Experte wurde 2016 als Kandidat f\u00fcr das Amt des Vizepr\u00e4sidenten unter Trump gehandelt. Er gilt als vergleichsweise besonnen und differenziert in seinen Wortmeldungen.\n\nIn Trumps Pr\u00e4sidentschaft seien radikale politische \u00c4nderungen n\u00f6tig, sagte Corker. Trump m\u00fcsse aufh\u00f6ren, sich selbst so wichtig zu nehmen, sagte Corker. Der Pr\u00e4sident d\u00fcrfe nicht jeden Morgen aufwachen und erstmal dar\u00fcber nachdenken, was f\u00fcr ihn selbst gut sei.\n\nAuch andere Senatoren r\u00fcckten von Trump ab.\n\nVideo des
